properties.name: York Bridge #4 Lendal Bridge
properties.gc_short_desc: A small micro near the bridge.
properties.gc_long_desc: Lendal Bridge was built by Thomas Page in 1863 and is an iron bridge with Gothic features. It links Station Road with Museum Street and thus York railway station with York Minster, and is part of York's Inner Ring Road. At both ends of the bridge stand towers, Barker Tower to the west and Lendal Tower to the east. A rope ferry previously existed at this location.

properties.name: York Micro #10 Three Wheeling (or not!)
properties.gc_short_desc: A magnetic 35mm placed outside the National Railway Museum
properties.gc_long_desc: The NRM is free to enter and is a great place for families and those who like trains. The NRM in York displays a collection of over 100 locomotives and nearly 200 other items of rolling stock, virtually all of which either ran on the railways of Great Britain or were built there. Also on the 20 acre (8 hectare) site are many hundreds of thousands of other items of social, technical, artistic and historical interest, exhibited mostly in three large halls of a former motive power depot next to the East Coast Main Line, near York railway station. It is the largest museum of its type in the world. It also has more visitors than any other British museum outside London. The NRM was established on its present site, the former York North locomotive depot, in 1975, when it took over the former British Railways collection located in Clapham and the York Railway Museum located elsewhere in the city; since then, the collection has continued to grow. Three wheels ???? Up until the 7th November 2008 we had written - "Don't forget the Yorkshire Wheel" but it is no longer at the NRM The Yorkshire Wheel was almost as high as York Minster - so the views across the city were excellent! Construction started in the last week of March 2006 and the wheel opened to the public on April 12 2006. The structure was 54 metres high, had a diameter of 50 metres, and weighed 365 tonnes. It had 54 climate-controlled pods each holding up to eight people at a time. There was also a VIP pod with a leather interior, DVD sound system, phone and fridge for the Champagne! The ride on the wheel lasted approximately 13 minutes. The Yorkshire Wheel had one million visitors and ceased trading at the National Railway Museum on 2 November 2008. The original Wheel was moved overseas but, at the time of this edit (11/11/08) there was a plan to erect a new Wheel near to the Ouse - maybe a chance for a new York micro cache!

properties.name: St Ethelberts Well
properties.gc_short_desc:
A easy offset Multi-cache, with actual cache within 30 metres of
the WGS84 Datum location provided. It is a micro cache located in
an interesting part of Hereford near to the cathedral and its
associated buildings. A short walk from the town centre and train
station.
properties.gc_long_desc: St Ethelberts Well is a small, somewhat insignifcant, feature in a quiet back-street of Hereford which is now most noteable as being the main drop-off and pick-up point for kids attending the Hereford Cathedral School. The site is adjacent to Castle Green and to the river Wye and is the site of the now long gone, Hereford Castle. Its one of 28 sacred wells listed in the Herefordshire Sites and Monuments record and can be found at: Herefordshire SMR record To find the actual cache take the year when the Hereford Civic Society renevated the well, so that the letters ABCD each represent a single digit number. To find the cache you need substitute the numbers from year in the place of the letters N 52.03.1(A+C)4 W 002.42.(B-A)(C-D)1 The cache is within 30m of the initial coordinates so you don't have too far to go. The cache itself is a magnetic key holder and contains only a log book so make sure you bring a pen or pencil. Also, recommend that you don't attempt the cache between 08h20-08h45 and 15h00-15h40 in weekdays in term-times as there are lots of mummy-muggles doing the school run

properties.name: The Plough
properties.gc_short_desc: Wheelchair accessible cache situated in the town of Hook, Hampshire.  The cache is a magnetic nano so you will need to bring your own pen/pencil to sign the tiny log.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The plough is a relic from Gower's Foundry which was established in Hook by Andrew Gower in 1825. 

The plough was assembled from a number of ploughs bought second hand by Gower's - such items were referred to as "Bitzas" because they were made from "Bitza this and bitza that"!  The plough consists of a Massey-Harris body, with Ransomes and Lister-Cockshutt parts. The plough-shares were made by the "Bedford Plough and Eng. Co. Ltd

Why is it here?
The plough stands as a reminder of Hook's agricultural past and a monument to the once green fields which have fallen victim over the years, one by one, to development.

properties.name: Pagans
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache is about an igneous rock which is one of three types of
rock igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rock.
properties.gc_long_desc:
** **This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about geocaching.** **
                
 
You are standing by a statute of Benjamin Disraeli (Lord
Beaconsfield). He was a fascinating character but we are interested
in the plinth on this occasion. The plinth is made of a very hard
rock.It was formed when different types of rock melted and formed a
new rock when the molten rock crystallised. It has a granular
structure contain many grains. If you look closely you will see
three different materials making up the stone. There is also a dark
mark on the West Face of the plinth on the left hand side near the
words "Earl Beaconsfield” which is part of the original rock
which did not melt when the rock was formed.
The current theory of how such a rock is formed as follows.
Below the surface of the earth on which we walked lies molten rock
magna. Floating on this sea of magna are plates of solid rock.They
are the tectonic plates which are in constant movement . Where the
plates meet one plate will slide on top of another plate forcing it
down into the sea of magna. The downward pressure causes some of
the molten magna to swell up in bubbles and melt some of the rock
above.
The molten rock under great pressure from the solid plate above
cools slowly to form large crystals. Not all the original rock
melts and fragments of it remain in the rock which gives a clue to
how this rock formed. At a later date the newly formed crystals of
rock are forced up and expand as they are under less pressure. This
two stage process forms the rock forming the plinth. There are
other theories but for the purpose of logging the rock you must
answer the following five questions.
1) Name the type of stone
2) Describe the three materials making up the rock and if
possible give their names though this is not essential
3) Give me the name given by stone masons to the dark patch
found in this rock or alternatively the scientific names for these
patches of the original rock.
4) Look at the Dark Patch. Is the shape of it rounded or
angular. Can you give a reason for its shape?
5) Look at five of the rectangular crystals in the stone.
Measure their length, average their size and then state whether the
rock is coarse, medium, or fine grained using the following scale
coarse crystals over 5mm in length, medium crystals between 1-5 mm
in length , or fine crystal less than 1mm in length .
To claim this earthcache as a find please post a photo of the
location (preferably you with your GPS - with your hand pointing to
the dark patch- or just your GPS at the location) and send me an
email with the answers to the five questions, your caching name (eg
Loony Londo) and your email address through my profile.
As soon as you receive my confirmation, you can log this cache
as a find and upload your picture. Please do not reveal the answers
in your log!
The information in this cache about the plinth is taken from
Eric Robinson and Martin Litherland 's booklet "Holiday Geology
Guide Westminster" published by the British Geological Survey but
you do not need to read the leaflet to find the answers as the
information to answer the questions can be found by looking at the
stone and using the Internet
Good rock hunting!
I try to reply to all emails sending me answers within 48
hours.Unfortunately sometimes emails sent by geocaching.com do not
arrive. So if you have not heard from me in reply to your email
with in 72 hours please feel free to send me another email.

properties.name: Goldfinger Revisited
properties.gc_long_desc:
Memo
James
I want you to go down to Tiger Bay Cardiff, birthplace of Dame Shirley Bassey. She sang the title song to three of your films, Goldfinger, Diamonds are Forever and Moonraker. Its changed a lot since she was born and the docks are no longer there. A small micro cache has been left there containing some items of interest to us. Some French and Austrian wartime coinage during the time when your creator was spying for us in those countries, some coins from our North American cousins, possibly some from Hong Kong, and two Blutenite crystals. 
You will need to bring a pen with you to sign the small log, and not one of those that either fires or explodes.
This is a very public spot.
Make sure they are still in tact, keep a watchful eye on the comings and goings and leave them there. 
There’s plenty of space to park the Aston, but being a Royal Marine, you may wish to approach from the sea. Just like in Goldfinger when you wore a DJ under your wet suit, we did like that! 
There are plenty of bars and restaurants here now where you can order your Martini shaken not stirred. They have even named one after our man in Havana.
The co-ordinates will take you to a large Celtic Ring, use this as a base to home in on the cache. Just remember two things, deck level and ‘The Hole in the Wall Gang’.
We have been informed that the local beauty has already been taken by a member of the Douglas Clan, and the new upstart, Charlotte C is far too young and mouthy for an agent like you.
If you need to escape, there is a train every half hour back into the city or there is always a speedboat across the bay to Penarth.
Good luck old man, you might need it.
M

properties.name: Helical Ridges
properties.gc_short_desc:
At the cache site there is a large slab of rock with a metal pole
with a red box on top of it. You will need to look at it closely.
The stone is from the Tithonian period which is the latest age of
the Late Jurassic epoch or the uppermost stage of the Upper
Jurassic series. It has fossils in it!
properties.gc_long_desc:
** **This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about geocaching.** **
                
 
Approximately 145 million years ago the land mass which forms
the United Kingdom was located much further south. The area was at
the bottom of a shallow warm sea filled with living creatures .As
the sea water heated up in the sunshine, it released a gas. The gas
reacted with positive ions in the water to form a salt.
The salt precipitated out of the and fell to the bottom of the
sea Over millions of years the precipitate continued to fell to the
sea floor in layers and formed a rock. This is how sedimentary
rocks form. This type of rock is called limestone.
As time past different conditions and objects felling to the sea
floor resulted in differences between the layers of rock laid down.
The creatures living in the sea died and their remains fell to the
sea floor and the rock formed around them In the rock you are
looking at after a while the remains of the creatures dissolved
leaving holes in the rock. If you look at the rock you will see
hollows whose shape is an impressions of the creatures. The voids
are a type of fossil.
After many years the rocks moved north due to continental drift
and were up lifted to form an island just off the South Coast of
England Several layers of the rock from this area makes a good
building stone and were used all over London.
To log the cache you will have to answer four questions:-
1) Name the type of stone
2) Give me the name given by stone masons to the fossil found in
this rock
3)Give me one of the Latin or scientific names of the fossil,
there are two.
4) Describe the fossils .
To claim this earthcache as a find please post a photo of the
location (preferably you with your GPS - with your hand pointing to
one of these fossils- or just your GPS at the location) and send me
an email with the answers, your caching name (eg Loony Londo) and
your email address through my profile.
As soon as you receive my confirmation, you can log this cache
as a find and upload your picture. Please do not reveal the answers
in your log!
Good fossil hunting!
I try to reply to all emails sending me answers within 48
hours.Unfortunately sometimes emails sent by geocaching.com do not
arrive. So if you have not heard from me in reply to your email
with in 72 hours please feel free to send me another email.

properties.name: Who Was Here 3: The Runaway Nan-O What A Liberty
properties.gc_name: Who Was Here 3: The Runaway Nan-O What A Liberty
properties.gc_long_desc:
Another of the caches that take you to filming locations for the Doctor Who series, though in this case it was actually a Christmas Special.

This is one of a series of caches based on locations used for filming Doctor Who, be the filming the latest series or any of the earlier ones.  If you're near such a location and want to add to the series, just let me know so I can keep the numbers without duplicates and please keep to the naming convention of starting the series with "Who Was Here: ".
Thanks

"The Runaway Bride" was the first appearance of Catherine Tate as ‘Donna’, hence the Nan reference in the title.  St Johns Church is where the interiors shots of the wedding were filmed.

I know that the name of this cache is a mix of "Doctor Who" and "The Catherine Tate Show", but that’s to give you a clue as to what you are looking for – it’s a nano.  You can’t see it at all easily, but as it is magnetic, it will pull away easily enough.

While you’re in the area, and since I can’t place caches at these places because (a) they are too close and (b) there’s no way of putting caches in these places. 

If you’ve found The Runaway Nan, look up and you’ll see St David’s Market used in “Love and Monsters” where Elton (Mark Warren) tracks down Jackie (Camille Coduri) doing her shopping.  Look further down you’ll see the Howells department store, if you go down the lane beside this, you’ll get to the other end and look back to see the façade that was blown up in “Rose” as the store where Rose worked.  This also appeared in “The Christmas Invasion”.

Back at the cache, you only have to turn around to see the Queen’s Arcade which appeared in “Rose”, as did Working Street to your left as you look at Queen’s Arcade.  Working Street also appeared in “Voyage of the Damned”, it is the point where The Doctor (David Tennent) and Astrid Peth (Kylie Minogue) spoke to the paper seller (Bernard Cribbins).  If you go down the High Street Arcade, you’ll see the spot which appeared in “Ghost Machine”.  Turn right at the top of Working Street and you’ll be in the pedestrian Queen Street, which has appeared variously in “The End of the World”, “Blink” and “Smith and Jones”.

There are others in the area, but this is getting long enough already.  Enjoy the cache.

Warning, when I was searching for the location on this cache, I only had a 15m accuracy.

properties.name: Britannia Quay
properties.gc_long_desc: This is a nano cache – please bring your own pen/pencil. Please just initial the log roll - no need for full names! On the Eastern edge of Cardiff Bay is Britannia Quay, home to the Bay Visitor Centre, Norwegian Church, Lightship and the Fossil Walk. This place can be busy – so engage stealth mode. There is parking close by – free on Sundays or after 18:30 otherwise.South Wales Geocachers are proud to organising The UK Mega in 2011   The event will be held in Swansea on July 31st

Parking at Bitton is available at Golden Valley Lane, N51.25.497 W002.27.414. Parking at Keynsham, N 51° 25.150 W 002° 29.404 the distance between is just less than 2 miles.

properties.name: Peace Pole
properties.gc_short_desc: Such a lovely city as Norwich deserves a urban microcache!
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache is a 35mm film canister and is placed in a little park
in the city called Chapelfield Gardens. Whilst you are in the city,
why not see the sights – including the covered market, the
cathedral and some great little cobbled back streets with unusual
shops.
The original cache went walkies so we replaced it in a slightly
different place.

properties.name: Last Delivery (London)
properties.gc_short_desc: A medium sized cache (6"x8"x2.5" tupperware container) in a small park. Note: The park is open during the day and locked at night.
properties.gc_long_desc: PLEASE: Do not leave any travel bugs outside the container. Do not use zip lock bags to increase the capacity of the container. The Corporation of London and the park gardeners are aware of this cache, however using extra bags may increase the likelihood of the cache being found by geomuggles and then being destroyed. Let's keep this cache safe for everyone. Although Nick the gardener no longer works in this park, Jessex would still like to thank him for helping with the establishment of the cache, thanks Nick! Thanks to the many cachers throughout the world who helped make this cache the most visited one in the UK! -------------------------------------------------------------------- A tiny oasis opened in 1880, this stamp of a park is enveloped by the City. We hope you have a chance to recuperate from your day of caching in this pleasant environment. The location is between St. Paul's Cathedral and the Museum of London, an interesting area to explore. Bear in mind it is busy on weekday lunchtimes with the City folk (unless it's raining!). The park was formerly a graveyard, stones of which remain around the sides. Don't miss the wall of Commemmoration of Heroic Sacrifice, an unusual and touching feature. One of the names on this wall is assumed by Natalie Portman in the film "Closer". (Please return the cache as you found it so as to keep it well hidden - thank you.) PLEASE NOTE: Since many Travel Items go in and out of this cache the owner must sometimes mark items missing. They can still be tracked via the Trackable Items page.

properties.name: 16th Century Pub (Central London)
properties.gc_short_desc:
This pub is straight out of Dickens and must be a strong contender
for "Quaintest pub in London". The pub is closed at the weekends
but you can access the front and answer the question without
entering the private area of the alleyway.
properties.gc_long_desc: This timbered pub was built in 1546 and is still in use today. Apparently this is the second oldest pub in London. It is hidden close to the given coordinates although you'll need to work at the last bit (GPS reception at the pub was impossible). This is my favourite pub consisting of a fascinating building, excellent beer and two cosy bars. I often came here when I worked in the area but you wouldn't normally find it unless someone brought you here. If you fancy a pint then you'll have to visit during the week because pubs in the City are closed at the weekend. The difficulty reflects the problems in GPS reception and also the additional problem of actually finding the pub when you get to the coordinates. Remember the date, 1546 - you'll need it! To claim this cache, mail the answers to these questions through "The Wombles" profile link at the top of the page, and tick the box to release your email address. Under no circumstances post the answers in your log. 1. The name of the pub and 2. The number of red gem stones (jewels) on one side of the pub sign on the pub itself. Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. You must physically visit this cache in order to log it, please do not abuse this requirement (I regret that I will have to delete logs that do not meet these requirements). When you email the answer then please remember to release your email address to enable us to reply. Why not combine your visit here with St Eltheldreda's micro-cache which is just round the corner. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: The London Rainbow Cache 2 - Orange
properties.gc_short_desc: Originally set by McDehack, then enhanced by Master Mariner.
properties.gc_long_desc: The London Rainbow Cache series comprises seven virtual caches that can be logged individually. Information obtained from each cache can then be used to find an eighth, physical cache.   The London Rainbow Cache 2 - Orange This is the second of seven virtual caches each of which has a connection to the colours of the rainbow. The sites, for all the virtual caches, are a little bit off the well beaten tourist tracks but take the visitor to interesting places, in and around London, that would not normally be seen. The caches can be done in any order but information will need to be collected from all the caches to help find the final cache. Good heavens, it's a pub! It was BUILT in ABCD. A world famous composer lived, for a short while, in a square near here during the year EFGH. To claim this as a find please post a photo (within 24 hours - if you can't upload a picture when you are logging, then please don't log till you can or post a note in the meantime) of EACH person logging with your GPSr at the location (WITHOUT REVEALING ANY OF THE ANSWERS) AND using the below answers, send a blank email to surnameABCDEFGH@howeasy.org (eg travis19022002@howeasy.org). Make sure you include include your caching name (eg rodz) as the subject of the mail or your log may be deleted. You will receive a confirmation email almost instantly if your answers are correct, at which time you may log your find. a. The name of the composer? b. The year the pub was built? BE VERY CAREFUL! THE ANSWER IS NOT 1776 OR 1979 c. The year the composer lived here?   To locate the final cache the year the pub was built in ABCD. B+E = position "W8". Latitude = N 12 34.567 Longitude = W 123 45.678

properties.name: The London Rainbow Cache 4 - Green
properties.gc_short_desc: Originally set by McDehack, then enhanced by Master Mariner.
properties.gc_long_desc: The London Rainbow Cache series comprises seven virtual caches that can be logged individually. Information obtained from each cache can then be used to find an eighth, physical cache.   The London Rainbow Cache 4 - Green This is the fourth of seven virtual caches each of which has a connection to the colours of the rainbow. The sites, for all the virtual caches, are a little bit off the well beaten tourist tracks but take the visitor to interesting places, in and around London, that would not normally be seen. The caches can be done in any order but information will need to be collected from all the caches to help find the final cache. This is an area of many colours. From this spot, the hospital can just be seen, go east about 100 metres and find the school that was once a hospital built in ABCD and closed in EFGH. The "colour" of this hospital is not the colour in the cache title. To claim this as a find please post a photo of EACH person logging (within 24 hours - if you can't upload a picture when you are logging, then please don't log till you can or post a note in the meantime) with your GPSr at the location (WITHOUT REVEALING ANY OF THE ANSWERS) AND using the below answers, send a blank email to hospitalnameABCDEFGHFIRSTwordofpubname@howeasy.org (eg barts19022002blackties@howeasy.org). Make sure you include your caching name (eg rodz) as the subject of the mail or your log may be deleted. You will receive a confirmation email almost instantly if your answers are correct, at which time you may log your find. a. The name of the hospital?(8 characters long) b. The year the hospital was built? c. The year the hospital was closed? d. The first word of the name of the pub that gives this pub its rainbow colour? (nine characters)   To locate the final cache use the years ABCD and EFGH: F-A = position "W7" G = position "N1" D = position "N5" Latitude = N 12 34.567 Longitude = W 123 45.678

properties.name: The London Rainbow Cache 5 - Blue
properties.gc_short_desc: Originally set by McDehack, then enhanced by Master Mariner.
properties.gc_long_desc: The London Rainbow Cache series comprises seven virtual caches that can be logged individually. Information obtained from each cache can then be used to find an eighth, physical cache.   The London Rainbow Cache 5 - Blue This is the fifth of seven virtual caches each of which has a connection to the colours of the rainbow. The sites, for all the virtual caches, are a little bit off the well beaten tourist tracks but take the visitor to interesting places, in and around London, that would not normally be seen. The caches can be done in any order but information will need to be collected from all the caches to help find the final cache. "The school was founded in ABCD for the education of poor children". But were they taught to spell? The present building was erected in 1709 so do not email this year as the founded date is clearly shown on both the north and south ends of the building. To claim this as a find please post a photo of EACH person logging (within 24 hours) with your GPSr at the location (WITHOUT REVEALING ANY OF THE ANSWERS) AND using the below answers, send a blank email to wordABCD@howeasy.org (eg goofy2002@howeasy.org). Make sure you include your caching name (eg rodz) as the subject of the mail or your log may be deleted. You will receive a confirmation email almost instantly if your answers are correct, at which time you may log your find. a. What word can be spelled differently? (four characters long) b. What year was the school founded?     To locate the final cache use the year ABCD: C-D = position "W3" C-A-B = position "W4" Latitude = N 12 34.567 Longitude = W 123 45.678

properties.name: A Meating place for Martyrs
properties.gc_short_desc:
The spelling of the title is not wrong. It could be a clue for this
virtual cache site.
A short walk from some of London's more well known land marks.
This spot is steeped in history. Many tourist would be pleased to
explore the area if they knew of it.
When you arrive at the site. Find for me as evidence. THE FULL
NAMES OF 3 JOHN'S AND A BILL. Send by email to me, and then log
your visit on this page.

properties.name: Paddington Dare (W London)
properties.gc_short_desc: Something to do whilst waiting for the train.
properties.gc_long_desc: Take a walk round the station, and look for something slightly predictable. Find for us as evidence: what is written on the bearly used suitcase. Send it by email to us, and then log your visit on this page. Don't post the answer here please, even if encrypted. Based on an original concept by Sangsvan from Sweden. Screenplay by JeremyP For an explination of this cache click Here Please check out the G.A.G.B and G:UK web sites. They offer support for all Geocachers in the UK.

properties.name: TechnOLOGY (Central London)
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy virtual cache with an interesting piece of history.
properties.gc_long_desc: This location has a link with history showing the amazing pace of technological development in just over 100 years. The subject of this cache certainly changed the modern world and could be considered a small step towards GPS, the Internet and many other technologies which are now an everyday part of our lives. At the time of this event, the building on the site was the Central Telegraph office. The answer is on the wall - the wall of a very appropriate corporate headquarters. Don't linger under the watchful eye of the security cameras! To claim this cache, mail us the exact wording of the circular grey historical plaque/sign on the wall. Mail the answers through our profile at the top of the page. The answer is NOT "City of London, Ward of Cheap" Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. You must physically visit this cache in order to log it, please do not abuse this requirement (I regret that I will have to delete logs that do not meet these requirements). When you email the answer then please remember to release your email address to enable us to reply. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: The Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament)
properties.gc_name: The Palace of Westminster (Houses of Parliament)
properties.gc_short_desc:
This virtual cache is on the site of the old Palace of Westminster,
currently better known as “The Houses of Parliament” and “Big
Ben”.
properties.gc_long_desc: Big Ben is famous throughout the world, but few people know that Big Ben is the clock bell and not the tower or building. There is more information about Big Ben at this web site. The whole building is called the Palace of Westminster and was originally constructed as the principle residence of the King during the 11th century. The only remaining buildings from that time, Westminster Hall and the Jewel Tower, were built between 1097 and 1099. The Royal court carried out the functions of government at that time, so all the other government buildings grew up around this location. This site only became the permanent seat of what we would recognise as Parliament (The House of Commons) in 1547. There is more information about The Houses of Parliament at this web site. This cache is placed near The Jewel Tower, built to protect the King's personal treasure by Edward III. Much of the medieval Palace of Westminster was destroyed by fire 1834 and The Jewel Tower was the only surviving complete building. The Jewel Tower has a moat and quay. Access to this cache is via a waist-high barrier which is open between 10.00 - 17.00 during the Summer (1 April - 31 Oct), and 10.00 - 16.00 during the Winter (1 Nov - 20 Mar). In order to claim this cache as a find, please answer the following questions and mail the answer to us through our profile above (including your return email address): 1. When was the moat constructed and 2. How many navvies did it take to dig out, and 3. How long? Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. You must physically visit this cache in order to log it, please do not abuse this requirement (I regret that I will have to delete logs that do not meet these requirements). When you email the answer then please remember to release your email address to enable us to reply. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: Sharpstone Ring 2 : The Village
properties.gc_short_desc: Cache 2 of 6 on a 1.7 mile (approx) circular walk around beautiful village of Sharpstone. Route can be muddy and therefore not really suitable for pushchairs or wheelchairs. Marking the caches proved tricky due to tree cover so it may be advisable to take the clue with you. If anyone has better coordinates then pls let me have them!!!
properties.gc_long_desc:
If this cache is done on its own it is suitable for push/wheelchairs.

After you find it head onwards to the T junction, turn right then left at the drain cover.

properties.name: Pineal Accolade
properties.gc_short_desc:
Welsome to this 4-stage puzzle cache centred round Clifton Village, Bristol. The total walking distance is less than 1km. Not wheelchair accessible because of steps.

Note: dogs are allowed on the vast majority of the trail but will need to be tied up outside one location
properties.gc_long_desc:
Follow clues one to three to obtain the numbers you will need to find the cache.

========================================

CLUE ONE

The starting coordinates lead you to the first clue.

Look for a Roman numeral on the front of this red object, towards the base.

A = that number.

Now use A to find clue two.

========================================

CLUE TWO

The coordinates of clue two are:

N 51° 27.1A1 W 002° 37.42A

Clue two is a metal object above you. Number of points = B, number of horizontal bars = C.

========================================

CLUE THREE

The coordinates of clue three are:

N 51° 27.2B0 W 002° 37.C44

Clue three is the explanatory text, which lists several dimensions. Use these dimensions to give you the values of D and E.

The fourth dimension in the list is DE5 feet.

Now use the numbers from all the clues to find the cache!


========================================

THE CACHE

The coordinates of your final destination are:

N 51° 27.DCC W 002° 37.EDA

There are two extra clues in the hint section but once you have the right coordinates it shouldn't be too difficult to find the cache.

========================================

The cache is a small round tupperware container. It is hidden in a publicly accessible place, so beware of onlookers.

The inaugural contents are;

Info sheet, logbook + pencil
Set of stickers
Pink silk cufflinks
Dresden thimble
Country Club Tasmania card
Mini mirror
World Trade Centre NY squashed coin souvenir
Japanese 5 yen coin

Happy hunting!

properties.name: St Andrews nano
properties.gc_short_desc: Tiny nano in this pretty little park in the city. Easily accessible to wheelchairs and fun for children as nearby to playground.
properties.gc_long_desc: Congratulations to Wear Pilgrims for FTF

properties.name: B&HM - Kings Road (formerly known as “Grand View")
properties.gc_name: B&HM - Kings Road (formerly known as “Grand View")
properties.gc_short_desc: SHORT DESCRIPTION: A traditional cache. You are looking for a magnetic micro. Difficulty rating due to muggles. There is only room for a log book, so bring your own pencil please.
properties.gc_long_desc:
LONG DESCRIPTION:
You are at a very busy part of Brighton’s seafront. 
From here you can see the prestigious Grand Hotel. A venue often used for conferences, particularly by political parties. 

There are lots of things to do here - including bungee bouncing, playing on fairground rides, dancing, watching a film, or shopping in the nearby ‘Lanes’ http://www.visitbrighton.com/site/maps-guides-and-interactive/brightons-villages/the-lanes . You can lose some money in the modern arcade or have fun in the Historical Penny Arcade instead.  There are also several art galleries, places to eat and even a free Fishermen’s Museum… http://www.visitbrighton.com/site/culture/brighton-fishing-museum-p56323  . 
Of course, to the East is the famous Palace Pier and the Sealife Centre. 
You are looking for a magnetic micro. I wanted to place a large cache but hiding spaces are tricky here. There is only room for a log book, so bring your own pencil please.
Stealth is required as this is a very busy location. 1 point added to difficulty rating due to muggles.

properties.name: Portsmouth Parks - Brunel Monument
properties.gc_short_desc: Another in the Portsmouth Parks series.
properties.gc_long_desc:
A new monument in the middle of St George's Square, Portsea, adjacent to The Hard and Ordnance Road was unveiled by the Right Worshipful the Lord Mayor of Portsmouth Councillor Robin Sparshatt on 7th April 2006 to commemorate the bicentenary of the birth of Isambard Kingdom Brunel.

The cache (a magnetic black nano) is located close to but not on the monument. There are plenty of benches to take a few minutes to enjoy this pretty little area.

Cache contains logbook only so bring a pen or pencil. Please write small.

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: Portsmouth Parks - Ravelin
properties.gc_short_desc: Another in the Portsmouth Parks series to get you to the rarer areas of greenery within the city.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Due the busy nature of the area the cache is a black magnetic nano containing a logbook only.

Ravelin park occupies the site of fortifications built by Sir Bernard de Gomme between 1665 and 1685. The area of Old Portsmouth used to be surrounded by defencive fortifications including walls, bastions, a moat and tall triangular constructions known as ravelins.

Ravelins were located beyond the city wall. Their initial function was as a fortification, however, if and when overrun, defenders could fall back and fire down into the ravelin from the wall above. The triangular shape of the ravelin would force a wave of attackers to divide before getting to the city wall.

During the 19th century the fortifications were demolished, the site became the city's army garrison headquarters. Ravelin House, Town Mount and Gun House were built, being used to house senior army officers.

The army left the site in the 1960's and the land was transferred in 1969 to Portsmouth Polytechnic, which later became the University of Portsmouth.

In order to be accessible at all times, the cache is located on the perimeter of the park and can be retrieved directly from the pavement.

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: Jack the Ripper 7 - Jack's Hideaway
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache is one of seven set in the East End of London tracking
the murder sites of Jack the Ripper's victims. It is designed to be
a walking tour as well as a hunt. Only cache 7 is a real
microcache, you have to visit caches 1-6 first to collect the
clues. The walk is flat and on paved streets. To do all the caches
in a single day would require a 2.5 mile walk.
properties.gc_long_desc: To reach Jack’s hideaway, you will need to complete the six caches memoralising the sites where Jack’s victims were killed. Having collected the clues, the co-ordinates for the “real” cache are as follows:- North (A-H) (N). (C-4) (D). (E-7) (F) (G-7) West 00(K). (K)(M-4). (N+4) (P+B+J) (Q-5) The cache is a micro cache hidden in a quiet backwater. You will need to watch for muggles. Please make sure that you cover the cache with leaves or sticks once you find it so that it does not disappear!! History buffs should note that the site of this cache was once an ancient Roman burial ground and recent archaeological digs have unearthed many fascinating treasures - visit The Museum of London to find out more.

properties.name: Portsmouth Parks - John Pounds Memorial Gardens
properties.gc_name: Portsmouth Parks - John Pounds Memorial Gardens
properties.gc_short_desc: Another in the Portsmouth Parks series to get you to the rarer areas of greenery within the city.
properties.gc_long_desc:
JOHN POUNDS 1766 - 1839 Shoemender whose work for the poor of this district inspired the Ragged School Movement is buried in the Memorial Garden. Spend some time looking around the gardens before or after finding the cache as there is some interesting history here.

The cache is outside the gardens on the public footpath area. It is wheelchair accessible. Because this is an urban area it is deliberately easy to find so that you don't have to hang around too long searching. Nothing needs to be moved or uncovered.

The area can get busy in the mornings as schools are nearby. There can also be weddings held in the nearby church so stealth and timing may be needed.

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: Monarch Way South #6
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the sixth of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way from Wick following the course of the River Boyd towards Upton Cheyney.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ords for parking at Court Farm are N51.27.021 W002.26.279. Limited roadside parking is available in Upton Cheyney but there is little opportunity for parking along the route due to the narrow country lanes. The distance from the Court Farm parking to Upton Cheyney is about 2 ½ miles. 

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch and several points in between.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. We have now started a Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court and will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the intention of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.

This cache is accessible from the road and is thus wheelchair and buggy friendly.  You are looking for a camouflaged nano container – bring your own writing instrument!

properties.name: Going Underground (not anymore) #1
properties.gc_short_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about
geocaching**
properties.gc_long_desc: This cache is a magnetised key container, coords are within 40 feet due to the buildings. This is one in a short series of caches that are to be found at or near entrances to dissused London transportation sites. This cache is at Hyde Park Corner station while the station still exists this entrance is long since closed. As with Angel station, the change in entrance location was brought about by the conversion from lifts to escalators. Room just wasn't available. You can find more information about this station if you CLICK HERE

properties.name: Going Underground (not anymore) #2
properties.gc_short_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about
geocaching**
properties.gc_long_desc: This cache is a magnetised keysafe container located to the left of the newsagent, coords are within 40 feet due to the buildings. This is one in a short series of caches that are to be found at or near entrances to dissused London transportation sites. This cache is at Down Street station which was opened on 15th March 1907, it was never very busy due to the proximity of the larger Hyde Park Corner and Dover Street stations. After Dover Street was refurbished and renamed as Green Park Station, Down street was duly closed on May 21st 1932. Intrestingly Winston Churchill and his wartime cabinet used this station as a shelter during the early part of the war when the Cabinet War Rooms weren't available. You can find more information about this station if you CLICK HERE

properties.name: Big Ben's little brother
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching
properties.gc_long_desc:
Little Ben is a cast iron miniature clock tower, situated close to
Victoria station. In design it mimics the clock tower commonly
known as Big Ben of the Palace of Westminster found at the other
end of Victoria Street.
Little Ben was manufactured, according to Pevsner, by Gillett
& Johnston of Croydon, and was erected in 1892; removed from
the site in 1964, and restored and re-erected in 1981 by
Westminster City Council with sponsorship from Elf Aquitaine Ltd
"offered as a gesture of Franco-British friendship".
Unusually for clocks in Britain, Little Ben is set one hour in
advance of Greenwich Mean Time throughout the year. During the
summer this coincides with British Summer Time, while in the winter
this is the same as Central European Time. Although this means that
the clock displays the local time for only half the year, it does
demonstrate a preference for neither Britain nor Europe. This
sentiment is captured in the rhyming couplet Apology for Summer
Time signed J.W.R. affixed to the body of the clock:
My hands you may retard or may advance
my heart beats true for England as for France.

properties.name: Parliament View
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching. A black magnetic keysafe ...
properties.gc_long_desc: This spot affords one of my favourite views in London, particularly good at night. Close by is Lambeth Palace which is not open to the public, and The Museum of Garden History which is open to the public. Many thanks to Westie Walker & The Weston's for helping keep this cache up and running.

properties.name: Abbot John Islip
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching. A wheelchair accessible magnetic keysafe cache, set as a thank you to all the other cachers who set and maintain Londons' micros ... I love 'em!
properties.gc_long_desc: John Islip (b.1464) was Abbot of Westminster from 1500 until his death in 1532, one of the last pre-Reformation Abbots. He was responsible for adding his own Jesus chapel off the north ambulatory and finally completed the nave vaulting and glazed the west window of Westminster Abbey. The cache is set in the street named after him. Members Only until the first 5 finders have been!Update 22/11/06 5 finders have been so the cache goes public today. Update 27/06/08 Cache relocated see spoiler and new clue.update 02/08/08 Co-ords updated to new cache location and clue changed slightly to suit new location.

properties.name: Tate Britain ~ Mark 2
properties.gc_short_desc:
You are looking for a black magnetic keysafe, reachable from the
public footpath. Please ensure you replace exactly as found to
ensure the cache can be reached by a wheelchair user.
properties.gc_long_desc: A cache near one of Londons' premier galleries. The Tate Britain contains British art from 1500 and offers a wide selection of permanent and temporary exhibits. Acknowledgement is given to Currykev who previously had a cache nearby.

properties.name: B&HM - New Road
properties.gc_short_desc:
Please place this cache back EXACTLY where you find in. Up
the 'top'. Anywhere else and it is visible to all!! Part
of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the
Brighton and Hove Monopoly board. You are looking for a 35mm film
canister
properties.gc_long_desc:
New Road, a street laid out in the early 19th century to divert
people away from The Prince Consorts' new Brighton Pavilion. The
street, which became run-down and dominated by traffic, has been
redesigned as the city’s first shared surface, in which the
street surface and furniture are laid out to encourage defensive
driver behaviour. Since its opening, the street has become
well-used and a centrepiece of the city Cultural Quarter and won a
Civic Trust Award in 2009. Have put dangerous area attribute as it
is a road/pavement. Watch out for cars

properties.name: B&HM - The Dome
properties.gc_short_desc:
Part of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the
Brighton and Hove Monopoly board. You are looking for a 35mm Film
canister. This cache is accessible once more - happy caching!
properties.gc_long_desc: The Brighton Dome is an arts venue in Brighton, England that contains the Concert Hall, Corn Exchange and the Pavilion Theatre. All three venues are linked to the rest of the Royal Pavilion Estate by an underground tunnel to the Royal Pavilion in Pavilion Gardens and through shared corridors to Brighton Museum, as the entire complex was built for the Prince of Wales and completed in 1805. Originally the Concert Hall was the Prince of Wales' stables with the Corn Exchange being a riding school. William Porden designed the new stables and riding school for the Prince. Inspired by water colour pictures of India he created an incredible building in the Indo-Saracenic style with a vast glass dome (24 metres in diameter and 19 metres high) covering the main hall. Many pessimists predicted that this daring construction would collapse once the scaffolding was removed. The stables were converted to a Concert Hall around 1860. Since this time the Corn Exchange and Concert Hall have gone through many different guises with the latest renovation of the Concert Hall taking place in 2001/2 and costing £22m. This rebirth was ushered in with the help of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, Courtney Pine, Nigel Kennedy and Fatboy Slim (amongst others). (Taken from our friend wikipedia! Brighton Dome

properties.name: Monarch Way South #7
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the seventh of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way from Wick following the course of the River Boyd towards Upton Cheyney.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ords for parking at Court Farm are N51.27.021 W002.26.279. Limited roadside parking is available in Upton Cheyney but there is little opportunity for parking along the route due to the narrow country lanes. The distance from the Court Farm parking to Upton Cheyney is about 2 ½ miles. 

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch and several points in between.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. We have now started a Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court and will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the intention of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.

This cache is accessible from the road and is thus buggy friendly; wheelchair users will need able bodied assistance to reach the cache.  You are looking for a small screw top container.

properties.gc_short_desc: Brighton and Hove Monopoly Series
properties.gc_long_desc:
Part of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the Brighton and Hove Monopoly board.

Madeira Drive can get very busy in the summer months.

properties.gc_long_desc:

properties.name: shocking
properties.gc_long_desc: A new area i recently discovered whilst out walking doing one of thehoomers,you are looking for a 35mm canister.dont worry you wont get hurt? i have placed it low down so young and old can get to it easy,enjoy a srtoll to Bicester village,and even get porridge,hope you enjoy this one

properties.name: The South Bank Lion
properties.gc_short_desc:
A cache on the south bank, visit at night best a it gives a great
view of the Big Ben
properties.gc_long_desc: The South Bank Lion was originally red in colour, due to it being located outside the Red Lion Brewery, which was demolished to make way for the Royal Festival Hall. Thanks to George VI the Lion was saved, and was moved outside Waterloo Station. When the station was made bigger in 1966 the Lion was moved to its current home. The lion was then renamed the ‘South Bank Lion’. The Coade Stone statue was designed by W.F. Woodington, and is 13 feet long and 12 feet high, and weighs over 13 tons. Cachers, who clearly are not reading this page are reporting the co-ords are off! Difficulty increased by half a star to take note of muggle factor. ***Read below, and then understand the co-ords get you to the GENERAL AREA, you then have to solve the clue to find the cache*** The log is just a bag and log replaced as last location proved to be inapropriate. Use the co-ords to get you to the general area and to admire the lion, then refer to the clue, look around you, it's under U, second in from left. Wheelchair accessible

properties.name: Time At The Bar - Marquis of Granby
properties.gc_name: Time At The Bar - Marquis of Granby
properties.gc_short_desc:
Located in Winchester centre in a very mugglesum area.

Please do not drive down the road where the cache is as it is a bus and taxi only route.

Parking is in the city center car parks or use the park and ride.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Time At The Bar series will take you around the centre of Winchester to visit some of the gone and forgotten public houses that ceased trading long ago.

There will hopefully be 8 caches when the series is complete

The caches can all be done on a pleasant walk in one day in good weather or on their own.

If you would like to learn a little more about Winchesters forgotten history, have a go at GC1279A which is a mystry cache created by Juggles.


On the site where the cache is, stood The Suffolk Arms which was demolished in 1934. The pub was origonaly called the Marquis of Granby where the local freemasons held meetings between 1816 and 1831.

This one is best tackeld at quiet times i.e. early morning and late evening as it is right in the center of town.

properties.name: BBB 10  – Sweet Home Chicago
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is track ten of eleven caches celebrating “The Music from the Soundtrack” album released on June 20, 1980 by the Blues Brothers Band,
Each Bristol based cache is located at a place that has links to either the song title or the lyric content.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Track 10 Sweet Home Chicago" (Johnson) – 7:48

Elwood and Jake and the Blues Brothers Band - Dedicated to the musician Magic Sam

Sweet Home Chicago" is a popular blues standard in the twelve bar form. It was first recorded and is credited to have been written by Robert Johnson. Over the years the song has become one of the most popular anthems for the city of Chicago despite ambiguity in Johnson's original lyrics.
In fact, the song is a variation of "Kokomo Blues", a song popularized by Scrapper Blackwell, Madlyn Davis and most notably by James Arnold. Arnold's version of the song, which he recorded in 1934 as "Old Original Kokomo Blues", was such a success that he changed his performing name to Kokomo Arnold.

The earliest recorded version of the song by Scrapper Blackwell in 1928 referred to Kokomo, Indiana, a city well known to the Indianapolis-based guitarist. Kokomo was famous for the number of traffic lights. It was known to truckers as "stop light city" and to blues singers after Arnold as "level light city".

The Cache is a nano container just big enough for a rolled up log sheet situated next to a place where you can rock out Chicago style and to the imax

Enjoy the cache

* Congratulations to The Evil Poles for being FTF *

properties.name: Banksy woz 'ere
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching. A microcache in Leake Street, which was the site of the Cans Festival in May 2008.
properties.gc_long_desc: Banksy is a celebrated British street artist and in May 2008 he brought together a number of street artists to put on a display in a tunnel that had largely fallen into decay. If you are here during the day, why not take time to view the tunnel? Other examples of Banksy work can be seen across London, click here for the Google map of other locations. If any other cachers have access to the other sites, how about a series? The cache is a black nano, attached to something black, it is lowdown and in full view, beware of being overlooked. Take a paperclip or similar in case you cannot extract the logsheet, no sign = no find.

properties.name: Time At The Bar - Masons Arms
properties.gc_name: Time At The Bar - Masons Arms
properties.gc_short_desc: Located in one of the back streets in Winchester city centre. Parking on street is for permit holders only 08:00 to 18:00 Monday to Saurday, there is a car park nearby. Please be respectfull of local residents.

The Time At The Bar series will take you around the centre of Winchester to visit some of the gone and forgotten public houses that ceased trading long ago.

There will hopefully be 8 caches when the series is complete

The caches can all be done on a pleasant walk in one day in good weather or on their own.

If you would like to learn a little more about Winchesters forgotten history, have a go at GC1279A which is a mystry cache created by Juggles.


Number 101 used to be The Masons Arms which ceased trading in 1924. The pub was possibley named after the stonemasons who built the cathedrial.

The High Street end was a slum area that was redoveloped in the 1960's and replaced by the council offices and a hotel where The Royal Standard once stood.

properties.name: SideTracked - Clapham Junction
properties.gc_short_desc: A nano, suitable for everyone by Clapham Junction station.
properties.gc_long_desc:
{From Wikipedia}

Clapham Junction railway station is located at St John's Hill in the south-west of Battersea in the London Borough of Wandsworth. It is not in Clapham but the area, influenced by the station, is commonly known as Clapham Junction. Many routes from London's two busiest termini, Waterloo and Victoria funnel through Clapham Junction.

By number of trains passing through each day, some 2000 (most of which stop), it is the busiest railway station in Britain, and in Europe as signage of 17 June 2005 proclaimed. It is less busy by the number of passengers, most of whom pass straight through. Interchanges make some forty per cent of the activity and by that count too it is the busiest station in the UK.


===

The cache...
You are looking for a 'nano', placed away from the busy areas of the station and a short walk from the southern entrance to the station.
Please replace as found and exercise stealth when searching for and replacing the cache.

properties.name: University Challenge 6 (Elation to disgrace)
properties.gc_long_desc:
40 years old in 2002, you too can have a go at the Bamber Gascoigne – Jeremy Paxman show, albeit with a difference. For visitors to Oxford I suggest you park in one of the five park and ride car parks the surround the city, and take the bus in to the centre. From here you can start our little quiz. But be warned, the cache is a black 35mm film cassettes and due to the very urban nature of their locations, are much in the public spotlight. The trick is to winkle them out of their hidey holes without attracting attention. 
This year University Challenge was won by Corpus Christi, where single handily team captain Gail Trimble, hailed by many as the strongest competitor in the history of the show for having scored some two-thirds of the team's total points, powered them past Manchester University.
So here we are in Merton Street, a very pleasant backwater so close to The High. Merton College to the south and University College to the west and in between, Corpus Christi, one of the smallest.
Or not as the case maybe. For fielding an ineligible student who left during the series, Corpus Christi have been stripped of their trophy. Now it appears that other contestants have not been eligible over the years...oh dear.
Your exercise for the week is to go from elation to disgrace in single letter increments.

properties.gc_long_desc:
Clarendon Gardens is described as an attractive traditional park within one of the Southsea conservation areas. Apparently the swathes of daffodils are spectacular in springtime. 

Onstreet parking is possible very close to the cache location.

The cache is a magnetic 35mm film canister. It can be busy here so please be discrete when locating and replacing the cache.

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: BBB 2 - Peter Gunn Theme
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is track two of eleven caches celebrating “The Music from the Soundtrack” album released on June 20, 1980 by the Blues Brothers Band,
Each Bristol based cache is located at a place that has links to either the song title or the lyric content.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Track 2 - Peter Gunn Theme" (Mancini) – 3:46

Peter Gunn Theme, composed and performed by Mancini. A hip, bluesy, brassy number with an insistent piano-and-bass line, the song became an instant hit for Mancini, earning him an Emmy Award and two Grammys

Written by Mancini  performed by Blues Brothers

The Cache is a nano situated in a place where you can view the Sheldon Bush and Patent Shot Company Limited II - Lead Shot Tower of 1969. 

Shot making
Process
In a shot tower, lead is heated until molten, then dropped through a copper sieve high up in the tower. The liquid lead solidifies as it falls and by surface tension forms tiny spherical balls. The partially cooled balls are caught at the floor of the tower in a water-filled basin. The now fully cooled balls are checked for roundness and sorted by size; those that are "out of round" are remelted. A slightly inclined table is used for checking roundness.To make larger shot sizes, a copper sieve with larger holes is used. However, the maximum size is limited by the height of the tower, because larger shot sizes must fall farther to cool. A polishing with a slight amount of graphite is necessary for lubrication and to prevent oxidation.
History
The process was invented by William Watts of Bristol, UK, and patented in the late 18th century.[1] Watts extended his house in Redcliffe, Bristol to build the first shot tower in 1782.
The tower was Designed by E.N. Underwood and Partners (Structural Engineers) for the Sheldon Bush and Patent Shot Company. 
It is an enforced concrete structure of a concave bilateral planned form and has vertically set slit windows in the tower. Its twelve sided top has a central band of vertically set windows with a band of ventilation slits beneath.

The tower is a direct descendent of the first lead shot tower to be built, in 1782, by William Watts who invented the tower process of lead shot manufacture. Watts original tower survived in Bristol until 1968 when it was demolished as part of road widening scheme. The Cheese Lane Tower is its replacement, built for the same company for use in the same process. It is a unique 20th century shot tower and one of only 3 shot towers of any period now surviving in England.

The cache is so small it only has room for a teeny log scroll, as with all urban hides please take care and use stealth whilst searching and please make sure you replace exactly as found

Enjoy the cache 

Bristol Blues Brother

* Congratulations to The Evil Poles for being FTF *

The original station was opened in 1857, its use shared between the Great Western Railway and the London & South Western Railway. The current incarnation was opened in 1986.

Good view if you manage to venture to the top of the hill - great for sledging when we get a bit of snow & grass boarders use it in the summer!  If you are feeling fit, do 'Don't fence me in GC1Q7RK'.

35mm canister with log book (don't know what's happened to the sawn off Ikea pencil that was supposed to be in there so bring a pen or pencil!)

The name 'Brislington' is Saxon, and it is even mentioned in the Domesday book. Arnos Park is buit on land bought from the Lord of the Brislington Manor by a private family in the 17th century.  It is one of only four estates in Bristol that still have the original estate house standing (now known as Arnos Manor Hotel).  The remaining estate land includes the cemetery, the hotel, Black Castle Public House, Arnos Court Triumphal Arch and Arnos Park.

properties.name: Sidetracked - Portsmouth Harbour
properties.gc_short_desc: About SideTracked: We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy. But what about public transport users? SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Portsmouth Harbour station opened in 1876 as the terminus of the Portsmouth Waterside Extension to the Portsmouth Direct Line, which runs between this station and London's Waterloo station. It is situated beside Gunwharf Quays in the city's harbour, and is an important transport terminal, with a bus interchange and ferry services to Gosport and the Isle of Wight. The station currently has four platforms, an earlier fifth platform having been abandoned. These platforms are numbered 1, 3, 4 and 5. It is managed by South West Trains. 

The cache is accessible from outside the station.
You are looking for a black plastic canister smaller than a 35mm film canister attached with magnets. Stealth will be required for this one and please ensure it is well hidden as its a very busy place!

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: Sidetracked - Portsmouth & Southsea
properties.gc_short_desc: About SideTracked: We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy. But what about public transport users? SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Portsmouth and Southsea railway station is the main railway station in central Portsmouth in Hampshire, England. It is close to the Commercial Road shopping centre.

It is located on the Portsmouth Direct Line which runs between London (London Waterloo) and Portsmouth (Portsmouth Harbour). In addition there are regular services to Cardiff Central, Bristol Temple Meads, Southampton Central, Eastleigh, Brighton and London Victoria. The station is split into two distinct parts: the high level (one island platform for through trains) and the low level (two bay platforms) where some trains terminate. Portsmouth and Southsea was once the junction for the Portsmouth Dockyard branch.

The cache is only accessible from outside the station. Come out of the front entrance, turn left and left again till you can see the platforms from the staff car park.
You are looking for a black 35mm film canister attached with magnets. 
Stealth will be required for this one and please ensure it is well hidden as its a very busy place!

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

The cache is located in the Garden of Remembrance, which was built to honor King George V, in 1936 after his death.

properties.name: SideTracked - Salisbury
properties.gc_short_desc: A 'cache and dash' next to Salisbury Station, Wiltshire.
properties.gc_long_desc:
* Please note, this cache is now in a new location *

Salisbury Station is a railway station serving the city of Salisbury in the county of Wiltshire in southern England.
It is the crossing point of the West of England Main Line, 83¾ miles south west of London Waterloo on the way to Exeter and the Wessex Main Line between Cardiff Central, Bristol Temple Meads and Southampton/Portsmouth Harbour.

South West Trains operate services from London Waterloo to Bristol and Exeter as well as services from Devon and Somerset to Portsmouth and Brighton.

First Great Western operate services between Cardiff and the South Coast.

Alongside the station is Salisbury Depot, where South West Trains maintain their fleet of diesel multiple units. The station is operated by South West Trains.

You are looking for a magnetic nano cache.
Stealth is required as CCTV and muggles may be watching.

* Please note, this cache is now in a new location *

properties.name: SideTracked-Winchester
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy cache and dash close to Winchester railway station.
properties.gc_long_desc:
HISTORY

Winchester station was opened on 10th June 1839 by the London & South Western Railway on its mainline from London to Southampton. It opened as a temporary terminus for the line from Southampton until the through line was completed on 30th March 1840. Between 1949 and 1966 the station was named 'Winchester City' to avoid confusion with the Didcot, Newbury & Southampton Railway station named  'Winchester Cheesehill' (later 'Chesil') located to the East of the City.

The current station was renovated in 2004. South West Trains currently operate services from London Waterloo through Winchester to Portsmouth, Southampton, Bournemouth and Weymouth. Winchester is also on the cross country network.

THE CACHE

 You are looking for a nano container. Please use stealth when retrieving and hiding the container and ensure it is replaced in exactly the same location.

Happy Caching

properties.name: Carfax Tower
properties.gc_long_desc: The Carfax Tower is the remains of the church of St Martin which was demolished in 1896 in order to widen the road and improve traffic flow. The tower was renovated following this and visitors today, for a small charge can climb the 99 steps to the top of the tower which offers some wonderful views over Oxford. There are two figures known as “quarter boys” on the front of the tower that strike the quarter hours. On the second floor of the tower is an exhibition on its history.   The cache is a magnetic micro placed in a very busy part of Oxford so stealth will be required when retrieving and replacing this cache. At the time of placing this cache we had great difficulty getting a good fix on the GPSr, probably due to the tall buildings. We suspect that the co-ords may be a little bit out, but with the hint the location should become obvious.

properties.name: Sidetracked   Brighton
properties.gc_short_desc:
A nano placed outside the station entrance. Extreme stelth will be required here as the station is busy at all times.

PLEASE ONLY PUT INITIALS IN THE LOG.it may last a bit longer then. Thanks
properties.gc_long_desc:
After doing a few of the Sidetracked series I could not believe there was not one at Brighton. So here it is,sorry its a nano but there is no where for anything bigger.

Brighton railway station stands on a man made plateau at the top of Trafalgar Street. It opened for use on May 11th 1840 with the opening of the line to Shoreham. The main terminus building was completed for the opening of the line from London on the 21st September 1841.

The building in the Italianate style popular at the time was the work of the architect David Mocatta who was responsible for the original stations on the line; it is the only one surviving. Its façade is now much hidden by the later, 1880's, porte-cochere and originally there was a colonnade on the south, west and east sides.

Spanning the tracks and rising 22m (75ft) above the platforms is the recently restored magnificent cast iron and glass train shed which was erected in 1882/3. Following the curvature of the tracks the roof is supported on cast iron columns some of which bear the name of the Midlands engineering firm, the Patent Shaft and Axletree Company of Wednesbury who had won the contract to supply. All the ironwork was delivered by rail and erected above the existing shed with not a single day of train service operation being lost.

The new train shed was lit by arc lamps supplied by the Hammond Electric Light Company (the generating plant was in the works of the Regent Iron Foundry in North Road, the site of which is now occupied by the postal sorting office).

24/10/09 Co-Ordnates changed . Magnetic Nano

properties.name: Church Micro #772 – Upton Cheyney
properties.gc_short_desc:
A quick and easy cache adjacent to the United Reform Church, Upton
Cheyney
properties.gc_long_desc: United Reform Church, Upton Cheyney Upton Cheyney is a picturesque village situated on the steep slopes of Lansdown Hill within the Cotswold Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. It consists of a cluster of traditional natural stone buildings and walls which, together with mature trees and hedgerows, create an attractive enclosed environment. The village setting is one of open countryside characterised by varied and sloping topography, open fields and mature trees. It is thought that the name Upton Cheyney is derived simply from the words 'upper farmhouse'. Archaeological records indicate the site of a Roman settlement to the south-east of the village and at nearby Pipley Bottom the stepped terraces, cut by Romano-Britons for vine cultivation can still be seen. It is likely that the present settlement grew up around springs and above the marshy river valleys. Manor Farm at the junction of Wick Lane was mentioned in the Domesday Book and most of the buildings in the village were constructed between 1690 and 1830. The United Reform church was built in 1834; the recently-extended Upton Inn dates around 1710, and the former school 1849. If any body would like to expand to this series please do, I would just ask that you could let Sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication.. You are looking for a a 35mm film container. Tree cover may make precise location of the cache difficult, hence the hint is very descriptive

properties.name: CBC Series - CGC
properties.gc_short_desc: A quick Cache and Dash on Anchor Rd
properties.gc_long_desc:
CBC series – College Green Centre
Welcome to my first series of caches. This series is based
around the City of Bristol College sites past, present and future.
I will be increasing the number of them over a period of time. I
have tried to place the cache’s near to the college sites but
not actually on the property. My reasoning for doing this series is
that I work at the college and visit many of the sites regularly
meaning I can easily check on the caches.
The City of Bristol College was formed in 1997 by the merger of
South Bristol College (based in Bedminster and Hartcliffe) and
Brunel College of Arts and Technology (Ashley Down). Since the
merger, City of Bristol College has expanded rapidly merging with
the College of Care and Early Education (Lawrence Weston),
Soundwell College and Brunel and Gordano Training to become one of
the biggest college’s in the UK covering the counties of
Bristol, South Gloucestershire and Gloucestershire (Staverton
Airport).
Opened in 2000 the College Green Centre was the first major
development by the City of Bristol College. This centre is now
primarily occupied by the College’s Sixth Form Academy which
runs the majority of A-levels within the College.

properties.gc_short_desc: No.2 of a 13 cache series.  This section on a decline.

properties.name: Septic
properties.gc_short_desc:
The cache is not at the given co-ordinates although someone there
ought to be able to solve it.
properties.gc_long_desc: Mrs Defective Detective (an occassional visitor to these parts from Cornwall) was a bit miffed that she didn't have a clue where to start with our first puzzle cache and thought that something mathematical might be more up her street so here's one unashamedly copied from drsolly's The fundamental theorem of algebra. As the Good Doctor says in his cache, we all learned how to solve quadratic equations at school. However, the solution for a cubic equation is a beast and quartic and quintic are really rather hard - whether this drove Galois to his early grave is doubtful but you get the point. Anyway, drsolly set a sexic equation, but frankly quite an easy one which seemed out of character with some the other challenges he has set. But don't worry about any of that - this puzzle isn't about quadratic, cubic, quartic, quintic or even sexic equations. The observant amongst you will have deduced from the name of the puzzle that this involves solving a "septic" equation. More precisely, this septic equation: x7 - 35x6 + 507x5 - 3921x4 + 17388x3 - 43956x2 + 58352x - 31360 = 0 There are seven solutions to the equation - arrange them in ascending order to give you ABCDEFG. The cache is hidden at N51 2E.B0G W2 3D.CEA If you know how, you should be able to solve by hand in about five minutes...

properties.name: Shirehampton Stroll
properties.gc_short_desc: A gentle stroll around Shirehampton village, staying close to shops, pubs and cafes and incorporating a vist to St Mary's Church
properties.gc_long_desc:
The cache is a green plastic Petling tube.  it is placed a good height above the road, whicjh might make it inaccessible to wheelchair users, who should instead, e-mail "Severnside" with the date of the house opposite the cache.

Shirehampton, near Avonmouth, at the north-western edge of the city, is a district of Bristol which originated as a separate village. It retains something of its village feel, having a short identifiable High Street with the parish church situated among shops, and is still thought of as a village by many of its 6,867 inhabitants

 It is informally known to local people as "Shire", which is also the title of the monthly community newspaper and website

properties.gc_long_desc: ** **This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching** If you look South West from the location given in the coordinates you will see the Headquarters of a famous transport system.        The location of the actual cache is given by the following code. North EF, T&W WP,KT.TP,HB, HB. West HB, HB, HB HB, A . A, EF,A. The letters refer to stages on a route into London starting at 0. properties.gc_long_desc:
This understated Square is just along from the world famous Children's Hospital. It can be quite busy if the weather is fine.
**Please use stealth and replace so it cannot be seen**
