properties.name: St. George's Gardens
properties.gc_short_desc: Beautiful old gardens in the heart of London, Camden.
properties.gc_long_desc:
ATTENTION: THIS CACHE IS NOT 24H ACCESSIBLE. The park opens in the early morning and closes at dusk.

"Before the site was acquired in 1713 to serve as the burial grounds for the new churches of St George, Bloomsbury Way, and St George the Martyr, Queen Square, the land here was meadows.

These were the first burial grounds in London not to be sited next to their churches. The first recorded case of ‘body-snatching' (the theft of corpses for medical research and teaching) took place here in 1777.

Today the gardens are a peaceful retreat. The many large plane trees create shade, while imposing ivy-clad tombs and gravestones may be found throughout the gardens.

The site (restored in 2001 by the London Borough of Camden, with a grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund) now includes a new sensory garden created by the Friends of St George's Gardens near the Chapel of Rest. It was awarded a Green Flag in 2009."
[Open Squares] http://www.opensquares.org/detail/SaintGeorgeGdns.html

properties.name: Weymouth Town bridge
properties.gc_short_desc: The final cache is a magnetic micro
properties.gc_long_desc:
The current Town Bridge was built in 1930 on the line of an earlier 1824 bridge, the first bridge was built in 1594 between Melcombe and Weymouth. Before this, crossing was by rope-hauled ferryboat, when not disrupted by frequent feuding between the two communities

 

This is a two stage cache

At this location you need to find the following information

properties.name: H.M.S. Warrior
properties.gc_short_desc: A simple traditional offering an opportunity to get fairly up close and personal with HMS Warrior.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Warrior, launched in 1860, was the pride of Queen Victoria’s fleet.  Powered by steam and sail, she was the largest, fastest and most powerful ship of her day and had a profound effect on naval architecture. Warrior was, in her time, the ultimate deterrent. Yet within a few years she was obsolete......

Close to Portsmouth Historic Dockyard which is well worth a visit. 

Accessible 24/7 from the public footpath. You are looking for a nano containing logbook only. Bring your own pen/pencil and please write small.

properties.name: Weymouth Town Circuit 15
properties.gc_short_desc: You are looking for a 35mm film container
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is a series of 19 traditional caches placed around Weymouth. The route takes you through a  residential area, past the Weymouth Rugby Club, around the Lodmoor Country Park, along the 
Esplanade, around the harbour, across to the RSPB Reserve and back along Radipole Lake. Distance is approximately 6 miles.   Much of the route is on designated cycle and foot paths, along which the caches are located. Please note the No Cycling signs on the Esplanade, they are strictly enforced.

There is nothing to collect, no bonus. The caches are intended to be simple to find and finding sequence is entirely up to where you decide to park.

There are various free parking points. Between caches 1 and 2 along the residential Monmouth Avenue. Near cache no 4  on Southdown Avenue/Oakbury Drive. Or along Radipole Park Drive near the tennis courts. In the town, you may very well have to pay Weymouth Council for a parking space. They were set on our cycles – a much preferred way to travel around Weymouth.

There are several other caches already in existence placed quite close to the route which you may like to look up and find.

properties.name: Pica-pica #1 - Salisbury
properties.gc_long_desc: Salisbury - TOURISTIC TOUR Number 1 By SEPING and bat62 Supported by TheTwoMotts Easy cache for everybody Pay attention with muggles. See the hint.

properties.name: Hope you find it...
properties.gc_short_desc: A cache and dash in a historic part of Weymouth.Please bring a pen/pencil to sign the log.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Beware of the Muggles this is a very popular area especially during the holidays. There is plenty of outdoor seating for the nearby restuarants and pubs. The Brewers quay complex is home to the former Devenish Brewery. Inside the historic building you will find The Timewalk, Weymouth Museum and a selection of independent gift shops. The Dorset Brewing Company still brews beer on site to this day.

Up until near the end of the eighteenth century the old harbour of Weymouth, formerly known as Ope Cove (from which Hope Square gets its name), had a larger inlet here. The inlet ran (until major reclamation in 1781) up to where the Red Lion public house stands today.

For those who have completed our Crabchurch Conspiracy cache, or who are interested in Civil wall history the inlet (known by some as the Black Hole) was the location where over 200 Irish mercenaries perished. They retreated from high ground on the night of February 27 1645, pursued by the parliamentarians and in confusion, blind panic and disarray plunged into the freezing depths.....it is said some of the bodies remain to this day under the nearby streets.

In the stone wall above the cache is a dent probably from a cannonball fired from the Chapelhay fort during this period Our 'arbour View cache (GC2FRM9) is nearby.
 
There is a little token for FTF ;o)

Happy Caching...

properties.name: SideTracked - Swindon
properties.gc_short_desc: A standard film canister micro hidden outside the station. This cache fulfilled our pledge for the I Pledge geocoin to place a wheelchair accessible cache. However, due to the removal of the original location the cache has been re-sited and is no longer accessible from a wheelchair.
properties.gc_long_desc: About SideTracked We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy (cos there aren’t many Motorways in Wales!). But what about public transport users? SideTracked Caches are intended to provide quick Cache-and-dashes at Train Stations. It is hoped this idea will spread across the country in the same way as the MMs….but if hiding one PLEASE BE SENSIBLE and remember that in this day and age, public transport is under greater scrutiny than ever before, so, although these caches should be quick and easy grabs, PLEASE don’t place a Cache where it could cause alarm!!!About Swindon Train Station Swindon railway station opened in 1842 with construction of the Great Western Railway's engineering works continuing. Until 1895, every passing train stopped here for at least 10 minutes to change locomotives. As such Swindon station hosted the first recorded Railway refreshment rooms. The station was 3 storeys, with the refreshment rooms on the ground floor and the upper floors comprising the station hotel and lounge. The building was demolished in 1972, with today's modern station and office block erected on the site. The station is served by inter-city services from London Paddington to Bristol and South Wales. Swindon is a major junction, where the old Great Western Railway line to Gloucester and Cheltenham, the Great Western Main Line to Bristol Temple Meads, and the Great Western Railway route to Bristol Parkway and South Wales diverge. The station is managed by First Great Western. It consists of an island platform containing a buffet, small shop and waiting room. Platform 4 on the down side (westbound track) contains a coffee shop and waiting room. Located on Station Road, the station is just a 5 minute walk from the central bus station and the town centre. Both long and short term parking are available on site. Please note the hint is cryptic and not an exact description!

properties.name: Ping!
properties.gc_long_desc: The coordinates above are a handy railway station, but the cache isn't there. When you've worked out a location, add 0.5 to the Northing and 0.1 to the Westing. You can check your answers for this puzzle on Geochecker.com. FTF goes to Trollhunter_94, Fraggle69, Chickenpooooo and Alibags

properties.name: Imperial Hotel
properties.gc_short_desc: The cache is a nano located on a busy road so lots of stealth is required. Although there are plenty of roads nearby/and right next to GZ for parking, finding a space can be quite difficult at times.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Canynge Hall (pronounced: can-ing) was opened as the Imperial Hotel in 1879 to serve Clifton Down station, which opened in 1874. The hotel was erected at a cost of £18000, including furniture. 

On 1st February 1915 the premises were sold to the University of Bristol for £7,500.

At the beginning of the First World War the building was used for billeting the Black Watch.  In the early autumn of 1917, it was opened as a depot hostel for all the women recruited in the South Western Counties and South Wales.

After the Great War, Canynge Hall was used by Bristol University as a men's hall of residence until Wills Hall was opened in 1929. It is now home to the University of Bristol’s Department of Social Medicine.

properties.name: Xmas Curios #1
properties.gc_long_desc: So, you've walked a few miles round Bristol so far? Just a warm up I'm sorry to say. Good luck with this Xmas collection. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. So, to the cache, and an easy start. "On the first day of Christmas my true love sent to me...a black metal dragon". Below the dragon's breath is a date, add all the numerals together to give B. Cache is at: N51.2?.(B-5)(B-10)0 W002.3?(B-6)(B-11)(B-6)      When attempting this cache you assume all risks involved particularly a loss of sanity and liberal use of the 'ignore' function for future PQs.Terms and Conditions

properties.name: Hot Springs, Bath
properties.gc_short_desc: For two thousand years Bath has been a spa town, built around Britain’s only hot mineral springs. For centuries this natural phenomenon has attracted visitors to Bath, and led to a unique historic urban environment around the springs.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Springs gave Bath 2,000 years of history, beautiful Georgian architecture and Bath becoming the UK’s first World Heritage City.  The thermal waters rise from a depth of about 3000m at a rate l.l million litres/day and a constant temperature of 46.5C. The waters originated as rainwater which fell on the Mendip Hills between 20— 80,000 years ago. They reach the surface in three places in the city centre, and baths have been built over each one.  The water is heated by geothermal action and these springs in Bath emerge at the highest temperature in the UK.

The Saxons and Normans made use of the thermal waters for curative purposes.  By the late 16th century there were baths attracting the poor and leprous to the city’s hospitals and almshouses in search of healing and relief from discomfort. Visits to the city’s baths by members of the royal family and the court during the 17th century helped establish Bath as a fashionable watering place.

The "Pump Rooms" were the Victorians' addition to the Roman Baths. Bath was built by the Romans around its hot spring waters around 2,000 years ago. The Victorians re-discovered the Roman Baths and they have since been restored to a magnificent condition. 

In order to find this cache you will need a picture at this location and to answer a question.  You must physically visit this location to log this cache. Please follow the following instructions at the location:
1. Take a photograph of the entrance to the Roman Baths or Pump Rooms (opposite side of the building to the coordinates) including your GPS in the photo (do not use a photo which includes the answer to the following question).
2.  Find out the answer to these questions: go to the above coordinates and find the stone wall plaque in the side street a) What does the plaque say about the first use of these Hot Springs? b) Adjacent to the plaque there is a shorter wall topped by a stone balustrade. This wall runs alongside the main bath, estimate its length to tell me the length of the Roman bath inside. (You may find your GPS is a useful tool for this measurement).


When you wish to log a find for this cache then please follow the following instructions: 
1.  Send us your answer to the above questions.  To do this, click the link for our name above “The Wombles” and then the link marked “Send message”.  Type your answer, tick the box marked “I want to send my email address along with this message.” and then send email.
2.  Now log your find. Don’t wait for an answer to your email.  We will only contact you if your answer is wrong. 
3.  Upload your picture. Once you have typed your log and clicked the link marked “log my find” then you will get a new page including your log and a link “upload image”.  Follow the instructions and upload your photo.  
4.  We periodically review photos and regrettably will delete all logs which do not include the required photo. Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. (these logs will be deleted). These requirements are necessary because of the high numbers of armchair finders who do not physically visit the location.  This requirement is effective as of September 2009.


You can walk round the baths in the Roman Baths Museum, the entrance is on the opposite side of this building. This is an excellent museum which we have visited recently and is suitable for all ages.  More details are on this website  www.romanbaths.co.uk/.

For more information on the City of Bath and the Roman Baths visit http://www.cityofbath.co.uk/romanbaths/romanbaths.html

Today you can once again bathe in the hot spring water at the new Thermae Bath Spa.  These impressive baths are an experience but rather expensive, details here. www.thermaebathspa.com/

You can also drink the spring water in the Pump Rooms Tea room.  Don’t.  It’s foul.

properties.name: Xmas Curios #3
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. Now to the cache:"On the third day of Christmas my true love sent to me, three stone inscriptions" Find the curio and add up the number of letters on the curved metal sign to the right to give 'F' This one is easy, it even tells you where it is on the curio! Cache is at N51.2?((F*55)+C)) W002.3?((F*43)+(A+B))

properties.name: SideTracked - Freshford
properties.gc_long_desc:
About SideTracked

We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy.  But what about public transport users?  SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.

About Freshford Station

This is a quaint, un-manned, request stop station serving nearby villages.  It's also been in the news for several things as reported by Miles Kington, journalist and resident of the nearby village of Limpley Stoke.  

If you visit during the summer months you will see the wonderful flowerbeds that the locals tend to.

This stretch of railway between Bradford on Avon and Bath Spa passes through the glorious Avon valley and hence offers the commuter another perspective to enjoy at a leisurely pace.  There is also the Kennet & Avon canal for those wishing to stop for a walk or bike ride. 

The Cache

You are looking for a magnetic key safe container. Although this cache is wheelchair accessible, some help will be required with the retrieval.

properties.name: Xmas Curios #8
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. This curio was thought to have been lost but was recently rediscovered. Make sure you find the correctly numbered one. Now to the cache:"On the eighth day of Christmas my true love sent to me, eight parish markers" Find the curio. Opposite is a round sign. How many digits are on it ?= 'Q' Cache is at N51.2?((Q*20)+(L+H) W002.3?((Q*25)+(Q+P))

properties.name: Xmas Curios #10
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. Now to the cache:"On the tenth day of Christmas my true love sent to me, ten important plaques" Find the curio. How many metal points are there directly to the left of the curio? = "U" Cache is at N51.2?((N*6)+B) W002.3?((U*84)+(N+P))

properties.name: Church Micro #941 - Christ Church Frome
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a simple magnetic cache located close to Christ Church Frome.  The cache container is not a micro and can takes geocoins and a number of small swaps.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Christ Church dates from 1814, when it was decided that Frome needed an extra church to serve the 8500 souls who lived in the town.  Up until then, Frome had only two churchs, on in the town and one out at Woodlands.  Therefore a subscription was raised to enable the building and endowment of the church.  

With the money raised, half an acre of ground was acquired and conveyed by deed into the possession of the  Registrar of the Bishop’s Court at Wells.  

This church, which was to be called Christ Church was built in the years 1817 and 1818, and was consecrated September 15, 1818. The expense of building it, including quarrying stones, carriage, and all incidentals, was about £3,900 and The Rev. Joseph Algar, M. A. at that time Curate of Frome, was nominated Minister of the said Church by the Rev. Charles Phillott, M. A. Vicar of Frome.

The cache is a magnetised box capable of taking geocoins and swaps, it is not a 35mm film canister.

If any body would like to expand to this series please do, I would just ask that you could let Sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication.

The cache when orginally deployed contained the following:

log book and pencil
path-tag holder
and as a First to Find prize: an unregistered geocoin.

***Congratulations to somersetsmithys on their FTF!!  Hopefully the first of many.  Happy caching!***

properties.name: New Year Blues at Blaise
properties.gc_short_desc:
Shake off the New Year Blues Shed a few pounds Walk the dogs/kids
Meet other nutcases with this crazy hobby WATCH OUT FOR THE RATTLER
- IT'S A TRACKABLE ITEM !!
properties.gc_long_desc: THIS IS AN EXTENDED FLASH EVENT   Shake off the New Year Blues Shed a few pounds/grams Walk the dogs/kids Meet other nutcases with this crazy hobby   Date Sunday 3rd January Time 1300 hrs - 1315 hrs to meet, followed by treasure hunting till 1700 hrs   Get out and get some exercise. Walk off that Christmas flab. Meet at the cafe at Blaise Castle in North Bristol for a slice of Christmas cake and a skinny latte. Submit your entry for "Name the Beast" at the location given. Bring your most pointless Christmas present and Be prepared to donate it to a worthy charity !! Follow it by a mad treasure hunt before the light fades, collecting eight new clues special to the day, There is also a treasure hunt for the little ones, very kindly provided by our mates OspreyNo1   Re-assemble at 1600 for a hot chocolate before departure Prize for most clues located on the day and the wooden spoon for the fewest.

properties.name: Wait, Watch & Wonder...
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a micro Nano cache containing a
log only, no room for anything else I'm afraid, so please bring
your own writing implement!
properties.gc_long_desc: Located on Southsea seafront, this cache can be done as a quick cache & dash (metered parking is available very close by), or as part of an enjoyable day in Southsea where there are lots of things to see and do. Some local attractions include Southsea Castle, The D-Day Museum, Blue Reef Aquarium and Clarence Pier Funfair, all well within walking distance, not to mention a boating lake, various ice cream / food kiosks, a nice promenade & pier for walking along and excellent views of the Solent and Isle of Wight! The cache should be quite easy to locate, but retrieving it without detection may be slightly more difficult as this area can be quite busy with muggle traffic, especially on a nice day! I would recommend some stealthy rummaging in bags/ tying of shoelaces/playing with your children etc! Please take care when replacing the cache to ensure that the log is sealed properly inside it's plastic bag and that the lid is firmly re-attached to the cache container. *EDIT* - NOTE ON CACHE REPLACEMENT - Please ensure that the container is placed at 180 degrees on the underside, on the seaward side of the object, and not at 90 degrees on the side of the object as this makes it too visible to passers by. ***Update: 30/8/2010*** After it's recent mugglement, the cache has been replaced on 30/8/2010 with a nano and has moved a couple of feet from it's previous location on the object at the location. (The micro may return when I have another suitable container but I didn't want the cache out of action for too long!). Please take care that it is well hidden and not about to fall out of it's location when you leave! - Thanks. Being a micro nano cache, I wasn't able to leave a cache camera for people to take photos with, but as I myself have an unhealthy obsession with taking photographs of everything wherever I go, it would great if visitors to the cache could take a photo of themselves and upload it with their log. I do like to see what other cachers look like and put faces to the names I frequently see on the logs! ;o) Happy Hunting! :o)

properties.name: TDMRSS 2 - Queen Street
properties.gc_short_desc: That damn monkey road sign series.
properties.gc_long_desc: We made the mistake of asking our travel bug "Matt the Monkey" to hide a series of Micro caches on the back of street/road signs. We gave him co-ordinates of roads in and around Bristol, but he ignored the co-ords and placed them on different road signs with the same name! Each is a 35mm file cannister containing a log and pencil and is either magnetically attached or hidden by another method on a corresponding road sign. Congratulations (again) to Alpharhino for being the FTF

properties.name: The round tower
properties.gc_long_desc: An easy cache at a popular tourist spot. So stealth may well be required. PLEASE don't let muggles see the hide. There is plenty of parking near by some free if your prepared to walk 20 or so paces extra. If you want other stuff to do in the area look at the sign posts for ideas, there everywere. Access is good unless you dont like BIG steps. View Ratings for GCYTMG

properties.name: Museum Micro #2 (Portsmouth)
properties.gc_short_desc: Part of the Itchen Puzzle series.
properties.gc_long_desc: An offset micro in Portsmouth starting from Portsmouth City Museum . The museum is open daily between 10am and 5pm and has free parking for visitors. Otherwise there is plenty of on-street metered parking available. No off road antics are required – paths suitable for wheelchairs and buggies at all times. If with small children, there are a couple of roads to cross. This cache can be combined with other caches in the area such as Southsea Secrets#1 and #2, and the Round Tower. Also, the museum is very informative and has an excellent tea room. Clues for the micro: Go to the coordinates above where there is a date high up above the entrance to the museum. Ans: FGHIThen the micro is located at: N50 47.(F+2)(G-G)(I-I) W001 05.G(H-I)(G-3) The micro is a small pot covered in black-masking tape containing a logbook only - bring your own pencil or pen. Please be careful of muggles and replace exactly as you found it (i.e. to the left and up a bit). Clues for Itchen Puzzle: Using the same date as for the micro XYZA, Y is the coordinate you need. To get the remaining coordinates of the Itchen Puzzle cache, you will need to visit the following other three caches in South Hampshire: Museum Micro #1 (Fareham) - GC10D05 Wheely Tricky #1 - GC10D12 Wheely Tricky #2 - GC10D19Each of these can be logged in their own right and each will help you to find a part of the cache coordinates for Itchen Puzzle.

properties.name: TDMRSS 3 - Church Lane
properties.gc_short_desc: That damn monkey road sign series.
properties.gc_long_desc: We made the mistake of asking our travel bug "Matt the Monkey" to hide a series of Micro caches on the back of street/road signs. We gave him co-ordinates of roads in and around Bristol, but he ignored the co-ords and placed them on different road signs with the same name! Each is a 35mm file cannister containing a log and pencil and is either magnetically attached or hidden by another method on a corresponding road sign. Congratulations to Alpharhino for his second FTF in this series

properties.name: Southsea Secrets #1 (Hants)
properties.gc_short_desc: Urban micro cache in Southsea, Hants.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Magnetic 35mm film canister covered in black tape containing log book only. Stealth required to retrieve and put back. You do not need to leave the pavement to retrieve the cache.

Parking is available along the road - short stay is free else it's meter based. Can be busy particularly in the summer months. 

The Common is quite near as is the promenade, Clarence Pier, and the Isle of Wight hovercraft. There are a number of interesting monuments on the other side of the road which are worth a look.

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: SideTracked - Basingstoke
properties.gc_short_desc: While we were at Robin Hood Bay for the New Year we did some caches in the area.  What we realized was that even some of the smallest Stations have a “SideTracked” cache.  We then realized that Basingstoke did not have a “SideTracked” caches so here it is.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Side Tracked caches have become a nationwide series of caches for public transport users. They are intended to provide quick cache-and-dashes at or nearby railway stations. Caches can be found close to stations of the national rail network and well as heritage railways.

I have included some links for those people interested in the history.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basingstoke_railway_station
http://web.ukonline.co.uk/cj.tolley/cjt-brhc.htm

properties.name: St Thomas' Cache
properties.gc_short_desc:
A 35mm located opposite St Thomas' Hospital.
Now the cache is for all to enjoy.
properties.gc_long_desc:
I was going to place a nano, but though I'd give something a little larger a go at this spot.This 24/7 cache is actually place upon the limits of Archbishop's Park, former gardens to Lambeth Palace.Grab from inside or out, but out allows 24 hour access.Very wheelchair friendly too.

***There are public loos inside the park****

***Transport details*****
Tube: Waterloo (Northern, Waterloo and City, Bakerloo and Jubilee lines), 0.2 miles (0.4km)
Rail: Waterloo (South West Trains) 0.2 miles (0.4km) – regular trains to and from Vauxhall, Clapham Junction and South West
Bus: 3, 12, 53, 77, 159 (to/from Brixton, Kennington, Elephant and Castle, Vauxhall, Waterloo and Westminster)

properties.name: View from the Bishop’s Garden
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a simple micro cache in the heart of Salisbury at an area so well captured by Constable in his painting “From the Bishops Garden”. There are beautiful views to be had of the Cathedral from the Queen Elizabeth Gardens and the Town Path or walk a little bit further along to enjoy the Old Mill.
properties.gc_long_desc: There is plenty of car parks and on road parking close by but being Salisbury it’s unlikely you will get away without paying for parking. Take care and avoid leaving your car in resident only parking areas, which some of the roads close by just happen to be, I found out the hard way! If you need parking co-ordinates the following are available: Car Park (small charge involved) at Salisbury end of walk N51º 04.084 W001º 47.996 (recommended as this is the more interesting walk) Limited free parking at Harnham N51º 03.808 W001º 48.526 In searching this cache out you will have great views of Salisbury Cathedral and surrounding meadows. The walk itself is less than 0.7 miles round trip from the nearest Salisbury car park. If you happen to do the walk late evening, keep your eyes open for the local foxes. For more information about Salisbury Cathedral, visit this webpage. Being a micro cache there is no room for the usual items for exchange, only log sheets and a pencil. It may be as well to bring your own writing implement, as who knows how long the pencil will remain or last! Warning: if you have children with you please take care and keep an eye on them as there is some deep water close to this cache.

properties.name: sidetracked marylebone
properties.gc_short_desc: A small metal pot a bit smaller than a 35mm film can.
properties.gc_long_desc:
A quick cache and dash near Marylebone station. You can almost reach the cache without getting out of your car! The cache only contains a log. The cache is not in the station.

Beware of the homeless muggles! (and the smell)

properties.name: Eyes Open
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching.
properties.gc_long_desc: This is a magnetic keysafe and is by a great viewing spot of London. Once you’ve found it: *** make sure it goes back where you found it. This is so it will be there for those who come after you and not found by those who shouldn't*** ***it would also be nice if you took a picture of your gps/you infront of the London Eye as it is such a nice area.*** Please do take the clue with you so that you do not look suspicious as it is in a very muggle prone area. Please do not try to find this cache when at busy muggle times especially if there are muggles sitting nearby. EXTREME STEALTH REQUIRED Thank you.

properties.name: Royal Crescent (Bath, NE Somerset)
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache is in a beautiful location very close to the Royal
Crescent, Bath. It is suitable for children of all ages. It has a
tiny log, please write your name only.
properties.gc_long_desc: The City of Bath is a wonderful location, loaded with history, beautiful architecture and quaint little shops. If you have time to visit the city before or after visiting the cache, it is very well worthwhile. Bath was built by the Romans around its hot spring waters around 2,000 years ago. The Victorians re-discovered the Roman Baths and they have since been restored to a magnificent condition. The Saxons built a huge Abbey in the 800s which was the site for the Coronation of the first King of all England, Edgar, in 973. The Abbey was re-built in the 1400s and still shows the scars of the English civil war in the 1640s. Bath became popular again in the 1700s due to its "restorative waters", resulting in a massive building programme. All buildings were constructed in a similar style, in a similar stone, resulting in its beautiful architecture. The Royal Crescent, Pump Rooms, Theatre Royal and Assembley Rooms are particularly recommended. For details of the Royal Crescent and more information on the City of Bath visit this web site. The cache is located at the foot of the Royal Crescent, easily accesible without a car although you could park very close. Don't go in the bushes. The clue is helpful without giving it away. Please take your own pen/pencil as there isn't one in the cache. An Ordnance Survey map for the location is available at this web site. When you replace the cache, please ensure it is not visible to the casual observer (especially from behind the location). There is an excellent, huge, childrens' playground just round the corner at N51°23.138' W02°22.565' - and its free! Our kids have tried it and loved it. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: Station X
properties.gc_short_desc:
The Station X cache is set inside Bletchley Park, the home of
British code breaking operations in World War II.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The cache is in Bletchley Park proper, so you will need to pay for entry to find this one. Please do not ask for free entry, the park is operated as a charity, and needs your donations. Bletchley Park is just south of Milton Keynes. It's quite hard to find, so it's worth printing a map from the web site - Bletchley Park. An admission charge of £10 for adults, £6 for children (age 12 to 16) and £8 for concessions (over 60 or with Studen ID card) is charged. Bletchley Park is a fascinating place, well worth a trip. You can see the first ever electronic computer in the world (Colossus) - don't believe those Yanks and their ENIAC! You can also see a real Enigma machine, visit a computer museum and more. This was originally a multi-cache, consisting of three clues, and a final cache location. However, there is now only one clue, but it has been relocated OUTSIDE the park, so there is no need to pay to get the clue. The GPS location given in this posting as the location of the cache is the one that used to be the location of the first clue, but now it serves only to locate the cache in roughly the right area on the map. It may also save you from the horrors of getting lost in Milton Keynes (Hint: The park entrance is very near to Bletchley Railway Station.) It is completely possible to find the final cache without the use of the clue. To find the cache, "all" you need to do is to de-crypt this cyphertext. 
TSEPT WYMVY NZWUB XUMAU UESVW YFCEU FQIPX QZVQU
WDTBI YEBRX TSEFB NVBUX OFGUM BVUNO NRAGX UELCG
RVAAW JRGSU RPNGK SRAAU RXAYL NFXFZ ACTNM NYMZG
IYGNM YRVQC AWKGH NYMJK SEAYH HXBUK RZAQB HKPRM
EYEET FUQEK CEIBG IWBUK MLNFB IEAGU PAAFL NYMPG
RAAED IEGBA RWESM MKWCV ADSGA YRLZO SDIBG MVVGX
AYCRH HPWHX RTGUM MKWCV ADSNU CTGPR EDHRW IEGBA
RCITA NKPRR AVEVL NFGBA RWESM UKBUO SAOVG NJBBV

properties.name: The First King of England (Bath)
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is an easy cache in the centre of Bath to bring you to the
magnificent Abbey building.
properties.gc_long_desc: The City of Bath is a wonderful location, loaded with history, beautiful architecture and quaint little shops. Bath was built by the Romans around its hot spring waters around 2,000 years ago. The Victorians re-discovered the Roman Baths and they have since been restored to a magnificent condition. The Saxons built a huge Abbey in the 800s which was the site for the Coronation of the first King of all England, Edgar, in 973. The Abbey was re-built in the 1400s and still shows the scars of the English civil war in the 1640s. Bath became popular again in the 1700s due to its "restorative waters", resulting in a massive building programme. All buildings were constructed in a similar style, in a similar stone, resulting in its beautiful architecture. The Royal Crescent, Pump Rooms, Theatre Royal and Assembley Rooms are particularly recommended. For details of the Bath Abbey and more information on the City of Bath visit this web site. When you visit this cache you will be adjacent to the starting point for the excellent (and free) Mayor's tours of Bath. These start outside the Pump Rooms at 10.30am and 2.00pm every day (except Christmas Day) and take about an hour walking through the streets. We've done it twice, they're excellent and much better than the tour buses. The start point is a sign at N51°22.871', W02°21.583'. Catch the street entertainers here too; they're often really good. In order to find this cache you will need a picture at this location and to answer a question. You must physically visit this location to log this cache. Please follow the following instructions at the location: 1. Take a photograph of Bath Abbey including your GPS in the photo (do not use a photo which includes the answer to the following question). 2. Find out the answer to this question: find the historical plaque which commemorates the coronation of King Edgar, the first King of all England who was crowned here in 973AD. Record all the text of the plaque. When you wish to log a find for this cache then please follow the following instructions: 1. Send us your answer to the above question. To do this, click the link for our name above “The Wombles” and then the link marked “Send message”. Type your answer, tick the box marked “I want to send my email address along with this message.” and then send email. 2. Now log your find. Don’t wait for an answer to your email. We will only contact you if your answer is wrong. 3. Upload your picture. Once you have typed your log and clicked the link marked “log my find” then you will get a new page including your log and a link “upload image”. Follow the instructions and upload your photo. 4. We periodically review photos and regrettably will delete all logs which do not include the required photo. Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. (these logs will be deleted). These requirements are necessary because of the high numbers of armchair finders who do not physically visit the location. This requirement is effective as of September 2009.

properties.name: Salisbury Cathedral Revisited (Wilts)
properties.gc_short_desc: This virtual cache is in the Close of Salisbury Cathedral. It replaces a micro cache in the Close which was taken twice in two months, and has now been archived. Finders of that micro can of course log this cache too. This cache is accessible by wheelchair users. View Handicap Ratings for GCH4HA
properties.gc_long_desc: To claim this cache, log your find, and at the same time email me through my profile or by clicking here with the exact text of the plaque at the location. The foundation stone of The Cathedral Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Salisbury was laid in 1220, and the cathedral was dedicated in 1258. Originally the cathedral had no tower or spire, but there was a free-standing belltower nearby, near the co-ords of this cache. The tower and the world-famous spire, which is the tallest medieval spire in Europe at 404 feet (128 metres), were added around 1300 to 1320. The original city and cathedral of Salisbury were at Old Sarum, just north of the present city. There was friction between the military in the city and the clergy, however, and this led eventually to the building of the new cathedral on the present site. There is a story, probably apocryphal, that the site for the new cathedral was chosen by having an archer fire an arrow from Old Sarum, and the cathedral was built where the arrow landed. The distance by GPSr is 1.95 miles (3.14 kilometres)! You can find more information about the Cathedral here and about the city here. There is limited parking in the Close, which seems sometimes to be free and sometimes extortionately expensive. Please note that most on-street parking in the city is now either residents only or pay parking. The pay meters are not always very conspicuous, and the wardens are zealous. The best option may be a paying car park, of which there are quite a few within easy walking distance. The approach to this cache from all the nearest car parks is paved and level, and suitable for pushchairs, buggies and wheelchairs. Note though that the final few yards is grass, which may sometimes be soft. There is plenty of open space in the close for children and dogs, but dogs must be kept on the lead. Refreshments are available in the cathedral. ----- -----

properties.name: University Challenge 7 (Sizzle Sizzle)
properties.gc_short_desc:
Sizzle Sizzle. Name the three that were burnt to their deaths here?
A log will not be accepted unless the answer to the above question
is emailed to me through my profile. Please do not include the
answer in your log.
properties.gc_long_desc:
40 years old in 2002, you too can have a go at the Bamber Gascoigne
– Jeremy Paxman show, albeit with a difference.
For visitors to Oxford I suggest you park in one of the five park
and ride car parks the surround the city, and take the bus in to
the centre. From here you can start our little quiz. Happy
hunting!
Standing on the X in the middle of the road, Broad Street opens out
towards the east. Balliol College immediately on your left,
followed by Trinity with its excellent surrounding gardens. (well
worth a stroll around if open). Then followed by Blackwells,
supposedly the worlds largest bookshop. All on 4 floors with a
decent little pub, The White Horse, in the middle. Go down stairs
into the Norrington Room and just look at the vast expanse of books
on sale.Coming back on the right hand side, the Sheldonian Theatre,
an early work by Christopher Wren, Exeter College with Blackwells
Art Shop on ground floor.

properties.name: University Challenge 3 (St Giles)
properties.gc_long_desc:
St Giles. What giants of literature
used the Eagle and Child in St. Giles as their watering
hole?
40 years old in 2002, you too can
have a go at the Bamber Gascoigne – Jeremy Paxman show, albeit with
a difference. For visitors to Oxford I suggest you park in one of
the five park and ride car parks the surround the city, and take
the bus in to the centre. From here you can start our little quiz.
But be warned, the cache is a 35mm cannister and due to the very
urban nature of their locations, are much in the public spotlight.
The trick is to winkle them out of their hidey holes without
attracting attention. It contains the most basic of waterproof
paper log, but no pencil, bring your own. Happy hunting!
Stand on the St Giles Memorial and
look north. To the west, The Randolph, over Beamont Street and
Cockerall’s magnificent Ashmolean Museum (one of the worlds greats
and worth a visit ). Then stretching up to the north, clockwise,
Blackfriars, St Cross, Pusey House, Regents Park, St Bennetts Hall,
to Somerville at the top, St Giles Church siting on its island
between the Woodstock and Banbury Roads, the Mathematical
Institute, then St Johns and finally Balliol on your
right.

Please note: the simple use of a 2p coin rotated between the
the lid and the base will prise the lid off with
ease.

properties.name: University Challenge 10 (Stomp Stomp)
properties.gc_short_desc:
Oxford University Museum of Natural History and The Pitt River Museum 
Question: Who or what left its mark across the grass outside?
A log will not be accepted unless the answer to the above question is not emailed to me through my profile. Please do not include the answer in your log.
properties.gc_long_desc: Another virtual I’m afraid as I could not find a suitable hidey hole anywhere.However, this is a must see location, not so much from the outside but from inside. Two stupendous museums, both free entrance, the Pitt River being entered in through the ground floor of the OUMNH. If you have kids in tow, they will just love it, but be warned, you could be there all day.

properties.name: University Challenge 1
properties.gc_short_desc: Radcliffe Camera
properties.gc_long_desc:
40 years old in 2002, you too can have a go at the Bamber Gascoigne – Jeremy Paxman show, albeit with a difference. For visitors to Oxford I suggest you park in one of the five park and ride car parks the surround the city, and take the bus in to the centre. From here you can start our little quiz. But be warned, this cache is a magnetic camoflaged breath strip and due to the very urban nature of their locations, are much in the public spotlight. The trick is to winkle them out of their hidey holes without attracting attention. 
 Happy hunting!
The way to approach this cache (when open) is to walk up the steps and through the gate of the admin building on Broad Street, across the gravelled courtyard and straight through the Bodelian and out the other side into the square.
Something to ponder about: The form of the three main buildings that dominate this space, to the north The Bodleian Library: A SQUARE, Radcliffe Camera in the middle; A CIRCLE, and St Mary’s The University Church to the south; A TRIANGLE. Deliberate or not?. Your essay expected in a months time please.

properties.name: Henry's Hever Cache
properties.gc_short_desc: A quiz themed on Henry VIII will get you to the cache location just a short walk from the centre of Hever.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The coordinates given are for parking which is in the Hever Castle Over-flow car park normally accessible from the road on the same side of the bend as the pub car park. Alternative parking is available in a layby by Hever church or in the pub car park if you fancy a drink! You do not need to go onto the castle grounds or pay the castle entrance fee to do this cache. The coordinates given are approximately 200m from the cache location.

Answer the following clues to get the coordinates:
N51 AB.CDE		E000 FG.HIJ

A:	Catherine of Aragon was wife number A.

B:	4 minus the number of children Henry had who succeeded him.

C:	The number of children Henry had with Catherine Howard.

D:	Number of older brothers Henry had.

E:	The end digit of the year of ‘The Field of the Cloth of Gold’.

F:	Date of marriage to Ann of Cleves, January 6th 154F.

G:	Number of the month (e.g January = 1) in which Henry was born.

H:	Year Jane Seymour died was 153H.

I:	Ann Boleyn’s cousin was wife number I.

J:	Henry VIII died on January 28th 15J7.

Henry the Ape Travel Bug
Henry VIII & His Chopping Block book
London bus wallet
35mm film

properties.name: King John Street
properties.gc_short_desc: A short offset multi featuring two of central Bath’s hidden gems.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Close to the main thoroughfare, this cache provides a brief diversion from sightseeing or shopping.  The final location is a good spot for a picnic.

At the posted coordinates you will find one of Bath’s oddest and most intriguing features. No-one seems to know much about it, other than that it’s probably been there since the early 1970s.  GPS reception in the area is poor, but you’ll know when you’re in the right place.

Now, count the total number of red (R), yellow (Y), blue (B) and green (G).  The cache can then be found nearby at
 
N 51° 23. (R-Y) (2*(Y-B)) (B-G)
W 002° 21. (B-1) (R) (G).  

The container is slightly smaller than a 35mm film canister.  Stealth is needed as this is a high muggle area.  The site is pushchair accessible, and also wheelchair accessible except for the last few feet.

UPDATE MARCH 2009:
On 12th February 2009 a planning application was passed for conversion of the vacant property on which the mural is painted into a restaurant.  The alterations to the building will result in the complete destruction of the mural.  We intend to leave the cache in place until building work starts - at the moment we have no idea when that might be.

properties.gc_long_desc:
Oldfield Park Station was opened on 18 February 1920, although the line through the site had opened in 1840.  Oldfield Park Station is a surburban railway station in the City of Bath.  It serves the mainly residential areas around Moorland Road in southern Bath.  (nb you can get a decent cup of coffee and quick lunch in Moorland Road if you are feeling peckish)

You can explore the countryside of the Avon Valley using the Bristol-Bath cycle path which can be accessed nearby.

properties.name: Gorgeous
properties.gc_short_desc: The coordinates for this Earthcache take you to Brunel’s famous Clifton Suspension bridge, which provides spectacular views along the Avon Gorge.
properties.gc_long_desc: The cache should be approached on foot as there is no parking on the bridge itself (free street parking nearby on both sides of the river). Please be aware that there is a toll on the bridge for motor vehicles (currently 50p). Pedestrians and cyclists may cross for free. The bridge is also wheelchair accessible. Once you've found the cache I would really recommend a visit to the suspension bridge visitor centre. You can also get more details about the bridge here: Clifton Suspension Bridge The Legend: There are a couple of different medieval legends which attempt to explain how the Avon Gorge was created. One version is that a giant called Vincent and his brother Goram both wanted to marry a beautiful woman called Avona. Not being able to choose between them, Avona challenged the brothers to drain a lake which lay over Bristol. Vincent chose to cut a channel through the limestone hills near Clifton, while Goram began to cut a channel through Henbury. Unfortunately for Goram, he drank one too many beers while he was working and fell asleep, leaving Vincent to finish his channel first, drain the lake and so win Avona. When Goram woke up, he was so distraught at having lost out to his brother, he stamped his foot in anger and in the process created another nearby geological feature in Henbury Gorge called the Giant’s Footprint. Goram then drowned himself in the Severn Estuary. The islands of Steep Holm and Flat Holm are supposedly the remains of his head and shoulder. The Geology: Although the legend makes a pretty story, in reality the gorge was formed by the river Avon which over thousands of years has eroded the limestone creating the spectacular gorge that you see today. The gorge runs 1.5 miles from here towards the Severn estuary where the river eventually meets the sea. Fossils show that the rock here was laid down during the Carboniferous period 350 million years ago. Firstly a layer of sandstone was deposited, followed by limestone sediments. The cliffs you see today are predominantly of limestone. Geologists have often pondered why the river Avon cut through the limestone ridge, rather than taking the more natural route to the sea through Aston Vale towards Weston-Super-Mare. The commonly accepted explanation is that during the ice age, Aston Vale was blocked by a glacier, forcing the river to take this alternative route.To Claim This Cache: Please take a photograph of yourself or your GPSr with the gorge in the background and post this with your log. Also after you log your find, please email the answer to the following questions to my profile: How wide is the Avon Gorge at this point? How high are you above sea level? (Tip: There are no info boards to answer these questions - instead why not use your GPS to find the answers?) Thanks for taking the time to visit this Earthcache and I hope you enjoy your visit.

properties.name: Avon Haven
properties.gc_short_desc: Our second cache, on the St Philips Greenway. We hope that it can be considered wheelchair friendly, as the path is flat, tarmaced and the cache can be accessed from the side of the path with the minimum of reaching.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is the second cache placed to celebrate Bristol being declared a Cycling City;  I think that the Greenway, which forms part of Route 3, is a great place to go for a walk/cycle with the family. The path itself is mostly flat apart from a rise/steps at the end near Avon Meads (there is a ramp for bikes!), and the odd tree route making interesting hummocks in the tarmac! 

Bristol City Council have produced a map of the cycle route, along with the Whitchurch Railway Path, also part of Route 3 and well worth a look, especially if you are on a bike. See this link for the map: (visit link)

If you want to know more about Route 3, or more about cycling in general, the best place to start is here: (visit link) (This takes you to the Sustrans web site)
Even if you are not in Bristol, Sustrans have lots of information about cycling all over the UK.

In addition, the route is on the River Avon Trail - if you follow this to the East you can get to some other caches in the area, such as Trooping by the chimney, which is just a short detour off, and also Hillside Hideout which is well worth a look. A map for the trail can be found here: (visit link)

This cache can be done as a nice stroll from Temple Meads, or if you fancy a break from shopping at Avon Meads, you can pop along to the site too, it is not far and a lovely walk along the river. If you drive, here is the best place to park.

When placed, the cache contained a map of Bristol's cycle paths (if you want one, it is a simple matter of asking the council, and they have maps that cover Bristol, South Gloucestershire, bits of Somerset and out towards Bath), a rubber duck, a bouncy ball, a frog and a geocaching pin.
There is also a log book and pen - please use both sides of the log book pages as although I cycle past the cache site every day, I dont want to waste paper!! 
We have now upgraded this cache to be a regular, given that people seem to want to put TBs in there. Please make sure you hide it well, and replace the 'camoflage' 

Enjoy!

properties.name: BATH TOURS #1 (St James's)
properties.gc_short_desc:
mapFirst of 3 short 'tours' around some of Baths architectural
delights providing clues leading to a final 'proper' cache on the
outskirts ot the town.
The walk is all on pavement and should be handicap accessible but
there are some steep slopes to consider.
You are looking for a 35mm film canister.
IF YOU DO THIS AT NIGHT YOU WILL NEED A TORCH!
properties.gc_long_desc: The co-ordinates above take you to an approximate start point in the South Eastern corner of St James's Square.St James's Square is just behind and to the north of Royal Crescent is one of the loveliest squares in Bath. Built by John Palmer between 1790 and 1794 on gently sloping ground. The terraces on opposite sides of the square match each other and have a garden area in the middle. The north and south sides have a central triangular pediment supported by Corinthian pillars with the houses on each end having a bowed façade. This is very similar to Lansdown Crescent, not surprising really as the same architect designed both. Look through the archway on the east side and note the lovely window. Did Dickens get his inspiration for his novel "The Old Curiosity Shop" from here? He certainly stayed with William George Savage Landor in number 35, and is said to have conceived the character of Little Nell whilst staying here. In this corner you need to look around for the following information: When did 'CD' Dwell here?: ABCD How many panes of glass are there in the curious window?: EF When did the poet WSG Landor die?: GHIJ When you have found these proceed to the NW corner of the square then follow the road up then right to take you out onto Cavendish Road the proceed up the hill to the junction with Sion Hill. As you go up you will pass the entrance to the rather grand Cavendish House. When you get to the junction find the date of the rather odd shaped building which used to be a Post Office: KLMN Now go back on yourself and turn left into Cavendish Crescent. Building of this crescent was begun in 1817 and took over 14 years to complete!. The architect was John Pinch and the crescent is far less flamboyant than the others in Bath. There are no central columns or pediment and hardly any decoration. The wrought iron balconies on the first floor are original, and note the canopies over some of the doorways and the lovely glass fanlights above the doors. When you have done admiring the crescent you can work out the final location N51 23.(M)(D)(F) W002 22.(A)(E+M)(J+A)PLEASE NOTE THERE IS NO PEN IN THE CACHE Now for the main bit! To find the location of the final cache you need to complete the puzzle below: Unfortunately to complete a Sudoku you need at least 17 boxes complete at the start to guarantee only one solution. As you may have noticed there are some missing. Each of the 3 'Tours' will provide 6 more numbers to assist you on the way. So that you cannot be sure you have the correct solution before you have completed all 3 tours. I suggest you print the grid and fill it in as you go. Obviously the same grid is used for all 3! The clues listed below give you the numbers to put in the grid E1 = (A+G+F) G3 = (H+G) G4 = (N-I) E7 = (H) B8 = (F+D) I1 = (M+K+G) If you need a printed grid on its own you can find oneherePlease note that there are no additional clues in the container. You have collected all the numbers you need while doing the 'tours'. I have done it this way so that short term visitors can still complete the series even if one of the three containers goes missing. Enjoy! Please take care when replacing as there is a drop the other side! Thanks.

properties.gc_short_desc:
Second of 3 short 'tours' around some of Baths architectural
delights providing clues leading to a final 'proper' cache on the
outskirts of the town.
The walk is all on pavement and should be handicap accessible but
there are some fairly steep slopes to consider.
You are looking for a 35mm film canister.
IF YOU DO THIS AT NIGHT YOU WILL NEED A TORCH!
properties.gc_long_desc: The co-ordinates above take you to an approximate start point in the centre of Lansdown Crescent.Built by John Palmer between 1789 and 1793, It is one of the nicest and better known of the crescents in Bath. Built in a fantastic position overlooking Bath with fabulous views (Now partly obscured by the trees)to the south. As you walk along the crescent you need to look around for the following information: How many 'Arrow heads' are ther between no's 10 and 11: A How many feet is to 'FC': BC How many lanterns are there on the front entrances: DE When you have found these proceed to the western end of the crescent and bear right which will take you into Somerset Place. Some people do not regard this as a 'proper' crescent as it has neither 'Crescent' or 'Royal' in its name but I think it qualifies and has better views than Lansdown. However it belongs to Bath Spa University so you cannot live there! It was designed by John Eveleigh and built in stages between1790 and 1830. Initially he built two semi-detached houses without curved facades and then added on crescent shaped wings on either side. Hence the reason for the very dominant central feature with the unusual broken pediment on top. Somerset Place was badly damaged during the air raids of 1942, and the central houses were gutted by fire - fortunately the facades survived. Look out for the very grotesque looking masks on some of the doorway keystones! You need to note the following: How many round 'View holes' are there on top of the western half of the crescent: FG When you have done admiring the crescents you can work out the cache location 51 23.(G+F+D)(C-D)(B+F-G) W002 22.(F-D)(C+D+F)(B-D-C)PLEASE NOTE THERE IS NO PEN IN THE CACHE Now for the main bit! To find the location of the final cache you need to complete the puzzle below: Unfortunately to complete a Sudoku you need at least 17 boxes complete at the start to guarantee only one solution. As you may have noticed there are some missing. Each of the 3 'Tours' will provide 6 more numbers to assist you on the way. So that you cannot be sure you have the correct solution before you have completed all 3 tours. I suggest you print the grid and fill it in as you go. Obviously the same grid is used for all 3! The clues listed below give you the numbers to put in the grid H1 = (A/2) B2 = (C) D5 = (E/2+G) D7 = (C+D) A9 = (G+C) B4 = (C+G) If you need to print a grid on its own you can find oneherePlease note that there are no additional clues in the container. You have collected all the numbers you need while doing the 'tours'. I have done it this way so that short term visitors can still complete the series even if one of the three containers goes missing. Enjoy!

properties.name: Sidetracked (permanently?) Bitton
properties.gc_short_desc: A short walk along level hard-surfaced paths. Wheelchair friendly.
properties.gc_long_desc: It seemed about time that I followed the trend and put out one of these side-tracked 'jobbies'! Bitton is the site of the Avon Valley Railway station. This restored rail link provides  a six mile return train ride along the former Mangotsfield to Bath Green Park branch of the old Midland Railway, and the chance to see the River Avon valley from an aspect that cars cannot reach.Parking is available close to the cache at N51 25.829 W002 28.558.The cache is only a short walk from here. This one is probably a good candidate for the old shoelace tying exercise!

properties.name: Bristol at Night
properties.gc_short_desc: Bored to death by the TV programme? Here is a nice and easy “city night” cache for you and your family. Ideal in winter when it gets dark very early. Clean boots guaranteed.
properties.gc_long_desc: At the given coordinates you will find yourself exactly where the background photo was taken. From this spot all clues and the cache itself are within a circle with a radius of ~400m. Stay on busy roads and places. Your task now is to find the locations where the different fluorescent letters have been photographed. When you have found a location, count the number of letters in the word from which the fluorescent letter has been taken. Note this number as you will need it later to calculate the cache coordinates. For Bristol take the letters A-G. For Night take the letters H-L. The three features in the centre of the picture are also somewhere to find. They won’t earn you anything but they tell you that you're reasonably close (max 200m) to the fluorescent letters. Letters that have changed since we set up the cache The O is only illuminated during the opening hours, i.e. in summer time it won't be on after dark, but still very easy to find. You don't need to look for i,s and t in Bristol anymore, as these letters are gone. That should make the cache a bit easier. Final N 51° 27.(A-G)(K-L-J)(B-I-I) W 002° 36.(F-H)(G)(J-A)Retrieving the Micro The final location is in a very busy place. We suggest you sit down and feel rather than look for the cache. Have fun! Some had fun.... Thank you Captain Gore-tex for this image.

properties.name: SideTracked - CC16 Keynsham and Somerdale
properties.gc_short_desc:
About SideTracked 
 We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy. But what about
public transport users? SideTracked caches are intended to provide
quick cache and dashes at train stations.
properties.gc_long_desc:
About Keynsham and Somerdale
Keynsham railway station serves the town of Keynsham, Somerset. It
is located on the London-Bristol and Bristol-Southampton trunk
routes and was opened on the 31st of August 1840 with the
completion of the Great Western Railway line between Bristol and
Bath. It was re-named "Keynsham and Somerdale" on the 1st February
1925 with the opening of the Fry's chocolate factory at Somerdale.
The station was rebuilt in 1931 to accommodate longer trains
bringing in workers who had transferred from a factory in Bristol
belonging to the company.
 The station's name reverted to Keynsham on the 6th May 1974. By
this time many workers had relocated to Keynsham, or commuted by
car. The factory had its own rail system which was connected to the
mainline. The connection to Fry's chocolate factory was taken out
of use on the 26th-27th July 1980. 
 The cache. 
 Just outside the main station entrance is the old cutting which
leads to the Somerdale Chocolate Factory, its is unfortunately
blocked by a padlocked gateway. Here you will find a micro
container AND BRING YOUR OWN PENCIL.
CAREFUL - the road can busy and fast, especially on the bend and
there is no need to go into the Cadburys Somerdale site (unless
your going to the chocolate shop!)
 Parking - Park either in the station or any of the nearby car
parks which are all free on Sundays. Alternatively down the hill
are the Lockkeeper and Brassmill pubs, both are thoroughly
recommended for food and drink.

properties.name: SIDETRACKED  - BATH
properties.gc_short_desc:
About SideTracked: We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy.
But what about public transport users? SideTracked caches are
intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train
stations.
properties.gc_long_desc: Bath Spa Staion: Bath Spa station was built in 1840 for the Great Western Railway by Brunel and is a grade II listed building. It is in an asymmetrical Tudor style with curving gables, and lies on the north bank of the Avon, with the line swerving elegantly across from the southern bank to the station and then back again. More info on Bath Spa station Cache is accessible from the platform and from outside the station You are looking for a 35mm film canister. The cache does not have a pencil. Please ensure it is well hidden as its a very busy place! FIRST TO FIND AWARDED TO: jenandberry

properties.name: SideTracked – Frome Railway Station
properties.gc_short_desc: A small magnetic cache in the SideTracked series.  We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy (cos there aren’t many Motorways in Wales!). But what about public transport users? SideTracked Caches are intended to provide quick Cache-and-dashes at Train Stations.
properties.gc_long_desc:
SideTracked started at Evesham station on August 10th 2007, placed by schnarff & bikermel76. It took a while to get started, but is now spreading across the country!
It is hoped this idea will spread across the country in the same way as the MMs….but if hiding one PLEASE BE SENSIBLE and remember that in this day and age, public transport is under greater scrutiny than ever before, so, although these caches should be quick and easy grabs, PLEASE don’t place a Cache where it could cause alarm!!! (Particularly, please ensure that you aware of the new rules of 04/09/08 before hiding your Cache!)

Frome station was originally on the Wilts, Somerset and Wymouth Railway, linking the Great Western Railway at Chippenham with Weymouth.  The line was authorised in 1845, was acquired by the GWR in 1850, reached Frome in the same year, and was completed throughout in 1857. The original route of this line is that of the loop line through Frome station. This line forms the basis for today's Bristol to Weymouth route.

A branch from Frome to Radstock, authorised by the same act of 1845, opened to freight traffic in 1854 and to passenger traffic in 1875. At Radstock this line connected with the Bristol and North Somerset Railway, providing a more direct route to Bristol than that provided by the Wilts, Somerset and Weymouth Railway.

In 1933 a by-pass route was constructed, enabling through traffic to avoid Frome station and the junction with the Radstock branch, and leaving the station on a looped branch as at present. 

Today the station is exceptionally quiet with only one platform still in use.  A few years ago it painted a sugar-mouse pink, which is erm nice.

Most of the trains server the Bristol to Waymouth route, although there are now peak services from Cardiff and London which pass through.  The most interesting of which is the 1836 ghost train which leaves Reading for Frome.  It's a ghost train because it doesn't show up on any time table right now... ooh spooky.  

The cache is a grey magnetic cache capable of holding small items,

properties.name: Nomen est Omen
properties.gc_short_desc: Once you’ve solved the little puzzle it is an easy multi stage cache ~0.5km round trip.
properties.gc_long_desc: The coordinates given are NOT the cache coordinates. As parking in Clifton can be difficult the above coordinates lead you to a street with limited pay and display spaces. After 6pm (or before 7am) or on Sundays parking is generally free in this area. The multi is set in a tranquil area. However it can get quite busy during lunch hour. Please make sure you don’t have an audience watching while you are programming your GPS and during retrieving of “Nomen est Omen”. The terrain is not perfectly flat but should be wheelchair accessible if you take a detour on the path. However retrieving of the cache might be tricky and will require a grip stick. (Please comment on this) We hope you enjoy this one. Again comments welcome. Please note that no dogs are allowed. WP1: You will find yourself in between 2 buildings. Both have a number where the 1st digit agrees. Let this be A.WP2: In which year was Prof. John Richard Clamp born? BCDE WP3: In which year was the sculpture purchased? FGHI FINAL The cache is at a relatively quiet spot of this area at:N 51 27.(H-A)(H-A)C W 2 36.(I-G) (C-A) (E-D) Free Webmaster

properties.name: Xmas Curios #4
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. Now to the cache:"On the fourth day of Christmas my true love sent to me, four sub-station vents" Find the curio. How many silver pineapple tips are to the right? = 'G' Cache is at N51.2?((G*D)+(16*B)+C)) W002.3?(G*12)

properties.name: SideTracked - Avoncliff
properties.gc_long_desc:
About SideTracked

We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy.  But what about public transport users?  SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.

About Avoncliff Station

This is a quaint, un-manned request stop station serving the hamlet of Avoncliff.  This area is often busy with local people and tourists who walk or cycle alongside the Kennet & Avon canal.  There is also a stunning aqueduct, built by John Rennie to see.   

This stretch of railway between Bradford on Avon and Bath Spa passes through the glorious Avon valley and hence offers the commuter another perspective to enjoy at a leisurely pace.  There is also the Kennet & Avon canal for those wishing to stop for a walk or bike ride. 

The Cache

You are looking for a magnetic canister.

properties.name: MASONIC BATHING? (BATH SPA)
properties.gc_short_desc: Stroll around some architectural delights in the city of Bath Spa. Should be suitable for all, there is no need to leave the footpaths. but there are some hilly bits. Modified clues as sign post 1 had changed. 19/Sept/2007. If you are doing this in the dark you WILL need a torch to read the plaque at the Crescent!
properties.gc_long_desc: In all formulae replace the letters in brackets () with the calculated numberStart at the co-ordinates above This is the 'Cross Bath'.The Cross Bath may possibly be named thus because the body of St Aldhelm rested there on its journey from Doulting to Malmesbury in 709. An 8th century poem in the 'Exeter Book' describes how "a stream gushed forth in rippling floods of hot water. The wall enfolded within its bright bosom the whole place which contained the hot flood of the baths." It also describes how the roofless ruins of the Roman town remained standing around the bath, dramatic and mysterious. Alsi's Bath, later the Hot Bath, was probably named after St Aelfsige, who was perhaps responsible for building a Saxon bath to replace the Roman one there. It is now part of the new 'Thermae Spa'. Just behind the bath you will find the entrance to the Hospital of St. John the Baptist. Get the year from above the gateway and make this ABCD. The hospital was founded in 1180 by Bishop Reginald of Bath for the sick and poor of the city in order that they might have the benefit of the waters. It was endowed with lands and tenements in Bath and with a tithe of hay from the bishop's lands Now walk to N51 22.(B+C)(B+C)(A+D) W002 21.(C)(D+B)(D+A+B) Here you will find a tourist signpost with how many pointers? Make this EF Now proceed up the hill to N51 22.(A+B+C)(B+C)(D+E+F-1) W002 21.(D+F-1)(D+F-1)(F+B) This will the bring you to Queens square. The architect John Wood the Elder (1704 - 54) built Queen Square and began the Circus. His son, John Wood the Younger (1728 - 82), completed the Circus and was responsible for the Royal Crescent. John Wood the Younger (1704 - 54) is believed to have been a member of the masons. and to have designed and planned this area to represent certain Masonic patterns. If you look at this area on a map you will see that Queens square, Gay street and the circus make up the pattern of a key. This is an important masonic symbol. Again you are next to a tourist sign. How many pointers this time? This is GH. Continue up past Queens square up the 'stem of the key' (Gay street) to N51 23.(G)(F)0 W002 21.(H+F-G-G)(F)(G+H) The Circus is one of the finest examples of Georgian architecture in the UK, built between 1754 and 1767. Originally known a the King's Circus, these elegant buildings were part of the architect's grand plan to recreate a classical Palladian architectural landscape in Bath. The Circus is considered to be Woods' masterpiece. Wood senior never saw the Circus completed as he died less than three months after the foundation stone was laid. John Wood the Younger, was left to finish the project. With three curved segments of equal length, the Circus has three separate entrances. The buildings have uniform facades and display three orders of Roman architecture ( the Doric, Ionic and Corinthian). It is thought that the Circus was Inspired by the Colosseum in Rome but John Wood the Elder was also influenced by Druids! The circular area of the Circus has almost the same dimensions as Stonehenge and the 30 houses of the Circus match the 30 standing stones. The freize includes 525 pictorial emblems representing the arts and sciences and a number of Masonic symbols. Originally the central area was an open piazza but in 1800 this was transformed into railed garden. During the air raids of 1942 several of the Circus buildings were destroyed but where later reconstructed. Ok, Onwards; Count the number of windows at ground level (thats the level you are on!) in the South Western segment of the circus. Make this JK. Proceed to N51 23.(G)(D+K)(K) W002 22.0(K)0 The Royal Crescent was built between 1767 and 1774. The curving terrace of 30 town houses was designed with 114 Ionic columns - the highest point of Palladian architecture in Bath. Created as lodging houses, the buildings had a uniform facade but varying interiors. (The Crescent Moon is also another Masonic symbol). Today Number 1 is a museum maintained by the Bath Preservation Trust. Numbers 15 and 16, at the centre of the Crescent, form the Royal Crescent Hotel. The Royal Crescent stands on a hill overlooking the Royal Victoria Park. The wide area of lawn in front of the building, owned by the Royal Crescent residents, is separated from the Royal Victoria Park by a ha-ha. Go along the front of the crescent and count how many have a 'split' front door that is the door opens in the centre in two halves. (In the same style as the first one.) This is LM. Whilst walking along the crescent you need to find the date that Sir Isaac Pitman died. This becomes NOPQ. Last one: Proceed to N51 23.(L)(H)(O) W002 21.(C)(O)(A+B+G+2) Assembly Rooms This is another of Mr Woods creations. Now an NT Property Access is free where there are Toilets and a cafe. Open most afternoons. This building also contains the Museum of Fashion to which there is an entry fee. Across the road (You have just passed it on the left) is the Museum of Asian art if you are interested. You are looking for a 'sticky' 35mm film container. , Cache does not contain a pencil so please bring one with you

properties.name: Way Down West 64
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.
