      After Way Down West 63 head to Waypoint 8 to turn right on footpath.

properties.name: Scooba Doo
properties.gc_short_desc: Traditional cache in an unusual hiding place at the Bristol Floating Habour WARNING: When you close it again DON'T screw the lid on too tight!!! (See below)
properties.gc_long_desc: No matter what season it's always nice to visit the Floating Harbour. Close by there is the famous S.S. Great Britain and there are numerous places to dine in or simply have a coffee around the harbour. The area is generally very popular and the muggle density can be extremely high. Especially then stealth is essential while retrieving and re hiding the cache. This shouldn't hold you back. We had the idea for this cache some while ago. Cache size is ~20x6x6 cm. As this is our first comments are appreciated. DON'T close the cache tighter than the marks indicate!!! Leave a tiny gap (~ as thick as a sheet of paper) between body and lid. Thanks. If we have to take Scooba Doo home again to open it we will remove the log entry of the guilty team as punishment! Why? See logs! since 22/08/07

properties.name: Eggsasperating Micro Eggstravaganza
properties.gc_short_desc: This geocache is a walk along part of the disused railway line on the south side of Bath called the Linear Park. It is fairly level but can sometimes be a bit muddy. The cache is a small 1.5l Tupperware box.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The path runs along the route of the old Somerset and Dorset Railway Line that ran from Green Park station in Bath to Bournemouth. The line closed in 1966, but some of the line has been converted into a footpath running from Twerton through Oldfield Park to Bear Flat. At Bear Flat, the railway went through the Devonshire Tunnel, then along Lyncombe Vale and into Combe Down Tunnel. Sadly, both of these tunnels are closed to the public, but the The Two Tunnels Greenway Organisation (part of Sustrans) has just secured some lottery money and planning permission to open up these tunnels and join the Linear Park to the Sustrans Path (NCN24) which exists at the other end of the Combe Down Tunnel. For more details see www.twotunnels.org.uk

There is parking on the main roads or side streets near the above coordinates, or at the other end of Linear Park – N51°22.612 W002°23.049

The geocache consists of six micros (Kinder egg containers – hence the title!) and the final box. Each of the micros contain one part of the final cache coordinates and are located randomly along the path.

The micros are located:
A	N51°22.484  W002°22.813
B	N51°22.442  W002°22.744 - answer is 1 (egg missing)
C	N51°22.227  W002°22.131
D	N51°22.345  W002°22.484
E	N51°22.367  W002°22.554		
F	N51°22.540  W002°22.957

The final location is:
N51°22.ABC  W002°22.DEF

It was quite difficult to accurately pinpoint the coordinates due to the tree cover. Please hide the caches well as this is a very popular path. Hopefully it won’t get muggled too often.

Once you have completed this, you may like to try my other geocache called Double Tunnel Trouble located on another part of the linear path, and starting at the same coordinates above.

properties.name: SideTracked - Bradford-on-Avon
properties.gc_long_desc:
About SideTracked:

We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy. But what about public transport users? SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.

About Bradford-on-Avon Station:

Bradford-on-Avon railway station is a quaint and surprisingly busy little station built from locally derived ‘Bath Stone’.  It is situated on the Wessex Main Line between Avoncliff and Trowbridge serving the town of Bradford on Avon (the station name is hyphenated, unlike the name of the town). The station is 15 km (9¼ miles) south east of Bath Spa.

Regular services are provided by First Great Western to a number of main line stations including Bath, Bristol Temple Meads and Cardiff Central in the north, Weymouth, Southampton and Portsmouth in the south.

The Cache:

You are looking for a magnetic film canister.  The cache does not have a mini pencil and hence we would advise visitors to bring their own scribing implement.

properties.name: The Nothe
properties.gc_short_desc: The cache, a medium-sized clip-lock box, is located a short walk from Weymouths' old harbour.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Nothe Fort was built in 1860 on the end of the Nothe Peninsular between Weymouth and Portland Harbours. It defended the latter before retiring from active service in 1956.
Now owned by Weymouth and Portland Borough Council, it is open daily, to the public, from May to September and Sundays/Bank Holidays for the rest of the year.

For more information visit:

www.weymouth.gov.uk  or  www.theheritagecoast.co.uk

Please be discreet when finding and replacing the container.
Happy caching!

properties.name: BATH TOURS #3 (Laura Place)
properties.gc_short_desc:
Third of 3 short 'tours' around some of Baths architectural
delights providing clues leading to a final 'proper' cache on the
outskirts ot the town.
The walk is all on flat pavement and should be handicap accessible
but there is one short steep slope to consider.
You are looking for a 35mm film canister.
IF YOU DO THIS AT NIGHT YOU WILL NEED A TORCH!
properties.gc_long_desc: The co-ordinates above take you to a start point of the fountain in Laura PlaceLaura place was the first part of a grand estate designed by the city architect Thomas Baldwin. His plans covered the 600 acre site of Bathwick Meadow owner by the Pulteney family, William Johnstone and Frances Pulteney, who inherited the estate in 1767. When Frances died in 1782 the entire Pulteney fortune went to their daughter Henrietta Laura after whom the place and Henrietta gardens (Implemented to replace the planned Frances Square residential area much later in 1833 by City Surveyor John Pinch.) to the north of Great Pulteney Street are named. Laura place is unusual in that it joins four streets of different sizes so it is 'lozenge' shaped. The grandest street in the whole of Baldwins plan is Great Pulteney street. This street was intended to split at Sydney Gardens and rejoin beyond but only the main street we have today and 16 houses in Sydney place were completed to his design. Half way up the street on the left is Sunderland Street which is only one house deep and on the right there are 3 more uncompleted roads, Johnstone, Edward and William streets. These three were designed to meet another street, Great Annerdale, which would have run parallel to Great Pulteney Street but was never completed. Most of the funding for these grand plans was speculative financed mainly by the BAth City Bank, unfortunately the bank crashed in 1793 which effectively brought the development to an abrupt end. Baldwin, the city architect was declared bankrupt in 1794 You need to proceed up Great Pulteney Street toward the Holburn Museum (Built 1796) and whilst admiring the buildings collect the following information: When did Lord Lytton Die?:ABCD When did Napoleon III Stay in the street?: EFGH When you have collected all that you can work out the final location N51 23.(E)(D)(F-A) W002 21.(B-H)(G)(C-H-E)PLEASE NOTE THERE IS NO PEN IN THE CACHE Now for the main bit! To find the location of the final cache you need to complete the puzzle below: Unfortunately to complete a Sudoku you need at least 17 boxes complete at the start to guarantee only one solution. As you may have noticed there are some missing. Each of the 3 'Tours' will provide 6 more numbers to assist you on the way. So that you cannot be sure you have the correct solution before you have completed all 3 tours. I suggest you print the grid and fill it in as you go. Obviously the same grid is used for all 3! The clues listed below give you the numbers to put in the grid E3 = (B/2) E4 = (G+E) H6 = (H+D) B9 = (A) E9 = (H+A) G8 = (D+E+G) If you need a printed grid on its own you can find oneherePlease note that there are no additional clues in the container. You have collected all the numbers you need while doing the 'tours'. I have done it this way so that short term visitors can still complete the series even if one of the three containers goes missing. Enjoy!

properties.name: Bristol Curios #12
properties.gc_short_desc: "Get Back VK"
properties.gc_long_desc: So you think you know Bristol? This series will find out how much you know/can find out/are lucky enough to bump into. All the series are small or micro caches with a code letter and number inside. Please make a note of these for the final cache. All the caches can be found within wandering distance of the City Centre. Some are well known and easy, some can be googled and simply found, some are obscure and some are plain difficult with no WWW reference at all. the cache difficulty will let you know which category is which. The series will be released bit by bit to give everyone a chance to find the cache first. The instructions are simple and apply to each cache: Find the object pictured and then follow the instuctions to find the cache location. Here is another, and is one of the easy ones. Find these items. How many letters and abbreviations are on the nearby black object = N Cache is at: (Checksum all digits = 48)      When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: BATH TOURS FINAL (View)
properties.gc_short_desc:
Final stage of the Bath tours serial. Posted coordinates are for
suggested parking which give access to the path to the hill!.
'Players' in wheelchairs may need assistance with the final
retrieval as the hide is down a smooth grass slope
properties.gc_long_desc: To do this cache you need to have completed:GC18V5C BATH TOURS #1 (St James's)GC18V5C BATH TOURS #2 (Lansdown Crescent)GC18WXW BATH TOURS #3 (Laura Place)AND completed the Sudoku grid.DON'T FORGET TO TAKE THE COMPLETED GRID WITH YOU! From the suggested parking (The area can be accessed from lots of other places but I think this is the most suited for easy access but the path is quite steep!) enter the path at N51 22.498 W002 21.853 go along and head up the hill. When you arrive at: N51 22.(C4)(D6)(F7) W002 21.(B5)(H8)(D9) Relax and take in the view I think this is definitely the best place to appreciate the city below and from here you can see (just!) everywhere you have visited to get you here. Once you have got your breath back, you need to find a micro (Smaller that 35mm 'pot') which will give you a set of references to decode from the previously completed grid. You will find it easier to roll the clue up and fit it into the lid of the holder before replacing the lid as it is quite a tight fit! Cache starting contents Flashing Spongebob magnet Travelling Draughts set (Not for kids as has small bits) Keyring torch And a prize for the FTF Hope you enjoyed the tour!

properties.name: Way Down West 53
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

      You will be lucky not to meet sheep,cows and horses.

      All smallish caches contain coins to swop.

      Eight waymarks are included to assist you.

      Cache is a 2 inch cylinder.

properties.name: SideTracked - Exeter St David's
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy 'cache and dash' near Exeter St David's station.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The station was opened on 1 May 1844 by the Bristol and Exeter Railway (B&ER).[1] The station was designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel and was one of his single-sided stations which meant that the two platforms were both on the east side of the line. This was the side nearest the town and so very convenient for passengers travelling into Exeter but did mean that a lot of trains had to cross in front of others.

This was not too much of a problem while the station was at the end of the line, but on 30 May 1846 the South Devon Railway (SDR) opened a line westwards towards Plymouth. A carriage shed was built for the SDR at the south end of the B&ER platform but the goods sheds and locomotive sheds for both companies were to the west, between the station and the River Exe. The SDR was designed to be worked by atmospheric power and an engine house was built on the banks of the river near the locomotive shed. This was only used for its original purpose for about a year but was not demolished until many years later.

The next railway to arrive at St Davids was the Exeter and Crediton Railway on 12 May 1851, the junction of which was a little distance to the north of the station at Cowley Bridge. This line was worked by the B&ER and trains were accommodated at the existing platforms. All these railways had been built to the 7 ft 0¼ in (2,140 mm) broad gauge, but on 1 February 1862 the 4 ft 8½ in (1,435 mm) gauge London and South Western Railway (LSWR) brought a line into the station from their own central station in Queen Street. The LSWR owned the Exeter and Crediton Railway and started to work the line for itself, although the broad gauge was retained for the B&ER to work goods trains to Crediton.

With two gauges and four companies using the single-sided station, it was in need of remodelling. A new double-sided platform opened on the site west side of the line and the original up platform at the northern end was closed. The original platforms had all had individual train sheds covering the tracks, and the opportunity was taken to replace these with one large train shed across all the main tracks and platforms. North of the station was a level crossing and just beyond this an additional goods shed was constructed. Unlike the earlier ones it was solely for transferring goods between the trains of the two different gauges. All these buildings were designed by the Francis Fox, the B&ER engineer, and the work was completed in 1864.

The B&ER was amalgamated with the Great Western Railway on 1 January 1876 and the SDR did the same thing exactly one month later. The main line from Bristol was rebuilt with mixed gauge track that allowed broad gauge trains to run through from London Paddington railway station to Penzance, while at the same time offering a standard gauge track for local trains from Bristol Temple Meads; the new line being ready by 1 March 1876.

The train shed was removed in 1912-13 and the platforms extended northwards towards the level crossing. A second island platform was provided on the west side and this entailed the goods sheds being narrowed from two tracks to one at their southern end. The middle island platform was mainly used for LSWR trains while down GWR services used the original main platform and the new island platforms. The station has remained largely in this form since, but resignalling in the 1985 saw the ex-LSWR services moved to the main platform so that down ex-GWR line services did not have to cross their path at the south end of the station. A through line between platforms 1 and 3 was removed at the same time. The new signal box was built on the site of the old atmospheric engine house and replaced three older signal boxes.

There are still many remains of the earlier stations to be seen. The main façade dates from 1864 and the Great Western Hotel dates from the earliest days, as does the southern section of platform 1. The goods shed opposite platform 6 shows the angle where the southern end was cut back in 1912, and at the northern end part of the original goods shed still stands beneath later extensions. The 1864 transfer shed can still be seen beside the line beyond Red Cow Crossing.

You are looking for a 35mm film container hidden near Red Cow Crossing, a short walk north from the main station entrance.

This is a very busy area and stealth will be required to retrieve the cache, particularly if the crossing gates are down.

Be careful of the busy road junction adjacent to the cache.

properties.name: Ring 1 : Entombed sea lilies and William Smith
properties.gc_name: Ring 1 : Entombed sea lilies and William Smith
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache shows Bradford on Avons fascinating geological history. This pit was specially excavated in 2007 and is famous for its fossils.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The heyday of the canals was in the first half of the 19th century. From the 1850s onwards, trade was taken over by the railway. Whilst carrying out engineering surveys for the nearby Somerset Coal Canal, William Smith (1769 - 1839) the 'Father of English Geology' was able to work out and publish the order of strata he encountered in the excavations. He published lithographs of fossils from the Bradford Clay in his pioneering collection, which was probably made in this or a nearby quarry.

At Bradford, the Kennet and Avon canal follows the southern side of the Avon valley. The cache site is on the dip slope of the Cotswolds Hills in the mid jurassic forest marble formation, some 165 million years old. 

This rock, some 24 metres thick consists of alternating limestones and clays. A thick layer of clay (Bradford Clay) occurs at this cache site above the limestones. The lower part of this clay is rich in fossil debris, derived from creatures that lived on or burrowed into the surface of the underlying limestone that formed the sea floor. Currents swept banks of broken shells around, breaking them down into shell-sand : lenses of more complete shells are found occasionally. Several different sea-floor environments are preserved in the rocks here complete with fossil fauna, buried by an influx of clay particles brought in on the current. This was probably the result of some sudden event, perhaps a river in flood, or the collapse of a pile of sediment nearby, maybe triggered by an earthquake. 

The most famous fossil here is the sea-lily Apiocrinites Elegans which grew fixeed to the solid sea bed (Ancliff Oolite). The shell-sand grains that make up much of this rock were by then cemented together with calcium carbonate dissolved in the sea water to form a hard, irregular limestone pavement. This provided a variety of habitats for burrowers, borers, and encrusting sea-creatures, as well as free swimmers. The site was first described in the 16th century, when it was realised that the fossils at the base of the clay bed had, in life, been living on the underlying limestone and that the clay bed had buried his fauna. Fine specimens can be seen in the Museum in the town centre by the bridge.

Fossils you are also likely to find here are Brachiopods (like tiny clawshells), Rhactorhyachia, Digonella & Epithyris. 

To claim the cache as a find please estimate and E Mail us the length and width of the pit and the telephone number on the back of the information board.

properties.name: Bolt out of the Blue
properties.gc_short_desc: A cache placed on the St Philip's Greenway - a great path that runs from near Temple Meads to Avon Meads.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is a cache placed to celebrate Bristol being declared a Cycling City; National Cycle Network Route 3 is often overlooked in favour of the much more publicised Bristol to Bath Railway path, however, I think that the Greenway, which forms part of Route 3, is just as nice, and a great place to go for a walk/cycle with the family. The path itself is mostly flat apart from a rise/steps at the end near Avon Meads (there is a ramp for bikes!), and the odd tree route making interesting hummocks in the tarmac!

Bristol City Council have produced a map of the cycle route, along with the Whitchurch Railway Path, also part of Route 3 and well worth a look, especially if you are on a bike. See this link for the map: http://www.bristol.gov.uk/ccm/content/Transport-Streets/Walking-Cycling/file-storage-items/whitchure-railway-path-and-st-philips-greenway-cyle-map.en;jsessionid=BA64293BFA644415CC361471FF4600E1

If you want to know more about Route 3, or more about cycling in general, the best place to start is here: 
http://www.sustrans.org.uk/
Even if you are not in Bristol, Sustrans have lots of information about cycling all over the UK. 

In addition, the route is on the River Avon Trail - if you follow this to the East you can get to some other caches in the area, such as Trooping by the chimney, which is just a short detour off, and also Hillside Hideout which is well worth a look. A map for the trail can be found here: 
http://www.riveravontrail.org.uk/

This cache can be done as a nice stroll from Temple Meads, or if you fancy a break from shopping at Avon Meads, you can pop along to the site too, it is not far and a lovely walk along the river. If you drive, here is the best place to park. 

The space in the cache itself is less than a 35mm film canister and there is probably no room for any geocoins, let alone swaps. There is a little pencil in there for signing the log. As it is not the usual micro, I have upped the difficulty due to recent DNFs. Good luck!

Suitable for push/wheel chairs. Dogs are fine .

properties.name: Way Down West 69-Ada Alley-The Final Retreat
properties.gc_name: Way Down West 69-Ada Alley-The Final Retreat
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

      You will be lucky not to meet sheep,cows and horses.

      All smallish caches contain coins to swop.

      Eight waymarks are included to assist you.

      Cache is a magnetic nano.

      Warning;-) You have entered Ada Alley.
      Ada's house is 200 yards further along the lane towards Way Down West 70.She is usually on patrol or on sentry duty outside her house disguised as a very angry lady.It really is best not to greet or engage her in conversation.Do NOT show any interest in the pole(the old cache location)just passed her property or you risk evoking her full anti-cacher fury.However if you do show an interest in the pole as I had to then do what I did and claim to be from E.P.A.S.(Electricity Pole Appreciation Society) Be careful out there.

      The Final Retreat.
After weeks of being dormant Ada has erupted again.In a clash already refered to in caching circles as The May Day Conflict, Ada's anti-caching fury has been vented again.For the safety of cachers worldwide I have had to relocate the cache again.
The new cache location cannot be seen from Adas sentry or patrol positions.Take care and good luck.

properties.name: View from Another Bridge (Bristol)
properties.gc_short_desc: Another micro along the Avon, originally between GCRDMM - A View from a Bridge and GCRDMJ - Bridge View [both sadly now archived].
properties.gc_long_desc: I like this area because of its 3D architecture. It's full of ramps and bridges, subways and stairs, twisting over one another. This place is an interface between road, rail and river, the meeting point of urban, rural and industrial. The cache site gives you sneaky views of Bristol, most obviously up the gorge to the Clifton suspension bridge, but also up to the Cabot Tower, and across to St Mary Redcliffe. There are a few places nearby where you can park a car nearby, but the area is notoriously difficult to navigate. You'll be better off biking it - the location is well connected on the National Cycle Network.

How many letters make up the mosaic work nearby = § The cache is at: (Checksum all digits = 65)        When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: Wolf tackles on Hyrule field (Where's Epona?)
properties.gc_name: Wolf tackles on Hyrule field (Where's Epona?)
properties.gc_short_desc: A simple child friendly multi cache on Gover Road field. Flat terrain but can be uneven in places and a bit muddy. Nettles and some thorns at the cache site.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Due to the need to move 'Wolf Tackles' from Hanham Mount we wanted to replace it locally. Our six year old Zeldarian chose the name but there are no current sightings of wolves on this field. Unfortunately we never even got off the ground with the first site chosen (before it was muggled)so we have had to re-work it from the second waypoint. You are searching for a cache cylinder (otherwise known as a beaker from Wilkinsons).

Go to the posted coordinates. There is parking nearby on Gover Road.

Once at the given coordinates answer the following questions:

How many swings are there? Call the answer A.

What colour are the gates? How many letters in the word? Call the answer B.

Now work out the coordinates for waypoint 2:

N 51 2 B . A 0 7  
W 002 (B-3) 0. (A+3) (B+2) (B-A-1).

Once you are there you will find something you would never want to be inside! There are three numbers on it - call them CDE and find the next waypoint using this:

N 51 C (D+E) . E (C+D) (C+D+E+1)

W 002 (A-1) (D-E-C) . (B+1) (C+D+E+1) (D+E+1)

This will take you to a post with two signs on it.

How many arrows are there on the top sign? Call the answer X

What are the last two words on the green sign? How many letters in each? - call the answers Y and Z.

Solve this and find the cache!

N 51 (Z-1) (Y+X) . D Y Z

W 002 Z (D-E-C) . (Y+1) X E

The coordinates take you to a point on the path (it can be very muddy) and the cache is a few paces off the path.

There is a bench fairly near the cache - sit down to have a rummage through the box, relax and think how nice it would be to have a horse called Epona to ride around the field on.

Please note that the original contents of the cache are all animal related please try and make animal swaps and if possible wolf ones!

We hope you enjoy this - we really like this area!

properties.name: Roamin'Bath #4
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the fourth in our Roamin' Bath series. This is in a different area but we  think that it is equally as interesting. It involves a short stroll around gardens adjacent to St Stephen's church. You can get here by public transport or by foot from the centre of Bath.  Free parking at the posted co-ordinates, but please observe the Residents Permit regulations. The cache is a small container suitable for GCs and small trade items.
properties.gc_long_desc:
From the posted co-ordinates you should be able to note what Zone number this is.  Call this AB

Go to N 51° 23.643 W 002° 21.785.  You should now be able to spot Richmond Hill xx.  Note the two digits xx as CD 

Entrance to the park is at N 51 23.649, W002 21.784. Take the time to admire the children's art work as you enter the garden - do we have a budding Gaudi?
There is a tiled area at N51 23.649, W002 21.767. Count the number of large square terracotta tiles. Call this EF 

The Millennium Greens Breathing Spaces garden is a joint project between the council and local residents. It is a lovely peaceful area with plenty of seating and some play equipment for the younger visitors. It is a pleasant spot to relax and admire your surroundings whilst you work out where the cache is located.  

The cache is not located in the garden but can be found nearby at 

N51 23.(C)5(A+B)   W 2° 21.(E+D)7(F)

Tree cover may affect your GPSr reading.

Happy hunting!!

properties.name: Bristol Curios #14
properties.gc_short_desc: "Get Back VK"
properties.gc_long_desc: So you think you know Bristol? This series will find out how much you know/can find out/are lucky enough to bump into. All the series are small or micro caches with a code letter and number inside. Please make a note of these for the final cache. All the caches can be found within wandering distance of the City Centre. Some are well known and easy, some can be googled and simply found, some are obscure and some are plain difficult with no WWW reference at all. the cache difficulty will let you know which category is which. The series will be released bit by bit to give everyone a chance to find the cache first. The instructions are simple and apply to each cache: Find the object pictured and then follow the instuctions to find the cache location. Here is the fourteenth. Find this object then sit back in the concrete chair. How many similar objects are there here together in a group, by a bridge that begins with this letter = P? The cache is at: (Checksum all digits = 57)        When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: Brighton Beach #4 - Passacaglia
properties.gc_short_desc: The cache is hidden somewhere along Brighton Seafront. I will continue to expand this series of caches over a period of time. While they are numbered, there are NO bonus clues to collect.
properties.gc_long_desc:
You are looking for a 35mm canister.  Please replace it carefully.

Finding ground zero will be easy enough. Accessing the actual cache may be a little tricky due to the constant muggle traffic and presence. Please adopt super stealth mode so as not to compromise the cache location. The cache name will become apparent on arrival.

Please bring your own writing implement as the cache does not contain one.

Good luck and happy hunting!!

properties.name: Church Micro #207 - Pyecombe
properties.gc_long_desc: Transfiguration of Our Lord - Pyecombe The original church was built in 1170 in the traditional Norman style. In the early 13th century the Tower was added and was topped with a pyramidal wooden roof with clay tiles. This roof is known as a 'Sussex Cap' as it is not common outside of Sussex. Inside the church you will find the original Norman Font dating from 1170. It is made from lead and is the best of only three other lead fonts in Sussex. The windows in the chancel date from the 13th century and the ones in the nave are from the Tudor period...circa 1500. If any body would like to expand to this series please do, I would just ask that you could let Sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication

properties.name: Mill Micro 25 - Hammerwood
properties.gc_long_desc:
I thought it would be fun to see how many new cache sites I could find near to Mills in my local area. These will include Watermills and Windmills, some still in use, some now used for other purposes. Most mills are sited in nice surroundings, so I hope you will enjoy visiting them. I will be adding new caches to this series over the next few months.

All the micros are hidden right on public footpaths. None of them will be very close to private houses. Some of them are near public highways, but many are along private roadways, with only footpath access. Please park considerately, and do not drive along any private roads to access the caches.

There are no sign of any mill buildings left here now, but there is still a lovely secluded mill pond. There is room to park by Hammerwood Church on the A264. There is a bridleway to the cache from 100 yards east of here. Be careful on this very busy road! There is no bridleway sign at this end of the track, but it is a driveway to a house, with 4 short concrete signs by it. Two of these say SV on them. Alternatively you could park in the little lane that goes past the northern end of the bridleway. There is space for a car about 50 yards to the west of the bridleway.

properties.name: Brighton Beach #1
properties.gc_short_desc:
The cache is hidden somewhere along Brighton Seafront.

I will continue to expand this series of caches over a period of time. While they are numbered, there are NO bonus clues to collect.
properties.gc_long_desc:
As of 24th August 2009 you are now looking for a black geocaching micro capsule which is actually larger than the original and should be easier to find... [;)]

The cache is not hidden at either road level and is NOT hidden in the bushes.

Good luck and happy hunting!!

properties.name: The Train That Never Comes..
properties.gc_short_desc:
The ghost train has moved on a little to a quieter location away from stray ostriches. He also requires you to find two other items of hidden history before he'll reveal his location.

The co-ordinates above are the only one's you'll get but are not those of the cache. All the locations you'll need to visit are less than a mile from this point.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This little cache stretches between Bristol University and the ghost line running beneath the graveyard at St Mary Redcliffe's. This is best found on a Sunday morning when the streets are quiet but can be found any day in good light.

You first task is to find the cross (the replica not the original) in the picture file 'map' below. Next count the number of capital letters in the two words that make the last line of text on the nearest park gate. These become A and B.

Your second task is to find a statue of Bristol's famous canine son. Beneath him is a door bearing the number CD.

Your final task is to find the heaven-bound branch line for the ghost train. Head to N 51° 26.872 W 002° 35.343 to find the East end of the tunnel then make your way through the church grounds to the West end. The branch line is within the church yard. Record the significant year - EFGH.

The final cache is at 51.26.(F-A)(C+8)(4-G), 2.35.(B+3)(D+E)(H+5).

properties.name: Lady with Veiled Face
properties.gc_short_desc:
Introduction
This is a 3 stage multi-cache. Its aim is to take you around some
of the more interesting or unusual parts of old Bristol and to give
some idea of its history. There are plenty of places to eat and
drink on the way. There is ample parking around the city
centre.
properties.gc_long_desc: Please note the difficulty rating of this cache - it is challenging but not intended to be deceptive. It should be fairly obvious when you have the right answer to each question. Almost all the route is paved, with the occasional short excursion onto grass. The route is relatively flat but some steps are involved. The waypoints are away from the traffic but there are some busy roads en route so be careful with younger children. You do not need to enter any buildings to complete this cache. There is 24 hour access to all sites apart from task 6 which is open approximately during daylight hours. Stage 1 involves locating the "Lady with the Veiled Face" somewhere in the centre of Bristol and collecting some nearby information that you will need for the next stage. Stage 2 involves a trail round the old part of central Bristol collecting information that you will need for stage 3. Stage 3 is a straightforward small cache in central Bristol. The cache is a small plastic box just large enough for a logbook and some small swaps and travel bugs. Stage 1 may take a little time depending how resourceful you are. Stages 2 and 3 will probably take 2 hours in total. Stage 1 - The Lady Somewhere in the centre of Bristol lives the "Lady with the Veiled Face". No-one knows who she is or why she is veiled. You need to find this lady. She is within a few minutes' walk of your starting co-ordinates. The search area is a triangular part of old Bristol bounded on the South by Baldwin Street, on the North-West by Colston Avenue/Quay Street, and on the North-East by High Street/Broad Street. When you have found her stand underneath her and look for a red box containing an eleven digit number. The last 7 digits are tuvwxyz. Use the table to record your answer: t u v w x y z              This is the end of stage 1. Stage 2 - The Search This stage involves some walking. Use the table at the end to record the answers. Task 1 Go to N51°27.uvv W2°35.zuy Look for the third of four. Please make absolutely sure you go to the correct one - there is a sequence. If you look around there is a way of verifying which is which. What date is inscribed on it? Last digit = "a" . Just for fun - also at these co-ordinates is a very interesting timepiece. You may want to look for it and read the notice giving its background. But this is not part of the cache if you don't want to do this. Task 2 Go to N51°27.wy(z-y) W2°35.v(v-z)u Sometimes it's not easy to get a GPS fix here, but it should be pretty obvious what you are looking for. Look up where you cannot see the sky. Count the stone circles. Answer = "b" At one corner of this building is an unusual feature. When was it moved to its present site? Last digit = "c" Task 3 Go to N51°27.(w-u)(z-y)z W2°35.zxw What is the year it was built? Last digit of year = "d". Task 4 Go to N51°27.xwu W2°35.z(z+u)x Look for two separate inscriptions that both start "STN". Which inscription has the lowest numbers after it? These are "ef". Task 5 Go to N51°26.t(u+u)w W2°35.(w+y)yt Last digit of year = "g". Task 6 - not accessible after dusk Go to N51°26.(y+w)vv W2°35.wvy Near this spot is an unusual plant that never needs cutting! What is the year in which it was planted? Last digit ="h". Also near this spot (40 paces or so) is a small, flat gravestone. You will know when you have found it because you might expect to see 8 more besides. In which year was he (or she, or it) born. Last digit="j". This is the end of stage 2 - you are now very near the final cache. But don't rush - please take a few moments to look inside the building; it has a fascinating history. a b c d e f g h j                  If you have completed this stage correctly the sum of the numbers in the above table will equal the last 2 digits of the year in the first part of task 6. NOTE: You will need some of these numbers again if you need to use the "hint". Stage 3 - The Reward The final cache location is nearby at N51°26.(a+e)(g+j)(c-h) W2°35.(d+j)(j-h)(b+d). Please be careful as muggles may interrupt you with little warning!

properties.name: York Micro #13 St Martin cum Gregory
properties.gc_name: York Micro #13 St Martin cum Gregory
properties.gc_short_desc: A stand alone cache in the York Micro Series. 35mm container
properties.gc_long_desc: The cache is located off Micklegate. There is no need to enter the church grounds. The church is the centre for stained glass work in York. More information can be found here

properties.name: Blaise Hamlet (Bristol)
properties.gc_short_desc:
Blaise Hamlet is a beautiful group of houses built for pensioners
by the renowned architect John Nash. The hamlet is open all year
and suitable for children, pushchairs (a few steps) but not
wheelchairs.
properties.gc_long_desc: Blaise Castle is a unique hamlet of cottages built by John Nash in 1809 and a typical photograph is shown here. The hamlet consists of nine different cottages around a central sundial, all of which are completely unique and very interesting. Further details are here. We were unable to plant a physical cache because the cottages are still occupied and there was nowhere suitable. Hence we've set a virtual cache here. Go to the coordinates to record the 4th line of text. Please mail this to us through the above link "The Wombles" at the same time as logging the cache. Under no circumstances should you post the answers in your log or post photographs of the answer. You must physically visit this cache in order to log it, please do not abuse this requirement (I regret that I will have to delete logs that do not meet these requirements). When you email the answer then please remember to release your email address to enable us to reply. An Ordnance Survey map for the general location is shown at this site. Parking is on the (wide) street next to the entrance. An (excellent) childrens' playground, space for picnics and the Blaise Castle museum are all just up the road, details here. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: Last Man Standing II
properties.gc_short_desc:
***** Last Man Standings - Big Brother *****
Now open for all to grab.
properties.gc_long_desc:
*****Do not attempt at rush hour or midweek lunch times*****
******* There's just to many office-mugglers about *******

My 1st listing using the 3G iphone to obtain the coodinates - using it's mapping, GC.com converting to DM's, and the iphone camera to obtain the spoiler pic and mapping screenshot too.Non-wheelchair friendly due to height.

**********Well done to that FTF hound - Luzian**********

properties.name: Flonopoly Cache 7 - Kings Cross
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to FireLanterns-onopoly, or Flonopoly for short. A cache
series inspired by (but in no way associated with or endorsed by!)
the board game of a similar(ish) name. This series of caches will
take you to 28 locations around the streets of London, some well
known, some not so well known, but all of them made famous by that
great board name we all know and love. 
The caches are mostly all 35mm and magnetic, containing log book
only, so bring a pen. Within each cache you will also find a small
Flonopoly logo, with a number on the back. Take careful note of
this number (and make sure you get the logo the right way up - turn
it round, not upside down - don't mix up those 6's and 9's!) - as
you will need all of these if you want to go for Flonopoly - Jail
and ultimatley Flonopoly - GO. If you make it all the way round
these London Streets, there will be a small Flonopoly reward as a
mark of respect for covering a lot of miles. Also if this is your
first Flonopoly cache, please take note of the date and time of
your first find - and when/if you do them all, the date and time of
your last, so when you log Flonopoly GO you can tell us how long it
took you to do the series !
Flonopoly Cache 7 - Kings Cross - one of 4 stations on the well
known board game. Originally opened in 1852, Kings Cross Station is
one of London's major railway terminus', predominantly serving the
East Coast Mainline.
The cache - near argyle square, close to kings cross. The cache may
not be accessible 24/7

properties.name: CORTON RING 40
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The caches are set in such a way that they can be completed in one 12 mile round walk or attempted in two separate 6 mile circular walks.  Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: Not the Westminster Cathedral Piazza
properties.gc_short_desc: Not the Westminster Cathedral Piazza
properties.gc_long_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about geocaching** Unfortunately because of the security
situation it is not possible to place caches within 200ft of
Westminster Cathedral so this is about the nearest I can place a
cache.

    The Cathedral site was originally known as
Bulinga Fen and formed part of the marsh around Westminster. It was
reclaimed by the Benedictine monks who were the builders and owners
of Westminster Abbey, and subsequently used as a market and
fairground.
    After the reformation the land was used in
turn as a maze, a pleasure garden and as a ring for bull-baiting
but it remained largely waste ground. In the 17th century a part of
the land was sold by the Abbey for the construction of a prison
which was demolished and replaced by an enlarged prison complex in
1834.
    The site was acquired by the Catholic
Church in 1884. T he Cathedral Church of Westminster, which is
dedicated to the Most Precious Blood of Our Lord Jesus Christ, was
designed in the Early Christian Byzantine style by the Victorian
architect John Francis Bentley. The foundation stone was laid in
1895 and the fabric of the building was completed eight years
later. The awesome interior of the Cathedral, although incomplete,
contains fine marble-work and mosaics. The fourteen Stations of the
Cross, by the sculptor Eric Gill, are world renowned. .
    In the early 1970s the area bounded on the
north by Victoria Street, on the west by Vauxhall Bridge Road and
on the east extending to the Army and Navy Stores was
comprehensively redeveloped and the Westminster Cathedral Piazza
created in front of the Cathedral. The Cathedral suddenly became a
highly visible architectural monument in a major public urban
setting. .
     The nearest tube stations to Westminster
Cathedral are Victoria Station and St. James Park, both within Zone
1 of the London Transport system.
The GPS signal round the cache is poor. I have changed the clue
to help cachers. Please note the cache is NOT in the piazza as the
cache name states! I have put up a photograph of the view from the
cache site to assit locating the cache.

properties.name: Way Down West 83
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

      You will be lucky not to meet sheep,cows and horses.

      All smallish caches contain coins to swop.

      Eight waymarks are included to assist you.

      Cache is a 3x3 locktop box.

      After this cache you have to go through the gate to continue with the hedgerow on your left.When I placed the cache the gate had a tyre leaning against it,so I had to climb over.

properties.name: Flonopoly Cache 17 - The Strand
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to FireLanterns-onopoly, or Flonopoly for short. A cache
series inspired by (but in no way associated with or endorsed by!)
the board game of a similar(ish) name. This series of caches will
take you to 28 locations around the streets of London, some well
known, some not so well known, but all of them made famous by that
great board name we all know and love. 
The caches are mostly all 35mm and magnetic, containing log book
only, so bring a pen. Within each cache you will also find a small
Flonopoly logo, with a number on the back. Take careful note of
this number (and make sure you get the logo the right way up - turn
it round, not upside down - don't mix up those 6's and 9's!) - as
you will need all of these if you want to go for Flonopoly - Jail
and ultimatley Flonopoly - GO. If you make it all the way round
these London Streets, there will be a small Flonopoly reward as a
mark of respect for covering a lot of miles. Also if this is your
first Flonopoly cache, please take note of the date and time of
your first find - and when/if you do them all, the date and time of
your last, so when you log Flonopoly GO you can tell us how long it
took you to do the series !
Flonopoly Cache 17 - The Strand, in the City of Westminster,
heads east from Trafalgar Square to join Fleet Street at Temple
Bar, which marks the boundary of the City of London. Taking it's
name from the old english word for "shore", The Strand (or just
"Strand" - it is referred to as both) has been home to palaces,
theatres, shops & nightlife for over a few hundred years, and
The Strand is still central to London's theatre land today, being
home to The Adelphi, The Savoy, and The Vaudeville. Another useless
fact (!) to note, is that Savoy Court, a road towards the eastern
end of The Strand that leads to the Savoy Hotel, is the only street
in the UK where vehicles are required to drive on the right.
So, the cache - at the Trafalgar square end, and just off The
Strand itself, think grills of some description....

properties.name: West End Trail - Sewer Gardens
properties.gc_short_desc: 35mm magnetic micro marking Victoria Embankment Gardens. Containing log book only, bring a pen.
properties.gc_long_desc:
A harsh title, as these gardens are actually very beautiful. They were laid out by Joseph Bazalgette to ease traffic congestion, beautify the riverside, and more importantly house the main London Sewer that Bazalgette is famous for creating. Link to the wiki here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joseph_Bazalgette

There is a wealth of statues and monuments in the gardens, fantastic greenery, and plenty of places to relax and feel like you aren't in the West End of London. The cafe in the middle of the gardens also serves a superb breakfast under the canopy of some amazing trees !

So - to the cache - accessible 24 hours a day, from outside the gardens on Villiers street. Muggle central 24 hours a day also, so maximum stealth will be needed.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

properties.name: Way Down West 1
properties.gc_short_desc: The caches start at West Down in North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      Way Down West will take around 10 to 12 hours to complete,either ring will take about 5 or 6 hours.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

      You will be lucky not to meet sheep,cows and horses.

      All smallish caches contain coins to swop.

      Eight waymarks are included to assist you.

      For some of the smaller caches you will need a pen/pencil.

      Most stiles do not have an opening for dogs.At Way Down West 49 and 50,two stiles are 6 feet high.

      As for taking a break there is a bench at Way Down West 7 and a picnic table at Way Down West 46.I am sure that is all.

      If you are planning on staying in this part of North Devon,for good value there is The Mullacott Camping Barn(01271 866877) or to wake up between Way Down West 10 and 11 there is Little Comfort Farm(01271 812414) where you can fall out of bed,do the whole circuit and be back in time for your evening meal.

      Cache is a 3x3 locktop box.

     TRACKABLES
     I know it will take cachers a long time to log their finds but may I ask that if you place/take a trackable could you please log that find as soon as possible.Thanks, kevham1.

properties.name: Fag Alley - Hole in the wall
properties.gc_name: Fag Alley - Hole in the wall
properties.gc_short_desc: Beautiful views over Bradford-on-Avon if you walk to visit this cache. Our first cache, within a few minutes walk of Pez's home. You could park right next to it, but for more enjoyment we recommend a walk from the middle of town, possibly dropping by GCJHCW. Small Tupperware container. Please make sure to re-cover with the rocks!
properties.gc_long_desc:
This alley is very popular with muggles late at night and just after the local school closes (3pm) so be alert!

Cache is slightly out of reach and hidden under some rocks, may require a stretch.

Clue; a square house has four of these - cache is inside (on top) of one.

properties.name: Queen Square
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a simple 'multi' cache set in one of Bath's famous
locations! You are looking for a 35mm film canister that contains a
log sheet and pencil.
properties.gc_long_desc: Queen Square was the first speculative development by the architect John Wood, the Elder. Numbers 21-27 make up the north side, which was described by Nikolaus Pevsner as "one of the finest Palladian compositions in England before 1730". The west side (numbers 14 - 18 and 18A, 19 & 20) was designed by John Pinch in 1830 and differs from Wood's original design as the central block is in Neo-Grecian style. 16-18 is now occupied by the Bath Royal Literary and Scientific Institution (BRLSI). The south side (numbers 5-13) which was originally left open is now occupied by a hotel. All of the buildings have been designated by English Heritage as grade I. The obelisk in the centre of the square was erected by Beau Nash. During World War II, between the evening of 25 April and the early morning of 27 April 1942, Bath suffered three air raids in reprisal for RAF raids on the German cities of Lübeck and Rostock, part of the Luftwaffe campaign popularly known as the Baedeker Blitz. Over 400 people were killed, and more than 19,000 buildings were damaged or destroyed. Houses on the south side of Queen Square were damaged but have subsequently been restored. The square hosts a lot of attractions all year, such as a French market, Italian market, and a Boules weekend. At the posted co-ordinates is an obelisk. In what year was the original obelisk built? Call this: ABCD Now go to N51 22.988 W002 21.848 and find out when William Oliver was born. Call this: EFGH Now go to: N51 2C.0F0 W002 21.DH(C+H) to find the cache!

properties.name: Child's Play
properties.gc_short_desc: A simple magentic nano near the play area and cafe at Blaise Castle.  It should be child's play to find the information required to find the cache - and if the children get bored, they can always just play!  Sadly children (and the more diminutive adults) will need assistance in reaching the final cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ordinates are for the entrance to the car park.

Once you have parked up, head towards Blaise Castle House Museum and look for the required information en route (they are in order).

1. Christopher Robin might be disappointed with the size of the nearby wood.  How many acres?  AB

2. When did the guard dog take its position? CDEF

3. How many words in the third line of the prose?  G

4. In what year was the English Oak planted? HJKL

5. What number (above the "E") is on the concrete post by the gate?  MN

6. When was the Silver Maple introduced?  PQRS

7. How many of the largest (ornate) stone vases are visible from the fork in the path?  T

8. How many dogs can you see? (stone ones, not real ones!)  V

In true pantomime fashion, the answer to the question "where's the cache?" is "it's behind you!".  More precisely, it is to be found at:

    N51 30.(F-V)(J+M)(G+L)
    W002 38.(S-C)(T-R)(Q-A)

Happy New Year & happy caching everyone.

properties.name: Lost and Found in Winchester
properties.gc_short_desc:
A magnetic cache with space for geocoins and small swaps

The coordinates are for one of many car parks nearby and play no part in the search for the cache. 
This cache involves a short walk around some lost or  forgotten places in this interesting city, but you will need a sharp eye and an enquiring mind to spot the details.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The ninetieth feast
 was celebrated with uncommon joy 
 August 23rd  1759

The two hundredth anniversary was celebrated  
by a 
public commemoration 
when the society of  aliens 
and all classes of the citizens 
united with the natives society 
in one grand festival

October 14th 1869



This  is  carved  into the plinth of a monument  to be found  just  outside (and with good reason) the walls of this historic city;      But where is it?

1.  When you have found it;  you'll need the last word on the west face = A  

2. Go to N51º 03.A90   W1º 18.923   and find the 
two-word  power source which sets this object apart from all the others in Winchester . The number of letters = B,C

3.  Go to N51º 03.7AC  W1º 18.900, you need to face the king, If you are unsure which one he is; he’s the one who knows the time! Then take ten paces to the south and note the number of  stone blocks wearing horseshoes !  = D.

4. Go to N51º 03.(B+D)(B+C)(A+C) W1º 18.930  where you should enter the tiny  Church of St. Peter’s-in-the-Shambles and count the flags against the west wall (inside) = EF

When you’ve got all those  you can work out where the  cache is to be found, and  have a well-earned rest.
N51º (A-B-E)(A-C) • (B+D) (B+C) (A-E)
W001º (C-D) (A+C) • E (C+D+E) (A+F) 


Contains at start: 2007 Evil-Micro geocoin, a little boat coin and an obsidian elephant (for the FTF) a logbook and pencil.

properties.name: Xmas Curios #9
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. This curio is really easy to google find Now to the cache:"On the ninth day of Christmas my true love sent to me, nine deceased heros" Find the curio. What sort of an animals behind are you looking at? Add the digits = 'S' Cache is at N51.2?((S*76)+(R*2)) W002.3?((S*25)+R)

properties.name: Via Romanus
properties.gc_short_desc: I've added a reminder which will make the starting point a little easier I hope!
properties.gc_long_desc:
There are several roman roads leaving Winchester,  most of them are still main roads in long straight stretches, but in some places all trace has gone.

The coordinates above are for the only roman street that King Alfred kept when he redesigned what remained of Venta Belgarum, but they will not help you to solve this puzzle.

I have disguised the whereabouts of this cache and when you have unscrambled the numbers below you will see that it is indeed on a stretch of roman road , and that parking can be found less than 300 passi away.

              The cache can be found here:

        112511169222222111111222211162292511111192222

Remember there are 26 letters in the alphabet.

placed in high muggle areas and enable geocachers to make the most

any not signed will be deleted. 17/02/09 - Congratulations to

properties.name: Gates To The Charterhouse
properties.gc_short_desc: One of my favourite spots in London.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Some wonderful hostalries although it is getting rather too trendy. Terminal trendiness has not yet spread to Charterhouse Square perhaps because they are protected by this magnificent set of gates, which also provided a safe home for a tiny nano magnetc cache.

Lots of people about by night and day. The chef at the restaurant opposite probably wondered what I was doing as they smoked their fags.

properties.name: Long Tall Alley - Nano
properties.gc_short_desc: Brydges Place - Londons Narrowest Alley
properties.gc_long_desc:
Just on the south side of the Coliseum Theatre is one of the narrowest openings to an alley in the whole of London. However, it is most certainly not one of the prettiest. The passage extends between St Martin's Lane and the corner of Bedfordbury and Chandos Place, with an outlet half way along to William IV Street. To get the full effect of the narrowness, walk from the east end towards St Martin's Lane. Towering walls on either side give one a feeling of being squeezed.

At one point it is on 13 inches wide.

The access from St Martin's Lane would not originally have been built so narrow. Through demolition and rebuilding over the years in an already congested district, available land was at a premium. This meant that every opportunity to snatch a little extra was seized upon, leaving the access to Brydges Place as little more than a crack in the wall. Although the passage has been here since the early 17th century it started life under the name of Dawson's Alley. At the beginning of the 19th century it appears to have been known as Taylor's Yard - indicating an area of rather larger proportions - and by 1875 the name had changed to the present Brydges Place. The reference is to George Brydges, Lord Chandos, who was the forces Paymaster and an ancestor of the Duke of Chandos. 

For the mischeivious it is also a great place to dart out from unexpectantly and startle innocent tourists!

properties.name: Church Micro 977 - London Westminster Chapel
properties.gc_short_desc: This is not the Abbey, nor is it the Cathedral - It is the Chapel. ** **This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching** The cache is a magnetic key safe clearly marked with a geocaching sticker - see attached photo It is on the same side of Buckingham Gate very near the Chapel and NOWHERE near the Guards Barracks
properties.gc_long_desc: It was a time of hope in May of 1841, as twenty-two Christians sat in the beautiful, newly-built chapel on Buckingham Gate – full of faith in God for how he would move in that downtrodden and degraded area. With Westminster Chapel's first minister, Rev Samuel Martin, at the helm, the church began to make waves in the neighbourhood. Alms houses and schools were built, orphans were cared for and work schemes were organised for unemployed men. Rev Martin's gospel-preaching and Biblical authority made Westminster Chapel stand out as a light of hope in what was then one of London's poorest slums - rife with prostitution, squalor and drug addiction. Even influential leaders of that time like Lord Shaftesbury and Dean Stanley of Westminster Abbey began to hear of the Chapel's impact in the area. By 1860, the 500-capacity building was unable to accommodate a rapidly-burgeoning membership so a new, 1,500-seater building was designed, built and opened in 1864. The area is not such a slum today!! If anybody would like to expand on this series please do so. Could you please let sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication. ** **This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching**

properties.name: Blind Spot
properties.gc_short_desc:
SHORT DESCRIPTION: Part of a route of caches along the South Bank, this is a nano cache, as the location is one of the busiest in England! 

Being a nano, it might be hard to spot.
I have also added points to the difficulty rating due to muggle presence.

Stealth, Stealth and MORE STEALTH is required. Please bring your own pen as there is no space for anything other than the log.
properties.gc_long_desc:
LONG DESCRIPTION:
Part of a route of caches along the South Bank, this is a nano cache, as the location is one of the busiest in England! Muggles everywhere, of every description. 
You are between The London Eye http://www.londoneye.com/   and County Hall http://www.londoncountyhall.com/  . As I am sure you are aware, The Eye is an excellent place from which to see London (as long as you are not scared of heights). County Hall is home to a number of attractions including a Sea Life Aquarium, Oceanic Village, Dali Universe and the London Film museum.
Across the Thames you can see Big Ben’s Tower and the Houses of Parliament http://www.parliament.uk/visiting/index.cfm .
To the West is the Royal Festival Hall and South Bank Centre, home to various arts and often a venue for free International events. Also in the immediate vicinity are The Hayward Gallery, British Film Institute, National Theatre and the Royal Festival Hall. More about the South Bank Centre: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southbank_Centre .  
SO - TO THE CACHE:
Being a nano, it might be hard to spot.
I have also added 2 points to the difficulty rating due to muggle presence.
Stealth, Stealth and MORE STEALTH is required - as the site is overrun by sightseeing muggles!
Please bring your own pen as there is no space for anything other than the log.

properties.name: Birchmoor
properties.gc_short_desc:
A small-medium clip top box in a camo bag.  Contains logbook, pencil and space for a few swaps.  
Launched with a prize for FTF.
** CONGRATULATIONS! To Team Turney and Dave for your FTF! :) **
properties.gc_long_desc:
The cache site is located with easy parking, along a public footpath on the outskirts of Aspley Guise village.  Aspley Guise was first mentioned in the Doomsday Book of 1086 and although situated just outside the new city of Milton Keynes and close to the M1 motorway it has managed to retain its rural feel.  The footpath where the cache is located takes you on a nice countryside walk between between the villages of Husborne Crawley, past Birchmoor Farm, the old manor-house of the Stauntons in the 17th century, to Woburn.

Most of the surrounding land is owned by the Bedford Estate, ancestral home to the Dukes of Bedford.  One of the entrances to the Woburn Park, Woburn Abbey and Wild Animal Kingdon is situated close to the cache site, at the end of Horspool Lane.

The only disturbance to your cache walk might be the occasional dog walker so please take care not to draw attention to the cache site.

properties.name: Manchester Sights - St John's Gardens
properties.gc_short_desc: A magnetic micro.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This Cache is located in one of Manchester’s many gardens; St John’s Gardens. This is the site of the former St John’s Church and Graveyard, built in 1769. On 28th April 1768, Edward Byrom laid the foundation stone for the church in memorial to his farther. Ecclesiastical Commissioners handed over the church to Manchester City Council in 1930 such that it be laid out as an open space for the benefit of the locale. The Church itself was demolished in 1931, though 2 stained glass windows were transferred to St Anne’s Church (St Anne’s Square) where they still remain. The gardens then became a city park. 

The park continues to provide a pleasant green space in the centre of Manchester and in 1998 was awarded a Green Flag Award for achieving the national standard for parks and green spaces. Currently present are formal lawns, flower and herbaceous bedding, ornamental planting, a well laid out footpath plan and plenty of seating and picnic areas. At the original entrance to St John’s church stands a central monument to the church and the 22000 people buried in its grounds. On this monument is also a panel dedicated to the memory of William Marsden who presided over the committee which obtained the Saturday Holiday for Manchester in 1843. 

The area has several trees and is surrounded by high rise buildings, therefore the GPS signal may be unreliable. Our given coordinates may not be precise so We’ve encrypted a very detailed description of how to get the cache in the hint. If you find the park, this hint should be enough to locate the cache. 

The area should be fairly low on muggles, but people do use this place to sit and relax. Also, people may be more likely to notice you looking around in a relaxed environment so please take care. 

Enjoy the park, and the Cache. DG + CS.

27/09/09 - Original cache was muggled and there were concerns over the safety of the original location due to reports of hypodermic needles. We’ve replaced the cache with a micro, and put it in what should be a safer location. YOU NO LONGER NEED TO ROOT IN ANY BUSHES. The original coordinates remain valid. The hint has been updated accordingly.

properties.name: Brighton Beach #3 (New)
properties.gc_long_desc:
A replacement for the original Brighton Beach #3 which had to be archived as it kept getting wet. New location so should be ok now.

You are looking for a 35mm film cannister hidden somewhere along Brighton beach front. As with the others, this is not at either road level. 

Please bring your own pen/pencil as the cache does not contain one.

Happy hunting!

properties.name: Vanguard Cache
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy cache placed off a bridleway, easy terrain, will be muddy when wet.
properties.gc_long_desc:
We placed this cache after we decided to move near to the Vangaurd Way - a little known but super bridleway that runs 68 miles from London to Seaford.

The cache is placed just off the Vanguard way at a junction with another footpath, sandwiched between two farms, Beeches and Dry Hill. Along the way you can see 'Dry Hill Fort' a 24 acre site dating back to the first century BC. Horse lovers with love this area too there is always plenty of horse riding going on along the bridelway, there are lots of animals to see around the farms. Bring your wellies/walking boots!

We hope you have fun and enjoy the scenery this area has to offer at 172 metres this is the highest point for some distance and therefore has some stunning views. 

The cache is a small click style tupperware, just big enough to hold a logbook, small pencil, standard cache instructions and a few finds. There is no designated parking nearby, you could try park along the B2028 as the vanguard way intersects this road or perhaps along Furnace Lane near to the A264.

properties.name: B&HM - The West Pier (was "West Pier's Bones")
properties.gc_name: B&HM - The West Pier (was "West Pier's Bones")
properties.gc_short_desc:
SHORT DESCRIPTION:
A simple off-set cache. (Only 1 stage.) You are looking for a small container. Stealth required. Difficulty rating due to muggles. 
Cache is 3 poles North, 1 pole East from ‘Crown of Thorns’. (NOT safe to swim in this location.)
properties.gc_long_desc:
LONG DESCRIPTION:
The West Pier is 1 of only 2 Grade 1 listed piers in the UK. Built in 1866 by Eugenius Birch, it subsequently suffered a number of fires on different occasions. The pier has been closed since 1975 and has had its fair share of incidents – even once being hit by a RAF Hawker Typhoon! 

There continue to be plans to renovate this pier and so it may once again rise from the ashes. You can find more information here… http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Pier 

Stealth is required as this is a very busy location. The area behind the pier is used by a variety of interesting market stalls and attracts many muggles. (The difficulty rating reflects this. It is NOT safe to swim in this location.)

So – to the cache:
You are looking for a small container. From the location coordinates you can see a figure wearing a ‘crown of thorns’. He is looking towards the cache but it is off-set. J says… “Look 3 pillars North and 1 East. There you will find a post at rest, waiting to rise again.” This pillar shelters the cache from muggles and tide.

There is only room for a log book, pencil and small swaps in this cache.

*** Congratulations Brightonrob - FTF 3rd June 2009 ***

properties.name: Brighton Showers
properties.gc_short_desc: SHORT DESCRIPTION: A traditional cache. You are looking for a 35mm film canister. Difficulty rating due to muggles.
properties.gc_long_desc:
LONG DESCRIPTION:
You are at a very busy part of Brighton’s seafront. There are lots of things to do here - including bungee bouncing, playing on fairground rides or even having a quick shower! You can lose some money in the modern arcade or have fun in the Penny Arcade museum instead... http://www.ukattraction.com/south-east-england/old-penny-arcade-museum.htm  Slightly further to the West are several art galleries, places to eat and even a free Fishermen’s Museum… http://www.visitbrighton.com/site/culture/brighton-fishing-museum-p56323  . 
Of course, to the East is the famous Palace Pier and the Sealife Centre. 

You are looking for a 35mm film canister. I wanted to place a large cache but hiding spaces are tricky here. There is only room for a log book, pencil and tiny swaps.
Stealth is required as this is a very busy location. 1 point added to difficulty rating due to muggles.

properties.name: Dry Hill Hike #19
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is a circular walk of about six miles, along public bridleways and footpaths, starting from Dormansland, and taking you up to Dry Hill, from where there are good views across to the North Downs.  Along the route you will find 21 traditional caches, most of which are micros, but there are 3 bigger ones for your swaps. There are no pencils in the micros, so remember to bring your own. Nearly all of the walk is on farm roads or hard paths, so most of it should be mud free, even in the middle of winter.

There is room to park a bit before #1,  in Ford Manor Road, which starts near The Plough Inn, at Dormansland. There is a bus stop for two bus routes outside the pub. Alternatively you could park at Marsh Green and start your circuit with #18.
