properties.name: No trains on this track
properties.gc_short_desc: Near the start of a pleasant walk along the old railway track (Linear Park) from Oldfield Park,
properties.gc_long_desc:
Near the start of a lovely walk along part of the Somerset and Dorset Railway Line which ran from Bath’s Green Park Station, now the site of Sainsbury’s, to Bournemouth. The line closed in 1966. 
This cache is in the Oldfield Park section of the park.
This cache is our first cache and we hope you enjoy searching for it. There are some goodies in the cache! Have fun!

properties.name: Foxx hunt 1#
properties.gc_short_desc: A 6 mile circular around the hamlets and villages of Turleigh, Winsley, Conkwell, Haugh and Great Ashley. The route starts at the outskirt of Bradford on Avon on the Winsley Road. All the route is on a road so easy for everyone but the lanes are narrow so take care. You can walk, run, take a pushchair or wheelchair and especially a car when its wet. There are a couple of inclines but nothing harsh. BRING A PEN! i forgot them.
properties.gc_long_desc:
I designed this when it was raining all day and Little Foxx was bored. If you drive the course then all locations of the caches are easy to get as they all have places to stop e.g. lay-by, wide roads etc. If you drive then all caches are about 1 to 2 arms length from the car door so you won't get too wet if done on a rainy day. The first 10 caches are small and will hold a book and small item like a bug or coin. 12 is a micro and 11 and 13 are regular boxes.
quite a few are around trees and was hard to get a true reading but the hints are a great help!  If you're FTF then you'll be happy as there is a TB or GC in 11 out of 13 boxes!

properties.name: SideTracked - Battle
properties.gc_short_desc:
We have Motorway Mayhem and we have A-Road Anarchy. Now a series for public transport users! SideTracked Caches are intended to provide quick cache-and-dashes at train stations.

There is no need to enter the station to access the cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Battle Railway Station is on the main Hastings to London (Southeastern) Line & serves the people of Battle & surrounding areas.

Battle is one of the most famous Military sites in the world. Just yards away the Battle of Hastings took place in 1066, thus giving its name to the whole town that is built on the site around five miles from Hastings. William the Conqueror came to the English shores from Normandy & defeated King Harold in 1066 & nearby there are several museums & commemorations of this amazing & significant event in English history.

The station was opened on 1st January 1852. The station building was designed by William Tress. It is grade II listed & considered to be one of the finest Gothic Style small stations in the country. Battle station consists of 2 platforms linked by a footbridge & a station building housing the ticket office & waiting room. The original sidings have now gone & now form part of the car park. The platforms are staggered & originally did not overlap as they do today, but were extended to cater for 8 car trains shortly after the 1986 electrification of the line.

For more information on SideTracked Caches please visit www.SideTrackedSeries.co.uk

If continuing the series you can follow the main road Right back up towards Battle Town to the Church.

The cache is a micro containing a logbook, pencil and certificates for the first 3 to find.

Please ensure that cache is fastened securely & replaced carefully, This is a popular area & stealth may be required.


* No swaps to be left in this cache please...It isn't big enough *

properties.name: Monarch Way South #9
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the ninth of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way heading South from Wick. Caches #8 and #9 lie between Upton Cheyney and Bitton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking at Bitton is available at Golden Valley Lane, N51.25.497 W002.27.414. The distance from Upton Cheyney to Bitton parking is just over ½ mile. 

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. This is a continuation of the Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court.  We will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the ambition of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.  Bitton church still bears the scars of Cromwell’s troops using it for target practice! 

This cache is not far from the road but wheel chairs will need to approach the it from the adjacent field to gain access; buggies may find the narrow footpath difficult.  

You do not need to deviate from the marked Monarch Way.  You are looking for a 35 mm film container.

properties.name: Monarch Way South #8
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the eighth of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way heading South from Wick. Caches #8 and #9 lie between Upton Cheyney and Bitton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking at Bitton is available at Golden Valley Lane, N51.25.497 W002.27.414. The distance from Upton Cheyney to Bitton parking is just over ½ mile. 

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. This is a continuation of the Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court.  We will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the ambition of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.  Bitton church still bears the scars of Cromwell’s troops using it for target practice! 

The cache is not accessible by wheel chairs; buggies will find it difficult because of the narrow footpaths, kissing gates and stiles.  

You do not need to deviate from the marked Monarch Way.  

You are looking for a medium screw top container.  Contents when placed were:

Log Book
Pencil
Lanyard
Angel Travel Bug

properties.name: The Yellow Banana Bridge
properties.gc_short_desc: Our second bridge cache, and an easy one this time..!
properties.gc_long_desc:
Nice easy cache'n'dash placed on another yellow bridge over the "new cut" in Bristol. You are looking for a magnetic 35mm film pot and you will need to bring your own pen just in case.

Parking is best in Clarence Road where there is usually plenty of room within 50 metres or so of the cache. The bridge is surprisingly busy at times with pedestrians and the cache site is overlooked by nearby flats so please use some discretion. Not really suitable for wheelchairs as there are steps at either end of the bridge.

properties.name: Bristol Curios #26
properties.gc_short_desc: "Get Back VK"
properties.gc_long_desc: So you think you know Bristol? This series will find out how much you know/can find out/are lucky enough to bump into. All the series are small or micro caches with a code letter and number inside. Please make a note of these for the final cache. All the caches can be found within wandering distance of the City Centre. Some are well known and easy, some can be googled and simply found, some are obscure and some are plain difficult with no WWW reference at all. the cache difficulty will let you know which category is which. The series will be released bit by bit to give everyone a chance to find the cache first. The instructions are simple and apply to each cache: Find the object pictured and then follow the instuctions to find the cache location. Have you missed these? Well here is another for you. New Clue Look backstage, it's all theatre. Find the mark, it is between premises numbered 28 and 26. Now find the plant name on the wall; how many letters? = * The cache can be found at: You may find THIS useful for this series of caches. It will be updated with the last 10 caches as they are published.      When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: A walk down Calton
properties.gc_short_desc: Calton Gardens in Bath. A small residential area which isn't busy often just outside the city centre. Big enough container for small items!
properties.gc_long_desc:
Just outside of Baths city centre a brief stroll up lyncombe hill.

The cache is a small, duck tape covered container big enough for small items. There is a pen and a log book in the cache. First to find will discover a travel bug. Please bring something to place in the cache.

properties.name: Monarch Way South #21
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a continuation of the Monarch Way series of caches. This stretch lies between Keynsham and Longwell Green. There is parking (and good pubs) at both ends of this stretch - the distance between is about 1 ¾ miles.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch.  There are several other caches along this part of the route including Chocatastic and some of the Longwell Green Mega series.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France. 

This cache is suitable for wheel chairs and buggies from the Longwell Green parking.

You do not need to deviate from the marked Monarch Way for this cache. You are looking for a magnetic nano container – bring your own writing instrument!

This cache is not suitable for wheel chairs and buggies due to the kissing gates along the route.

This cache is positioned a few feet from the marked Monarch Way. You are looking for a 35mm film container.

properties.name: Church Micro #611 St Bartholomew's Wick
properties.gc_short_desc:
A quick and easy find adjacent to St Bartholomew Church,
Wick
properties.gc_long_desc: St Bartholomew's Wick Wick is a modest yet pretty village that is situated on the A420 between Bristol and Bath. Many travellers will have passed through the ribbon-like development without realising the beauty that it hides. St Bartholomew's Church was consecrated on Wednesday 3rd April, 1850. The building was designed by William Butterworth - who also designed the parish church of Coalpit Heath, a few miles away, and part of Merton College Oxford to name just a few! If any body would like to expand to this series please do, I would just ask that you could let Sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication

properties.name: SideTracked - Hook(ed on caching) in Hampshire
properties.gc_name: SideTracked - Hook(ed on caching) in Hampshire
properties.gc_short_desc: Quick micro-cache by Hook station in Hampshire
properties.gc_long_desc: You're looking for 35mm film canister close to where my car has spent many a stationary day. The cache contains a log book and a pencil. FTF kudos to 37251. About Hook Station Trains run every half hour or so, between Basingstoke and London Waterloo. There's a wee coffee shop which operates most days in the morning. There's a ticket office which is also open most days in the morning. There's two short platforms (sit in the front 8 coaches), a footbridge, some locked loos, a very convenient Tesco and a couple of pubs and a decent Indian nearby. Parking is about £3.50 a day - but it shouldn't take you quite that long. About SideTracked We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy (cos there aren’t many Motorways in Wales!). But what about public transport users? SideTracked Caches are intended to provide quick Cache-and-dashes at Train Stations.It is hoped this idea will spread across the country in the same way as the MMs….but if hiding one PLEASE BE SENSIBLE and remember that in this day and age, public transport is under greater scrutiny than ever before, so, although these caches should be quick and easy grabs, PLEASE don’t place a Cache where it could cause alarm!!! For more information on SideTracked Caches, please visit SideTracked. Handicaching.com: View Ratings for GC1AW8M

properties.name: A Road Anarchy - A361 Cheese Hill
properties.gc_name: A Road Anarchy - A361 Cheese Hill
properties.gc_long_desc: A simple cache and dash in a layby on the A361 south-west of Frome near the hamlet of Marston Bigot.  In Summer the cache site is hidden from the main road by foilage.  In Winter a little be more stealth may be required.

properties.name: B&HM - Volks Railway
properties.gc_short_desc:
Part of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the Brighton and Hove Monopoly board. 

The cache is a 35mm film canister and is hidden near to the Volks railway. 

There is a very specific clue is given as this is a high muggle area. 

Please use uber uber uber stealth 

Cache rating due to muggles - especially in the summer.
properties.gc_long_desc: The Volks Railway was the first public electric railway in the world. Opened in 1883, the railway designed by Magnus Volks has been an institution in Brighton for well over a century. The railway runs along the seafront and carries passengers from the the main terminal at Madeira Drive close to the Pier all the way up the coast to the Marina and also stops at the Aquarium. The open carriaged trains are a great joy to travel in on a summers day.

properties.name: Westwood Trees Series : Sheeeeep
properties.gc_short_desc: Short series of 4 caches around village of Westwood near Trowbridge. This one is a cache and dash which could get muddy after long spells of rain.

properties.name: SideTracked - Southampton Central
properties.gc_short_desc: A cache located near to Southampton Central station, Hampshire.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Southampton Central station was opened as Southampton West in 1895, to replace the original Blechynden/West End station. It was enlarged in 1934-1935 (from two platforms to four), and became Southampton Central. Soon after the closure of Southampton Terminus station near the docks in 1966, the station was rebuilt in 1967, losing its clocktower which was replaced with an office block. At this point it was renamed Southampton, although in the early 1990s it was once again renamed Southampton Central.

If you do this cache by train, leave via the exit on platform 4, go up the steps opposite (slightly to the right) and follow the path onto Central Bridge, but cross the road here instead of going over the bridge itself.

You are looking for a keysafe container.

properties.name: Harnham Hunters
properties.gc_short_desc: Simple family multi-stage cache with famous views.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Park in the vicinity of N51.03.775 W001.48.551. Please be considerate to local residents.

From the parking head towards the Town Path.

1) How many Crowns? Answer = A

2) Continue along the Town Path and find the brass plaque to commemorate the bravery of Susan Harris on the BC of March 1966

3) Walk back to Middle Street, turn West and on the bridge you will see the numbers 1-D1

Now find the cache at:
N51 00A.9B2
W001 D8.C92

properties.name: Brislington Brook Walk 3 - Foss
properties.gc_short_desc:
A series of caches that lead from the River Avon up Brislington
Brook. The terrain is varied; paths and tracks wind their way along
the side of the brook and as you head further along, it can get a
bit muddy at times.
properties.gc_long_desc: Further in to St Annes Wood, it is clear that this was once a landscaped garden of sorts; there are little walls, bridges and steps, most of which have falled into disrepair. On your way up the valley, you may want to stop off at GC1R269 courtesy of the Bristol Blues Brothers - We decided to name this cache Foss after our pet rat, Fossli, who died just before we started to make the series. He was named after a hotel in Norway which was next to a beautiful and huge waterfall - Foss being Norweigan for waterfall (we think!) There are some little cascades near the cache which are the closest things to waterfalls we could find near by.

properties.name: Church Micro #692 – St Bart’s, Oldfield Park, Bath
properties.gc_name: Church Micro #692 – St Bart’s, Oldfield Park, Bath
properties.gc_short_desc:
A quick and easy cache adjacent to St Bart’s Church, Oldfield Park,
Bath. Although there is a terrain rating of 1.5, this is because of
the steep hill - strollers and wheelchairs should be able to manage
this with care.
properties.gc_long_desc: St Bart’s, Oldfield Park, Bath This area of Oldfield Park was threatened with development under the Beeching Plan in 1969. At that time, we lived in a house about 100 yards from this church. The Beeching Plan would have driven a motorway link from the M4 towards the south where this church stands and on stilts at bedroom level along Second Avenue. Not surprisingly, this was not a very popular plan! Thankfully it never came to bear and the area survives much as it did 40 years ago, except that it is now ‘Student-Land’ rather than the secluded residential district that it once was. Ah well, such is progress. You are looking for a 35mm film container

properties.name: Micro cache series #3
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located at the blaise castle estate, the terrain is easy and the cache is a simple find.
properties.gc_long_desc: This is cache number 3 of 5 in this micro cache series all located in the blaise castle estate, the micro is a tiny plastic screwtop container! The series takes you from one end of the estate to the other, all the micros are 0.2 - 0.5 miles from each other and are not too difficult to find and retrieve, happy hunting.

properties.name: Micro cache series #2
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located in the blaise castle estate, the terrain is no problem and the cache should be easy.
properties.gc_long_desc: This is cache number 2 of 5 in this micro cache series all located in the blaise castle estate, the micro is a tiny plastic screwtop container! The series takes you from one end of the estate to the other, all the micros are 0.2 - 0.5 miles from each other and are not too difficult to find and retrieve, happy hunting.

properties.name: St. Mary's Secret
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache will take you to an area of Bath even some residents
don't know about. The first part requires some detective work to
gather the information needed to calculate the location for the
second part.
properties.gc_long_desc: The coordinates are for a notice board in St Mary's Churchyard which is the starting place to find the answers to the questions below. Background This area was first opened in 1809 as an additional burial ground for St Mary's Church. It was closed in 1856 when it was full and it fell into disrepair until it was finally closed to the public in 1980 for safety reasons. In 2003 a group called the Friends of St Mary's was formed and they worked with Bath and North East Somerset Council to reopen the area. There is no physical cache in the churchyard. The final container is a short walk away in an area children may like. There is somewhere to obtain an ice-cream and a children's playground nearby. Questions The answers to the following questions can be found from the signs within the churchyard. There is no need to leave the paths and the questions follow the number order of the boards. How many letters in the last word of the 1st line of the 3rd paragraph of the information board? This is A. What was the birth year on the earliest known grave? This is BCDE. The great-granddaughter of a famous architect is buried here. How many letters are there in her name? This is F (first name) and G (surname). One grave has a link to Australia. Who's grave is it? Take the number of letters in each part of their name and this is H, I and J. How old were they when they died? This is KL. Coordinates The final cache is at: N51 (A-C)D.B(G-E)(I-J) W002 L(G-H).AF(K-H) Please note co-ordinates changed 16/08/08 If you would like more information the notice board gives details of two nearby places to obtain a free leaflet. Collect one on the way to the final location, it's interesting reading. All the walking for this cache is on paved or gravel paths or flat grass until the very last few feet and is suitable for pushchairs as long as you don't mind bumps. There is very limited parking near the start of this cache, most is restricted to residents only, however it is only a short walk from the middle of town where there are multiple car parks, park and ride bus stops and public transport links. The final location is under fairly heavy tree cover and you are looking for a small lock and lock type box and when placed it contained a few small swaps mainly aimed at younger geocachers and should have room for small travel bugs and coins. Please feel free to remove something to fit a trackable in if necessary. Please hide the box carefully again to help stop it going missing. This is my first multi-cache hide so please let me know what you think.

properties.name: B&HM - Churchill Square
properties.gc_short_desc: Part of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the Brighton and Hove Monopoly board.

properties.name: What the Dickens #2
properties.gc_short_desc:
A new easier and now quick offset cache to replace the old WTD's archived cache. Can be done in less than 5 minutes.It is an urban micro without pen.GPS reception is not great around here.
***Wheelchair friendly,but be careful of nearby traffic.***
properties.gc_long_desc:
The above coordinates will bring you to the entrance to a large red building that houses a bust of Mr Charles Dickens.(please take time to have a look as it's in the open courtyard ahead)It was here that he lived while completing his wonderful book,The Pickwick Papers in 1836.

************************************************************
So you now stand at the entrance to the building with a plaque to the left(L)and one to the right(R)and also the street(S)number above you too.

You will need to find the correct L,R or S numbers to work out the final coords.Here you go.

N  51-31.(L2-R3)(L3-S4)(R1) 
W 000-06.(R1+S6+S2)(L4-S2)(L3-S5)

properties.name: Time At The Bar - The Perseverance
properties.gc_name: Time At The Bar - The Perseverance
properties.gc_short_desc:
Located in one of the back streets of Winchester city centre.

Parking is for permit holders only from 08:00 to 18:00 Monday to Saturday.

Please be respectfull to the local residents.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Time At The Bar series will take you around the centre of Winchester to visit some of the gone and forgotten public houses that ceased trading long ago.

There will hopefully be 8 caches when the series is complete

The caches can all be done on a pleasant walk in one day in good weather or on their own.

If you would like to learn a little more about Winchesters forgotten history, have a go at GC1279A which is a mystry cache created by Juggles.


There were 5 pubs in  this street. The cache is near what was The Perseverance (now no. 87) and closed in 1956  The other pubs in the street were:

The White Horse closed 1974
The Sprtsmans Arms closed 1911
The Albert closed 1903
The Rose And Crown closed 1905

You are looking for a magnetic nano, unfortunately there really isn't any other choice of container of hide here. The difficulty is manly due to the bad GPS signal.

properties.name: SideTracked - Waterloo
properties.gc_short_desc: A nano, hidden by London Waterloo station.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The London and South Western Railway (L&SWR) opened the station on 11 July 1848 when its mainline was extended from Nine Elms. The unfulfilled intention was for a through station with services to the City.

The name on opening was 'Waterloo Bridge Station', from the nearby Waterloo Bridge across the Thames. In 1886 it officially became 'Waterloo Station' reflecting the long-standing common usage, even of some L&SWR timetables.
As the station grew it became increasingly ramshackle, a little-used railway line even crossed the main concourse on the level and passed through an archway in the station building to connect to the South Eastern Railway's smaller station, now Waterloo East, whose tracks lie perpendicular to those of Waterloo. Passengers were confused by the layout and by the two very close stations called 'Waterloo'. This complexity and confusion became the butt of jokes by writers and music hall comics. In Jerome K. Jerome's book Three Men in a Boat no one at Waterloo knows the wanted train's platform, departure time or destination.

Extensive reconstruction between 1900 and 1922 gave 21 platforms and a concourse nearly 800 feet (244 m) long. The main pedestrian entrance, the Victory Arch, serves as a memorial to company staff who were killed during the two world wars. Damage in World War II required considerable repair but entailed no great changes of layout.

On privatisation of British Rail in the 1990s, ownership and management of Waterloo passed to Railtrack, and subsequently to Network Rail.
Platforms 20 and 21 were lost as part of the site of Waterloo International railway station which from 1994 to 13 November 2007 was the London terminus of the Eurostar international services. Construction necessitated the removal of decorative masonry forming two arches from that side of the station, bearing the legend "Southern Railway". This was subsequently re-erected at the private Fawley Hill Museum of Sir William McAlpine, whose company built Waterloo International. Waterloo International closed when all Eurostar services transferred to St Pancras railway station with the opening of the second phase of "HS1", High Speed route 1, formerly known as the Channel Tunnel Rail Link or CTRL. The international platforms may be reinstated for some use by domestic services but substantial track-work would be needed to obtain any great advantage.

You are looking for a nano sized container, slightly out of view of the busiest parts of the station.

properties.name: Sidetracked Paddington
properties.gc_short_desc: About SideTracked SideTracked Caches are intended to provide quick Cache-and-dashes at Train Stations. For more information on SideTracked Caches, please visit SideTracked
properties.gc_long_desc: This is a 35mm film canister hidden near the entrance to London Paddington Station.London Paddington Station London Paddington station, also known as London Paddington, or just simply Paddington, is a major National Rail and London Underground station complex in the Paddington area near central London, England. It is the seventh busiest rail terminal in London. The site is a historic one, having served as the London terminus of the Great Western Railway and its successors since 1838. Much of the current mainline station dates back to 1854, and was designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel. The site was first served by Underground trains in 1863, and was the original western terminus of the Metropolitan Railway, the world's first underground railway. Despite its historic nature, and the need to preserve many of its features, the complex has recently been modernised, and has added a new role as the terminus of the dedicated Heathrow Express service to Heathrow Airport. The complex is in Travelcard Zone 1.Location The station complex is located in, alongside and under a long thin city block bounded across the front by Praed Street and to the rear by Bishop's Bridge Road, which crosses the throat of the main line station on the recently replaced Bishop's Bridge. The west side of the station is paralleled by Eastbourne Terrace, whilst the east side is constrained by the Paddington arm of the Grand Union Canal. The main line station is located in a shallow cutting, a fact that is obscured from the front by the frontal hotel building, but which can be clearly seen from the other three sides. The station's location is something of a back street one, with none of the bounding streets being major traffic thoroughfares. The surrounding area is largely residential, and contains many of London's hotels. Until recently there has been little in the way of office accommodation in the area, meaning that most of Paddington's commuter traffic interchanges between National Rail and the London Underground to reach its eventual destination in the West End or the City. However, recent redevelopment of nearby derelict railway and canal land, marketed as Paddington Waterside, has resulted in a number of new office complexes in the area.History The first station to open in the Paddington area was a temporary terminus for the Great Western Railway on the west side of Bishop's Bridge Road. The first GWR service from London to Taplow, near Maidenhead, began at Paddington in 1838. After the opening of the main station in 1854, this became the site of the goods depot. After years of dereliction, it is now being redeveloped as part of a mixed residential and business area called Paddington Waterside. The main Paddington station between Bishops Bridge Road and Praed Street was opened in 1854 and was designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel who was later commemorated by a statue on the station concourse (known as "The Lawn"), despite the fact that much of the architectural detailing was by his associate Matthew Digby Wyatt. The glazed roof is supported by wrought iron arches in three spans, respectively spanning 20.70 m (68 ft), 31.20 m (102 ft) and 21.30 m (70 ft). The roof is 213 m (699 ft) long, and a particular feature of the original roof spans is the presence of two transepts connecting the three spans. It is commonly believed that these were provided by Brunel to accommodate traversers to carry coaches between the tracks within the station. However, recent research, using early documents and photographs, does not seem to support this belief, and their actual purpose is unknown. The Great Western Hotel was built on Praed Street in front of the station in 1851-1854 by architect Philip Charles Hardwick, son of Philip Hardwick (designer of the Euston Arch). The station was substantially enlarged in 1906-1915 and a fourth span of 33 m (109 ft) was added on the north side, parallel to the others. The new span was built to a similar style to the original three spans, but the detailing is different and it does not possess the transepts of the earlier spans. On Armistice Day 1922, a memorial to the employees of the GWR who died during the First World War was unveiled by Viscount Churchill. The bronze memorial depicts a soldier reading a letter which was sculpted by Charles Sargeant Jagger and stands on platform 1. In 1961, the decomposing body of a male child was found in a case at the station. Paper stuffed into his mouth was the cause of death. His identity has never been discovered. A very early construction by Brunel was recently discovered immediately to the north of the station. A cast iron bridge carrying the Bishop's Bridge Road over the Paddington Arm of the Grand Union Canal was uncovered after removal of more recent brick cladding during the complete replacement of the adjacent bridge over the railway lines at the mouth of the station.The Station Today Today Paddington has 14 terminal platforms, numbered 1 to 14 from west to east. Platforms 1 to 8 are located below the original three spans of Brunel's 1854 train shed, whilst platforms 9 to 12 are located beneath the later fourth span. Platforms 13 and 14 are within the Metropolitan Railway's old Bishops Bridge station, immediately alongside the two through platforms, numbered 15 and 16, used by the Hammersmith & City Line of the London Underground. Platforms 6 and 7 are dedicated to the Heathrow Express, and platforms 13 and 14 can only be used by the 2 or 3 car Turbo trains used on local services. All the other platforms can be used by any of the station's train services. However in normal usage the tendency is for long distance trains to use the western platforms, and local trains (including Heathrow Connect) the eastern ones. The station concourse stretches across the head of platforms 1 to 12, underneath the London end of the four main train sheds. Platforms 13 and 14 can be reached directly from the country end of platform 12, or from the footbridge which crosses the country end of the station and gives access to all platforms. The area between the back of the Great Western Hotel and the station concourse is traditionally called The Lawn. It was originally unroofed and occupied by sidings, but was later built up to form part of the station's first pedestrian concourse. The Lawn has recently been reroofed and separated from the concourse by a glass screen wall. It is now surrounded by shops and cafes on several levels.

properties.name: Time At The Bar - The Market Inn
properties.gc_name: Time At The Bar - The Market Inn
properties.gc_short_desc: Located in Winchester city centre. There is a small car park behind the libuary, a multi story in Tower Street or use the park and ride.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Located in Winchester city centre. Vey mugglesum so use stelth. Parking is in the city center car parks or use the park and ride. 

The Time At The Bar series will take you around the centre of Winchester to visit some of the gone and forgotten public houses that ceased trading long ago. 

The caches can all be done on a pleasant walk in one day in good weather or on their own.


The Theatre Royal is where The Market hotel was, incorpareting The Market Inn. This was later changed to the Teatre bar and then the Theatre Pub. Since the refurbishment of the theatre in 1996 it has been used soley for patrons of the theatre.

The library was until 1936 the Corn Exchange and has since been extended and refurbished, most recently in 2007.

properties.name: BBB 8  – Theme from Rawhide
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is track eight of eleven caches celebrating “The Music from the Soundtrack” album released on June 20, 1980 by the Blues Brothers Band,
Each Bristol based cache is located at a place that has links to either the song title or the lyric content.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Track 8 - Theme from Rawhide" (Tiomkin) – 2:37
Elwood and Jake and the Blues Brothers Band

Rawhide is a Western song written by Ned Washington (lyrics) and composed by Dimitri Tiomkin in 1958. It was originally recorded by Frankie Laine. The song was used as the theme to Rawhide, the western television series that ran on CBS from 1959 to 1966. The song is about the job of drover on a cattle drive.
The Cache is a 35mm film container situated within sight of Tanners Thomas Ware & Sons Ltd 

“Thomas Ware & Sons Limited was incorporated in 1890 and since then has specialised in producing top quality vegetable tanned sole leather. We have survived the decline of the British leather tanning industry from over 70 tanners during the 1950's to under 5 at the present time by concentrating on quality and service. All our leather is produced in the traditional way with a minimum of 6 weeks in tanning pits which over the years has been found to be the best method of production of sole leather which wears superbly and withstands the vagaries of the British weather. “

It is also on a frequently used cycle path – Rawhide !

Enjoy the cache

* Congratulations to The Evil Poles for being FTF *

properties.name: BBB 7  – Think
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is track seven of eleven caches celebrating “The Music from the Soundtrack” album released on June 20, 1980 by the Blues Brothers Band,
Each Bristol based cache is located at a place that has links to either the song title or the lyric content.


The cache has a difficulty rating of 4 because super ninja stealth is needed
properties.gc_long_desc:
Track 7 Think" (White, Franklin) – 3:13

Aretha Franklin and the Blues Brothers with backing vocals by Brenda Corbett, Margaret Branch and Carolyn Franklin (real-life sister of Aretha) and Jake and Elwood

Think is the name of a hit single released by American R&B/soul musician Aretha Franklin in 1968, from her Aretha Now album. The song, a feminist anthem, reached #7 on Billboard Pop Singles Chart, becoming Aretha's seventh Top 10 hit in the United States. The song also reached #1 on the magazine's Black Singles Chart, becoming Aretha's sixth single to top that particular chart. The song was written by Franklin and Ted White.

The Cache is a 35mm film container situated near a thinking establishment.

The University of Bristol is a university in Bristol, England.It received its Royal Charter in 1909,although its predecessor institution, University College, Bristol, had been in existence since 1876.It is one of the original "red brick" universities. Bristol ranks as one of the top 20 universities in the United Kingdom according to most published league tables and receives more applications per place than any other British University.The University has an annual turnover of £260m and is the largest independent employer in Bristol.

Enjoy the cache

* Congratulations to Wonx, The Evil Poles and Babblings Kate for being Joint  FTF *

properties.name: Channel 4
properties.gc_short_desc: Channel Four
properties.gc_long_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by the Police. Please
avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if
challenged, explain about geocaching**

  The Channel 4 Headquarters was built in 1991-94 to the
design of the Richard Rogers Partnership. It uses glass,
pewter-grey aluminium and an exposed structural steelwork. It has
an external glass cladding with bands of sun-screen mesh. There is
an antenna tipped service tower which supports cute-looking wall
climber lifts, with banks of air coolant panels above.
  There is a very pleasant garden which is open to the
public at the building which does not seem to be well known. I had
thought of placing the cache there but there were warnings the
garden is patrolled by security guards so I decided to place the
cache else where.
The original cache has now disappeared and I have put a replacement
cache at a location very close to Channel 4. The cache is now a
small grey nano ( Please bring your own pen or pencil. Please be
careful when opening the cache NOT to lose the small disk magnet at
the bottom of the cache!

properties.name: Where are all the apples?
properties.gc_short_desc: Abbey Orchard Street
properties.gc_long_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about geocaching**
Cache has been replaced by a nano. Please Do Not Lose the small
magnet inthe Nano.
.
THANKS.
 

   The cache is now a nano with a magnet inside the
container. It contains a log book . Please bring your own pen or
pencil There was a badge for the first to find.
  The history of this area is surprising. It started of
as a marshy island the ancient Isle of Thorns or Thorny Island. It
was formed by rivulets of the River Tyburn, which entered the
Thames near the lowest point where it could be forded from the
north bank at low tide. It was described in a purported charter of
King Offa in 785, which is kept in the Westminster Abbey muniments,
as a "terrible place"
  The name Westminster is a contraction of the words
"West Monastery". However over the next 300 years, the monks of the
Abbey tamed the brambles, until by the time of Edward the Confessor
it was "A delightful place, surrounded by fertile land and green
fields". This area was the orchard for Westminster Abbey.
  Unfortunately it suffered a fall from grace and was
referred to as the Devil's Acre. Well into the 19th century this
area, was one of the country's worst pits of crime and despair. To
quote a local historian, "Into the rookery were crammed every
manner of lawbreaker and every vice, festering amid squalor which
shocked all who had courage enough to enter". The Devil's Acre was
described in Hollingshead's 'Ragged London' and Thomas Beame's 'The
Rookeries of London'.
  One of the reasons Victoria Street was built in the
1850's was to clear this area. As you look round the area today you
can consider how much the area has changed over the last 1000 years
and whether its present state as a modern street covered with
tarmac and concrete is an improvement over the Abbey Orchard which
gave this street its name.

properties.name: Renaissance Art at the National Gallery, London
properties.gc_name: Renaissance Art at the National Gallery, London
properties.gc_short_desc:
A puzzle cache that requires the seeker to visit the National
Gallery in London (some of the research can be done on the web, but
that wouldn't be as much fun!). If you get stuck, try asking one of
the gallery staff for help or go to
http://www.nationalgalleryimages.co.uk/ and try searching for
certain keywords.
properties.gc_long_desc: I adore Renaissance art, so couldn't resist setting up a puzzle cache in order to get people looking at some paintings! The National Gallery in London houses one of the greatest collections of Western European painting in the world. These pictures belong to the public and entrance to see them is free. The National Gallery is open daily from 10am until 6pm, apart from on Wednesdays when it remains open until 9pm. It is closed on 1 January and 24-26 December. This cache requires the seeker to visit the early and Renaissance art collections, and hunt for certain paintings based on the clues below. Using information taken from these paintings, it will be possible to work out the co-ords for the final cache (the given co-ords are just for the National Gallery itself!). There are a lot of paintings to look at, so I'm only making you look round two sections of the gallery! Paintings from c1250 to 1500 are in the Sainsbury Wing, and those from 1500 to 1600 are in the main gallery. It's probably a good idea to look around the earlier paintings first, entering the gallery at the Sainsbury Wing entrance. The final cache is now a 35mm film canister and is hidden a short walk (about a third of a mile) away. Sadly the larger clip-down boxes kept going missing; hopefully this one will last a bit longer. GOOD LUCK! The Clues! Before 1500 (Sainsbury Wing) A. "He got me to sit showing my best side, in my favourite yellow dress that matches my hair. The blue background’s nice. I do hope my husband likes it” What year was this picture bought by the National Gallery? (Third digit of year minus 3 = A) B. “Love has conquered all, as it always does….there he lies, God of War, tired out from love. These little satyrs are amusing, I like to watch them play with his armour.” How many satyrs are in this painting by a famous Florentine artist? (Number of satyrs minus 4 = B) C. “Giovanni wanted a picture of us together so I wore my posh green dress. Not sure about it though; think it makes me look pregnant. He had to have that blinking dog in the picture too.....nasty yappy little thing, I could kick it, really I could.” What year was this picture painted? (fourth digit of year = C) D. This diptych (two-panelled) painting is of an English king being presented to the Virgin and Child by his patron saint and a couple of other saints. The painting is named after the house in Wiltshire where it resided before coming to the National Gallery. How many angels are in the painting? (number of angels minus 11 = D) E. This large horsey battle scene is one of three panels that show incidents from the same battle; the other two are in the Louvre in Paris and the Uffizi in Florence. What year was the battle that is depicted here? (third digit of year plus 2 = E) F. This saint was out hunting one day when he came across a stag with a crucifix hanging between its antlers, and promptly converted to Christianity. The painting showing this conversion has lots of other lovely animals in it too, including dogs, hares and storks, which shine out gently against the dark background, but no-one knows why the scroll at the bottom has been left blank. What year did the gallery acquire this painting? (second digit of year minus 8 = F) 1500 - 1600 (main gallery) G. This is a large double portrait of two very clever French chaps who have been painted with various items to show off just how educated and intelligent they are. There’s a distorted image at the bottom of the painting which suddenly jumps out at you as a memento mori (reminder of death) if you stand on the far right of it. ((Lefthand friend’s age – righthand friend’s age) plus 4 = G) H. This is a portrait of a female saint who is usually associated with a Bonfire Night firework here in the UK. She’s resting on her attribute (that’s the thing that identifies which saint she is....!) and wears a very natty outfit in blue, yellow, pinky-red and green. (Spoiler clue for kids: the guy who painted her has the same name as one of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles!) What year did the painter of this picture die? (third digit of year minus 1 = H) I. “Having my portrait painted is so BORING! Ugh, I would rather be playing…..at least he’s given me this armillary sphere thingy to mess about with.” What year was this painting bought? (fourth digit of acquisition year minus 5 = I) J. This painting of about 1575 by a Venetian artist shows how the Milky Way was formed, according to myth. How many stars have been created here? (number of stars minus 2 = J Now that you have worked out all of the clues, substitute your answers for the letters in this grid and go out and seek the final cache! The final cache is a short walk away. Co-ords are within 100ft because of buildings but the spoiler clue should help a lot. The cache location is definitely quieter at weekends than weekdays, but is available 24/7 and I've made it quite easy to grab quickly if you know where you're looking; it is situated somewhere that won't look too suspicious if you happen to be standing there. Please take your own pencil in case the one in the cache goes missing, and be extremely careful to make sure that the cache is rehidden from general view. Thank you! UPDATE: 9th Aril 2009 - the cache has been replaced with a 35mm film canister by Currykev - many thanks! Note for wheelchair users: I've done my best to make this cache as accessible as possible for you. The National Gallery has excellent access for wheelchairs. The Sainsbury Wing Entrance has level access from Trafalgar Square with wide swing doors, one internal automatic door and two revolving doors. There are large lifts with low-level controls giving access to Level 2. This entrance is most convenient for taxis and set down and pick up, and closest to the parking bays. For more information, please see http://www.nationalgallery.org.uk/plan/access/default.htm It is possible to get next to the final cache in a wheelchair, but if you find it difficult leaning down to reach something near the ground then you might like to ask a geo-friend to help (besides it's a nice excuse for a meeting to tour round the gallery, have lunch etc if you're in London for the day! ) Following very helpful comments from other cachers, I have decided against including a link to Puzzlechecker for this cache, as it could allow people to skip doing the research for the last couple of paintings and simply guess the co-ords instead. However, I'm happy if people want to email me to check they have the correct co-ords if they need to - I can be contacted through my profile. MASSIVE thanks to CurryKev for replacing the cache and helping me to get this online again :-)

properties.name: The Smallest(?) Royal Park
properties.gc_short_desc: A members' only micro starting in London's smallest Royal Park and ending up outside a spooky place Bring your stealth kit This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching. Cachers are requested to try to avoid acting in a suspicious or furtive manner when searching for a geocache or when retrieving/replacing the cache.
properties.gc_long_desc: The Smallest(?) Royal Park This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged, explain about geocaching  Cachers are requested to try to avoid acting in a suspicious or furtive manner, when searching for or replacing the cache. You should only look for the final cache from ***a park area*** and very definitely not from Abington St or Millbank (the main road along the edge of the Embankment).   A fairly simple offset cache that starts off next to The Palace of Westminster in Victoria Tower Gardens and ends up somewhere green near by. Surprisingly this area is a Royal Park and not maintained by the City of Westminster. The coordinates are for Rodin’s Burghers of Calais monument, there will be some information to be gathered here before we move to the interesting structure at the other end of the gardens for the rest of the info prior to heading off for the final cache. You could encounter a spook or two around here – click here to find out why. The cache 35mm film canister (magnetic). Bring a pencil / pen. The GPS coverage here not bad – 24’ accuracy reported when I placed it. Once you’ve found it: *** make sure it goes back where you found it. This is so it will be there for those who come after you and not found by those who shouldn't  - the black tape indicates where the internal magnet is *** As with a lot of urban caches you’ll need to be sensitive of local residents, builders, gardeners and passers by. Be aware of potential watchers (whether in homes or offices or via security cameras). However, if you are approached by either Police or Security Officers avoid acting suspiciously and explain what you are doing. Avoid doing the actual cache discovery during the weekday commute or lunch hour. Very quiet in the evening or weekend. The parks area open from around 8am weekdays (9am weekends and public holidays) and close around dusk (around 16:30 in winter, around 21:00 in summer). Buggy and wheelchair friendly. A wheel chair user would need an assistant to do the final cache recovery. Directions Step 1 Have a look at the monument and the descriptive plaque: How many Burghers?  This will be A Which Eddie? This will be BStep 2 N 51° 29.767 W 00° 07.488 Walk over to the other structure in the park. This is the Buxton Memorial Fountain. Before looking for the answers to the questions have a look at the detail of the mosaics etc. Now, have a look at the descriptive plaque to find out why it was constructed and to answer a couple of simple questions: The fountain started life located in Parliament Square. It was relocated here in 19C7 After restoration it was unveiled again in time to celebrate the 200th Anniversary of the 1807 Act abolishing the transatlantic slave trade. The unveiling took place 2D March 2007.   Final N 51° 29.6WX W 00° 07.4YZ   W = A X = B – 3 Y = C + 4 Z = D - 5   Remember what I said about only operating from *** a Park area ***. So, plug in the coordinates, take a bearing, work out the approximate distance, put the GPSr in your pocket and head over there. Have a good look around before you start looking with the GPSr to establish where the watchers are – I suggest admiring the River view will help in this.   As a sanity check: If you loose sight of the river or walk for more than 10 mins, something has gone wrong       You can check your answers for this puzzle on Geochecker.com.

properties.name: Flonopoly Cache 18 - Bow Street
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to FireLanterns-onopoly, or Flonopoly for short. A cache
series inspired by (but in no way associated with or endorsed by!)
the board game of a similar(ish) name. This series of caches will
take you to 28 locations around the streets of London, some well
known, some not so well known, but all of them made famous by that
great board name we all know and love. 
The caches are mostly all 35mm and magnetic, containing log book
only, so bring a pen. Within each cache you will also find a small
Flonopoly logo, with a number on the back. Take careful note of
this number (and make sure you get the logo the right way up - turn
it round, not upside down - don't mix up those 6's and 9's!) - as
you will need all of these if you want to go for Flonopoly - Jail
and ultimatley Flonopoly - GO. If you make it all the way round
these London Streets, there will be a small Flonopoly reward as a
mark of respect for covering a lot of miles. Also if this is your
first Flonopoly cache, please take note of the date and time of
your first find - and when/if you do them all, the date and time of
your last, so when you log Flonopoly GO you can tell us how long it
took you to do the series !
Flonopoly Cache 18 - Bow Street, a thoroughfare in Covent
Garden, was once home to Bow Street Magistrates Court, a famous
London court building that tried (amongst others) The Kray twins.
You'll also see the newly refurbished Royal Opera House close to
the cache location. Oliver Cromwell was also a famous resident of
the street in 1645.
The cache - in a busy area again - take care of muggles.

properties.name: Thomas Coram (formally St George's Fields)
properties.gc_short_desc: A small black 35 mm container at chest height not using magnets.Log only.NEW EASIER 24 HOUR LOCATION
properties.gc_long_desc:
The cache is hidden in a little known area of Bloomsbury.
The sea captain Thomas Coram (c. 1668 – March 29, 1751) was born in Lyme Regis, Dorset, UK. He spent much of his early life at sea and in the American colonies. From 1694 to 1705, he operated a ship building business at Taunton, Massachusetts. He afterwards became a successful merchant in London and, in 1732, a trustee of James Oglethorpe’s Georgia colony. In 1735 he sponsored a colony in Nova Scotia for unemployed artisans. As a great philanthropist Coram was appalled by the many abandoned, homeless children living in the streets of London. On October 17, 1739 he obtained a Royal Charter granted by George II establishing a "hospital for the maintenance and education of exposed and deserted young children."

In 1742-1745, the Foundling Hospital was erected in Lamb's Conduit Fields, Bloomsbury. It is said to be the world's first incorporated charity. William Hogarth was among the first governors of the hospital. He painted a famous portrait of Thomas Coram (1740; now Foundling Museum, London; reproduced in stipple by William Nutter [1754-1802] for R. Cribb in 1796), and, together with some of his fellow artists, decorated the Governors' Court Room. He contributed paintings for the benefit of the Foundation, and the Foundling Hospital became the first art gallery open to the public.

properties.name: Monarch Way South #5
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the fifth of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way from Wick following the course of the River Boyd towards Upton Cheyney.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ords for parking at Court Farm are N51.27.021 W002.26.279. Limited roadside parking is available in Upton Cheyney but there is little opportunity for parking along the route due to the narrow country lanes. The distance from the Court Farm parking to Upton Cheyney is about 2 ½ miles. 

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch and several points in between.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. We have now started a Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court and will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the intention of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.

This cache is accessible from the road and is thus wheelchair and buggy friendly.  You are looking for a screw top beaker.

Note: If accessing  this cache from cache #4, the path is not very distinct.  After you cross the double stile, head diagonally across the field (there were friendly horses there when we set the cache).  There is a kissing gate and then a step stile next to the farm buildings which brings you out on the road opposite Chilcott House.

properties.gc_short_desc: This is the fourth of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way from Wick following the course of the River Boyd towards Upton Cheyney.

There is a kissing gate and then a step stile next to the farm buildings which brings you out on the road opposite Chilcott House.

You are looking for a small container.  Take the opportunity to enjoy the location of the cache – we think it is fantastic.  Beware that the stone bridge could be slippery if wet.

The container is a little unconventional.  For those that are really stumped, there is a spoiler picture attached of it out in the open.

properties.name: High society
properties.gc_short_desc: In London on a famous Landmark easy walk
properties.gc_long_desc:
You need to read the information off the gold plaques and convert
the letters to numbers to glean where to look for the cache.
It’s not to far away from here so you will probably complete
the cache in less than half an hour. First you have to work out
where you will find the plaques so I think some clues are needed.
Obviously you should be in London and looking for a location that
has stood in its current incarnation since the 6 August 1889 and to
the best of my knowledge it has the only official right hand drive
road in the country. There is a theatre and a garden named after
this place. Hopefully you will now know where to look if not look
at the spoiler part 1 for help Waypoint reference North 51-30-ABC
West 000-07-DEF
Anne Hyde was secretly married here 3rd September 16A0 A=
The plaque that commemorates the reopening of the theatre was on
the B9th July 1993 B=
On the plaque that mentions Geoffrey Chaucer a king died Cth April
1364 C=
John of Gaunt was here from 1362 until 138D D=
This site was bestowed “In vico qui vacato la straunde
February 12th 12E6 E=
many beautiful foreign ladies were brought here 1F47 F=
So now you found all the numbers well done Follow the road up from
the waypoint and the cache will be on your left

properties.name: B&HM - Malborough Place
properties.gc_short_desc: Part of a series of caches around Brighton and Hove based on the Brighton and Hove Monopoly board.
properties.gc_long_desc:
You are looking for a film canister hidden around this area. Beware for plenty of muggle traffic and things, so stealth is needed 

Have given it dangerous area attribute as lots of nearby traffic!

Please be careful when retrieving and replacing this cache as it is hidden in plain sight. When replacing, please make sure the Lid goes inwards and that the bottom is facing the world...you'll see why!

properties.name: SideTracked - Preston Park Station
properties.gc_short_desc: A SideTracked cache by Preston Park station in Brighton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
And now for the Wikepedia bit:

The London Brighton and South Coast Railway opened a new station named Preston, on 1 November 1869 to serve the growing parish of Preston, then north of the Brighton boundary. The station was enlarged and remodelled to its present design in 1879 during the construction of the spur line from the main line to Hove and the West Sussex coast line. The station was then renamed Preston Park although the nearby Preston Park did not exist until 1883.

In 1881 the notorious railway murderer Percy Lefroy Mapleton alighted at the station after having killed Isaac Frederick Gold and dumped his body in Balcombe tunnel. Lovely.

**********************The Cache********************

You are looking for a 35mm film canister placed on Woodside Avenue overlooking the Train Station. Parking is available all around the area so it should not be an issue. While placing the cache the GPS was playing up, so I would reccomend reading the clue in case the co-ords are out.

properties.name: Monarch Way South #1
properties.gc_short_desc: This is the first of a series of caches located along the Monarch Way from Wick following the course of the River Boyd towards Upton Cheyney.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ords for parking at Court Farm are N51.27.021 W002.26.279.  Limited roadside parking is available in Upton Cheyney but there is little opportunity for parking along the route due to the narrow country lanes.  The distance from the Court Farm parking to Upton Cheyney is about 2 ½ miles.  

Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch and several points in between.

We have now started a Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court and will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the intention of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.

This is a nice easy walk through pleasant fields.  There are stiles to negotiate and the footpaths are quite narrow which makes this neither wheelchair nor buggy friendly.  You are looking for a small lock’n’lock container.

properties.name: Battle Windmill
properties.gc_short_desc:
Use footpath to see this lovely Windmill, close to the open area known Kingsmead.

The cache is a painted small pot.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This lovely windmill is privately owned and there is no public access. There is a wonderful view of it from the ajoining area known as Kingsmead.

An open meadow close to the area known as Malfosse, where its thought King Harolds army gathered on the eve of the Battle of Hastings on the 14th Oct 1066. At the bottom of the incline is an area where many Normans were killed during the Battle.

There is also an old tri point in this area.

properties.name: Shiver my timbers
properties.gc_short_desc:
First cache we've hidden.  Placed by our youngest son. Trying to be as simple as possible for other children to find without too much difficulty. 

Hidden in the heart of Aspley Wood.  Ample road side parking (along Woodside Rd) good footpaths, & easy terrain.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Aspley Guise is a small village on the western fringe of Bedfordshire. The village has a population of approximatley 2,400 in just under 1,000 dwellings.
Aspley Guise has its origins in 1086, listed in the Domesday Book with 25 families. The name of Aspley Guise is believed to be derived from Aspen-Leigh meaning clearing in the aspen (alder) woods and from the de Guise family who owned much of the land during Tudor times and are best known through Mary de Guise, mother of Mary Queen of Scots.

Aspley Wood would have been an important source of timber and wood for centuries.  Fragments of fossilised wood from the underlying Greensand found in Aspley Wood led to stories of a 'petrifying spring' that turned wood to stone.  Two of the woodland's footpaths run past Mermaid's Pond, which is listed under that name in a Bedford Estate management book in 1791.

The cache is a camoed 0.9L snaplock container.

Original contents:
- Log Book
- Pen
- MumsTaxi TB.
- Green toy ring.
- Wooden figure.

FTF credit to The Other Stu 16/05/2010.

properties.name: Jack the Ripper 1 - Mary Ann Nichols
properties.gc_name: Jack the Ripper 1 - Mary Ann Nichols
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache is one of seven set in the East End of London tracking
the murder sites of Jack the Ripper's victims. It is designed to be
a walking tour as well as a hunt. Only cache 7 is a real
microcache, you have to visit caches 1-6 first to collect the
clues. The walk is flat and on paved streets. To do all the caches
in a single day would require a 2.5 mile walk.
properties.gc_long_desc: There are five caches numbered in chronological order of the murders with a possible sixth victim being cache number 6. You can find the caches in sequence but to avoid wear and tear on your feet, I suggest doing the caches in the order of: 1, 3, 6, 4, 5, 2 and 7. To get to Jack’s hideaway at Cache No 7 you have to visit each of the six caches to find the clues to the final co-ordinates. The caches are designed to be done independently but could be finished in a single visit. On Sundays the area is especially lively with popular markets at Columbia Road, Brick Lane, Petticoat Lane and Spitalfields. Whitechapel and Spitalfields are safe to visit during the day, but those of a nervous or crime cautious disposition should give the hunt a miss after dark. There is no doubt, however, that a hunt for Jack the Ripper is more creepy and atmospheric after the sun has gone down... Prosperity may be changing the character of the East End yet the melancholy air left by years of crime and poverty remains as you wander its streets. Victim 1: Mary Ann Nichols - Bucks Row Mary Ann Nichols is generally believed to be the first of Jack the Ripper’s victims. She was murdered on 31 August 1888. On the night of August 30, the weather was stormy with thunder, flashes of lightning and fierce rain. The sky was turned red by two dock fires. Mary was a prostitute and an alcoholic. She was last seen by Emily Holland at 2.30 am walking east on Whitechapel Road "looking for trade". She was discovered dead about 2 hours later in a street called Buck‘s Row. The 1 September 1888 edition of The East London Observer reported her death as follows:- "It was just after half-past four PC Neale discovered lying on the pavement the form of a woman. She was lying on her back, with hands that were tightly clenched, and presenting altogether the appearance of one who had died in the greatest agony. She was wearing a little black straw bonnet minus either ribbons or trimmings, battered almost out of recognition, and placed at the back of her head. Around her was a cloak - a threadbare garment that had once been red, but was now a dull, dirty colour. The expression on the face was a deeply painful one, and was evidently the result of an agonizing death. The gash across the neck was situated very slightly above the breastbone; it was at least six inches in length, over an inch in width, and was clean cut. The lower portion of the body, however, presented the most sickening spectacle of all. Commencing from the lower portion of the abdomen, a terrible gash extended nearly as far as the diaphragm - a gash from which the bowels protruded..." The name of Buck’s Row has been changed to avoid notoriety while the street itself has changed almost beyond recognition - it is no longer the "drab, mean little cobbled street" described by pundits in the 1920s. The only building that still survives from the 1880s is the Board School. Question: How many panels are in the red door of the building next to the wall (and on the same side of the street) where Mary Nichols was found slumped, her feet pointing toward it? ANSWER = A Check out the spoiler photo to see a picture of the actual murder site.

properties.name: Luke, it's here!
properties.gc_short_desc: An offset set in Canford Park and named after Toddler WP, who loves the recently refurbished playground.  Should you run the risk of being run over by an excited three year old on an orange balance bike, please say "hello"!
properties.gc_long_desc:
Canford Park was opened as a municipal park in 1874 with land bought from Rev H.A. Daniel by Clifton Urban Sanitary Society.  The park was absorbed into the city by the corporation in 1904.

There is a bowling green used by the Canford Bowling Club and the park has eight tennis courts, four of which are proposed to be floodlit.  There are also two football pitches and the summer sees the occasional Gaelic football match.

The co-ordinates are for a Grade 2 listed Victorian feature that was moved to Canford Park when the War Memorial in the centre of Westbury-on-Trym replaced it in 1920.  It was restored in the mid 1990s but was later vandalised and has now been cut off.

The Chariman of the Committee's surname should be converted into numbers according to the key pad on your mobile phone (e.g. a, b or c = 2).  The surname is ABCDEFG.

The cache is to be found at:  N 51° 29.(E+1)(B-1)(D+2) W 002° 3A.CG(F-3)

It is a small micro/large nano with room for a log only so please bring a pencil and be warned that the park is popular so a little stealth may be required.

This cache location is wheelchair accessible but the container is not.

Please note that the cache location had to be changed on 28.6.09 due to damage at the original hide.  There is no reason that damage should be caused at the new location so please be careful.

properties.name: Hole In One (Henbury)
properties.gc_short_desc:
THE CACHE IS NOT AT THE GIVEN CO-ORDINATES. Even if we could think
of a way of hiding a cache in the middle of the 10th green, we
doubt the members would approve!
properties.gc_long_desc: For a long time now Mrs WP has been looking to find a way to get Mr WP to go for a walk that didn't involve a golf club. She tried different avenues including glorious ridge walks, stunning valleys, gentle rambles with a pub at the end and spring time strolls through cherry orchards but none of these seemed to provide the same attraction as a frustrating walk up Coombe Hill with a heavy golf bag on his shoulder. When we moved to the Bristol suburbs, Mr WP had the opportunity for a short roadside walk to the nearest golf club and Mrs WP thought that maybe she was going to see more of Mr WP during the golf season given the shorter journey required. We explored our new surroundings and fought our way up past Cherry Orchards to take in the views of Westbury-on-Trym but still Mr WP would not give up his favourite golf club. Then last Christmas we received a GPS receiver and without any warning the whole family got the geocaching bug but particularly Mr WP. He can now be seen on any day of the week going for a walk and quite possibly there will not be a bunker or golf hole in sight. We have now explored many parts of Bristol that we have never been to before including many cycle paths (being very pushchair friendly) and many great parks to keep Toddler WP happy. One such place we had never visited before were the nearby cottages at Blaise Hamlet but the hunt for a geocaching clue took us there. We also do a lot of roadside cache and dashes. They may not be the most interesting caches but this has given us a fail safe way of getting both little WPs to sleep in the car! Mrs WP knows that Mr WP has got the bug badly because on a day off with both the little WPs at nursery on Henbury Hill we decided to spend the day goecaching and the golf club did not get a mention all day! Mrs WP would like to give her heart felt thanks to all those fellow cachers out there who take the time to place new treasure. The family is having so much fun and it doesn’t involve a golf club! Although the information needed to solve the puzzle is available on the golf course, it is also available via the internet - just not on the obvious website! There is also no need to set foot on the golf course to retrieve the small micro/large nano cache, which is just off a nearby public footpath. Other than dodging vegetation, access to the cache is flat from the footpath. Please be gentle with the container and just unscrew the lid rather than pulling it out. There is only room for the log book so please bring a pencil.! Good Luck. (In case you haven't already worked it out, the hint should help with both the puzzle and the find. That said, if you correctly interpret the puzzle clue, you are advised to do finalise the puzzle using an internet search rather than obtaining the physical representation as that has been changed and no longer includes the vital info...) You can check your answers for this puzzle on Geochecker.com.

properties.name: Suspension
properties.gc_short_desc:
The Clifton Suspension Bridge, spans the Avon Gorge, and has become one of the symbols of the city of Bristol. For almost 150 years this Grade I listed structure has attracted visitors from all over the world.
The bridge was designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel in 1831, but not completed until 1864, 5 years after his death. The long delays were caused by political unrest and lack of funds.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The 85 ft (26 m) tall Leigh Woods tower stands atop a 110 ft (33 m) red sandstone clad abutment. It is not a solid structure & contains 12 vaulted chambers up to 35 ft (11 m) high, linked by shafts and tunnels. Although similar in size, the bridge towers are not identical in construction, the Clifton tower having side cut-outs, the Leigh tower more pointed arches. Brunel's original plan proposed they be topped with then-fashionable sphinxes, but the ornaments were never constructed.

The bridge has three independent wrought iron chains per side, from which the bridge deck is suspended by eighty-one matching vertical wrought iron rods ranging from 65 ft (20 m) at the ends to 3 ft (0.9 m) in the centre. Composed of numerous parallel rows of eyebars connected by bolts, the chains are anchored in tunnels in the rocks 60 ft (17 m) below ground level at the side of the gorge. The deck was originally laid with wooden planking, later covered with asphalt.

Roller mounted "saddles" are employed at the top of each tower to allow movement of the chains when loads pass over the bridge. Though their total travel is minuscule, their ability to absorb forces created by chain deflection prevents damage to both tower and chain.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Hidden in busy part of Bristol, on a sunny day there can be hundreds of people around. The terrain is pretty easy going, but the actual cache can't be reached by wheelchairs or pushchairs. 

WARNING !!!  - recent cache finders have reported a Wasp / Hornet nest in close proximity to the cache position on site. PLEASE TAKE CARE when retrieving / replacing the cache. 
[Pixie Troll;  20.08.2010]

The other main thing to remember - Beware of the muggles they are watching from all directions!

This cache is a 0.5L container covered in camouflage tape. The original inventory includes: 
Notebook & pen
Clifton suspension bridge GC
K9 TB
Glass dog
Ladybird YoYo
some key-rings, pegs and pencils 

This is Pixie Troll's first cache, so any comments would be welcome!

properties.name: Monarch Way South #17
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is continuation of the caches located along the Monarch Way heading South from Wick. This stretch lies between Bitton and Keynsham. 

Parking at Bitton is available at Golden Valley Lane, N51.25.497 W002.27.414. Parking at Keynsham, N 51° 25.150 W 002° 29.404 the distance between is just less than 2 miles.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Because this follows the Monarch Way, it is not a circular walk but can be approached from either end of the indicated stretch.

We have created 24 Monarch Way caches heading North from Wick to Horton. This series has now been taken further by OOK the Librarian to Hawkesbury Upton, with more caches to come in due course. This is a continuation of the Southern series of caches from our original beginnings at Wick Court.  We will continue these until it gets beyond our reasonable range when we will seek another cacher willing to take the series further with the ambition of covering the whole Monarch Way in time.

Monarch Way is the 615 mile route used by King Charles II after the Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham from where he made his escape to France.  Bitton church still bears the scars of Cromwell’s troops using it for target practice! 

This cache is suitable for wheel chairs and buggies approaching from the Keynsham end.

You do not need to deviate from the marked Monarch Way.  You are looking for a small screw top container.  

Initial contents
Log Book
Pencil
Geopenguin GC

After this cache, follow the path along the river to the Lock Keeper Inn and the posted Keynsham parking.

properties.name: Great Strides
properties.gc_long_desc: As Rob Brydon would say.........It's just a bit of fun As the means to solve this puzzle was given out at the monthly meet without my permission. It is no longer warrants a 2* rating. For those not at the meeting, I wouldn't want you to miss out. Here is the link to solve it. http://between0and1.wordpress.com/2008/05/14/update-a-classic-trouser-semaphore/
