properties.name: Hamadryad Park
properties.gc_long_desc:
To the west of the Cardiff Bay shops & restaurants lies Hamadryad Park.  Away from the hustle and bustle, chill out and watch the boats & birds on the river.

This is a micro cache - please bring your own pen/pencil.

properties.name: Sidetracked - Westbury
properties.gc_short_desc: About SideTracked: We have Motorway Mayhem. We have A-Road Anarchy. But what about public transport users? SideTracked caches are intended to provide quick cache and dashes at train stations.
properties.gc_long_desc: You are looking for a 35mm film canister.

properties.name: CUBA Phone Box Cache #8
properties.gc_short_desc: The eighth of a small series of caches celebrating the iconic RedPhone Box. It's not quite a TARDIS, but it's getting close. Thesecaches will be placed in (or on) phone boxes around Bath and theeastern side of Bristol, across the Counties that Used to be Avon(CUBA).There is no pen in the cache.

properties.name: LQ:BRISTOL - surprise IKB views
properties.gc_long_desc:
Simple cache and dash but with views to die for, both here and
nearby. Just watch your footing in wet weather.

properties.name: Have a Heart #1
properties.gc_short_desc: In woodland to one side of fairway  -  take care crossing fairway, though both tee and green are clearly visible
properties.gc_long_desc:
Combine this cache with the Golden Cache for a good cardio-vascular workout !  Do it by itself for a simple Cache 'n Dash

The co-ordinates above are simply to show you the general area.
From the parking, access to the cache is via a kissing gate.
The approach to the cache is fairly good level mown grass, but not a defined or gravel path.  The last five metres are in the rough.

The cache is at a huge tree - a spooky freaky type tree straight out of Harry Potter !

Green Petling tube (green plastic blank for moulding drinks bottles) with yellow cap.

Please be careful when replacing to ensure it remains well hidden.

NB   The club have asked that searchers stay on the marked paths and remain aware of the need to be careful when passing near tees and crossing fairways so as to cause minimum interference to golfers. If they experience any problems, the club could cancel their permission to site the cache on their property.

This cache was placed with the kind permission of the National Trust and the  Shirehampton Park Golf Club.

properties.name: The Yellow Suspension Bridge
properties.gc_short_desc: A small micro cache placed on the St Philips Greenway.
properties.gc_long_desc:
There is a small park close to the cache. Parking can be at the
Avon Meads shopping centre (N51° 26.765 W002° 33.759), or Edward
Street off the A4 Bath road (N51° 26.596 W002° 33.795). If parking
in Edward Street then this cache should be wheelchair
accessible.
The cache only contains a small log book so bring your own pen!
The cache is accessible from the bridge, YOU DO NOT NEED TO GO
UNDER THE BRIDGE OR CLIMB ON IT'S STRUCTURE! Please be sure to
replace this cache just as you found it to keep it properly
hidden.
This is the first in a series of 'Evil' bridge caches. It may be
harder than the 2.5 stars indicated, we will see how you all get
on.
This cache can be done in conjunction with Avon Haven (GC1E40V)
and Bolt out of the Blue (GC1DVX7) to make a nice walk along the
Greenway.

properties.name: Bristol Curios #24
properties.gc_short_desc: "Get Back VK"
properties.gc_long_desc: So you think you know Bristol? This series will find out how much you know/can find out/are lucky enough to bump into. All the series are small or micro caches with a code letter and number inside. Please make a note of these for the final cache. All the caches can be found within wandering distance of the City Centre. Some are well known and easy, some can be googled and simply found, some are obscure and some are plain difficult with no WWW reference at all. the cache difficulty will let you know which category is which. The series will be released bit by bit to give everyone a chance to find the cache first. The instructions are simple and apply to each cache: Find the object pictured and then follow the instuctions to find the cache location. I think this is a fairly tricky nano. Simple to work out but difficult to find. How many characters are beneath the main commercial name=? New Clue: Not far from here, and check the attributes. The cache can be found at: You may find THIS useful for this series of caches. It will be updated with the last few caches as they are published.      When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: Mendleson's Ancient Tree Micro
properties.gc_short_desc:
Fairly easy micro in the Barbican Centre. 
Entry from Barbican station is the closest.
properties.gc_long_desc: Mendleson’s Ancient Tree Micro What is the link between an area that is sometimes called a ‘concrete waste land’ and the composer Felix Mendleson Bartholdy? Well, come and do this cache and find out. Once you’ve found the cache look by the John Trundle Court sign to find out why there is a 500 year old beech tree up here. You’ll also find that far from being a waste land is it surprisingly green. Look in particular at the hidden garden between John Trundle and Bryon Courts. There are other caches around here including Short back and sides (GC143RE), Museum of London (GC143RQ) and Last Delivery (London) (GCGBGB). The Museum of London itself is always an excellent place to visit both for locals and visitors from further afield – if you haven’t been, drop in – at weekends there are frequently live activities that both children and adults will appreciate. The cache 35mm film canister with magnet on the side. Bring a pencil / pen. The GPS coverage here not a good as I excepted it to be – 44’ accuracy reported when I placed it. Once you’ve found it: *** make sure it goes back where you found it. This is so it will be there for those who come after you and not found by those who shouldn't *** As with a lot of urban caches you’ll need to be sensitive of local residents, gardeners and passers by. Be aware of potential watchers whether in homes (lots of windows here) or offices or via security cameras. Only one security camera that I noticed, although that seems to be dedicated to something other than the cache area. However, if you are approached by either Police or Security Officers avoid acting suspiciously and explain what you are doing. Avoid doing the actual cache discovery during the weekday commute or lunch hour. Generally quiet off peak, in the evening and weekend. Buggy and wheelchair friendly.

properties.name: Museum of London
properties.gc_short_desc: Small(micro) member only cache outside The Musuem of London
properties.gc_long_desc: Museum of London Adjacent to the Museum of London. Click on the link for more info on the The Museum of London. The MoL is a great place for everybody, especially at weekends when there are often live demonstrations and events – so please think about visiting rather than doing a cache and dash. Nearby in the garden you’ll see an interesting wooden construction, have a look at it and find out a bit more about Roman ingenuity. Adjacent to the Museum you’ll see the John Wesley Conversion Place Memorial (the Wesley House, Museum and Chapel is about 15 mins walk away, some info here). We are on the walkway rather than at ground level. As with a lot of urban caches you’ll need to be sensitive of local residents, gardeners and passers by on the walk way. Be aware of potential watchers (whether in homes or offices or via security cameras). However, if you are approached by either Police or Security Officers avoid acting suspiciously and explain what you are doing. Have a look around the Museum once you’re done. Buggy and Wheelchair friendly. The cache Just a micro (35mm film canister with a special means of attraction) these days - original larger cache went AWOL. The GPS coverage here is a bit variable due to the buildings – look out along London Wall (the dual carriageway below you) and you’ll be in the right vicinity. Once you’ve found it: *** *** make sure it goes back where you found it and it is aatached properly ***

properties.name: Way Down West-Henry Pollard
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Welcome to North Devon.

      A series of 109 caches,over 20 miles,set on public footpaths and quiet country lanes.

      All directions given,assume that you are following the caches in numeric order.

      For parking in West Down see Way Down West 1(GC24XHH),in Blakewell see Way Down West 56(GC24Y69)
      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

      It will be muddy in places.There are two steep inclines after caches 34 and 61.

      You will be lucky not to meet sheep,cows and horses.

      All smallish caches contain coins to swop.

      Eight waymarks are included to assist you.

      This extra cache has been placed to fill a gap created by a rerouting of the series.Henry Pollard is my newest grandson born on the 7th April 2010.He weighed in at 11 lbs,his mum,Kay ate a lot of roast potatoes it must be said.

      Cache is a 35mm canister.

properties.name: Follow the path of least resistance
properties.gc_name: Follow the path of least resistance
properties.gc_short_desc:
At last, an easy puzzle (that's not a hint). The co-ords above are
NOT at the cache but suitable parking.
properties.gc_long_desc: GREEN BROWN BLACK ORANGE VIOLET ORANGE RED BLACK BLACK BROWN RED ORANGE BROWN RED BLACK You can check your answers for this puzzle on Geochecker.com. THIS CACHE IS NOT VISITED OFTEN PLEASE DO NOT LEAVE TRAVEL BUGS OR TRAVEL COINS IN HERE

properties.name: A tribute to Gullivers Monumental Journey
properties.gc_name: A tribute to Gullivers Monumental Journey
properties.gc_long_desc: This Country Park with its outstanding views lies close to the Old English Capital of Winchester. If the weather is nice there are some great spots for a picnic in the area. The cache is situated up an easy to walk incline from the Car Park.  Just before you reach the cache you will see the Monument on your left from which there are some brilliant views which on a good day stretch as far as the edge of the New Forest. Also follow the path a few yards past the cache and look to your right for more stunning views. This cache is placed in memory of our first placed cache “Monumental Journey” which was placed on the 8th September 2001, sadly the cache was muggled in May 2007.   This new one is placed very close to the original location. This was the cache that Gulliver Bear started his monumental journey from.   Gullivers story can be  found HERE.    Gulliver was the inspiration for our signature item T&J Bears CLICK HERE The cache is in an ammo box. Please, please ensure that it is well covered before you leave because this is a popular place for kids to play.

properties.name: City Trail - Height Limit
properties.gc_short_desc: A 35mm film canister, close to the very busy ring road, on the slip road out of the car park. There is a multi storey car park very close to the cache. Park next to the cache at your own risk as it is double yellow lines, please use discretion.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Salisbury has some strict planning rules concerning height especially for the city centre. This cache highlights that fact and what effect it could have if the height limit of new buildings was ever relaxed. 
From what I can remember the maximum building height is about 45 feet.

properties.name: Grovely Ring No2
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Ring  is a series of  24 caches of various sizes and difficulty. This was the 2nd cache we placed in this series. The 7 mile walk, which could last well over 4 hours, will take you around the Western end of Grovely woods enjoying a variety of scenery from dense woodland to open high elevation downland with spectacular views over the Wiltshire countryside. Success with the Ring will give you the opportunity to visit the Grovely Golden Cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking place co-ordinated are provided below, these allow the easiest walk and are convenient for the Grovely Golden Cache. However, don’t feel constrained to start here, access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock. If you want an even longer walk, there are tracks up to Grovely from Wilton at Water Ditchampton and from Wishford with a bit of a climb. 

When walking this series each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A, B, C, D and E., which should help locate the Grovely Golden Cache. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although very unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start your walk: see Golden Cache listing for details of the short cut. Failing that depending on your chosen route, if it’s not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds to gather the values; good luck.

Be warned comfortable footwear and walking boots are advisable when attempting the Ring. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All caches are placed on or within a few feet of public footpaths, bridleways, etc. You will not need to walk deep into the woods, remember game shooting starts on Oct 1st and it would be unadvisible for anyone to be wandering about well off the paths at such times. You should not need to climb fences or even stiles, although you will be required to open and close a couple of field gates; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions, so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

Warning:  please do not poke your hands down into any hollow tree stumps in the vicinity of this cache; someone has placed a coil of [}:)] [}:)] barbwire [}:)] [}:)] inside a hollow stump close to the track [V][V][V].

Please hide cache continers well, hopefully as you find them and remember to note the value of that letter A, B, C, D & E.

properties.name: Grovely Ring No1
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Ring  is a series of  24 caches of various sizes and difficulty. This was the 1st cache we placed in the series. The 7 mile walk, which could last well over 4 hours, will take you around the Western end of Grovely woods enjoying a variety of scenery from dense woodland to open high elevation downland with spectacular views over the Wiltshire countryside. Success with the Ring will give you the opportunity to visit the Grovely Golden Cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking place co-ordinates are provided below, these allow the easiest walk and are convenient for the Grovely Golden Cache. However, don’t feel constrained to start here, access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock. If you want an even longer walk, there are tracks up to Grovely from Wilton at Water Ditchampton and from Wishford with a bit of a climb. 

When walking this series each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A, B, C, D and E, which should help locate the Grovely Golden Cache. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although very unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start your walk: see Golden Cache listing for details of the short cut. Failing that depending on your chosen route, if it’s not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds to gather the values; good luck.

Be warned comfortable footwear and walking boots are advisable when attempting the Ring. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All caches are placed on or within a few feet of public footpaths, bridleways, etc. You will not need to walk deep into the woods, remember game shooting starts on Oct 1st and it would be unadvisible for anyone to be wandering about well off the paths at such times. You should not need to climb fences or even stiles, although you will be required to open and close a couple of field gates; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions, so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

Please hide the cache container well, hopefully as you find it and remember to note the value of that letter A, B, C, D & E.

properties.name: Two Parts Rum, One Part Sea!
properties.gc_name: Two Parts Rum, One Part Sea!
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy find for landlubbers everywhere, ahoy! Bring a scribe of your own
properties.gc_long_desc: Start at the sign that reads 'South Parks Road' cross cautiously with the scurvy men of green and red towards the arched door of 'St Johns College' (not inside the college). As you face the arched doorway turn right and follow the wall towards Museum Road. If you reach the plaque "4H25" you've gone too far!

properties.name: City Trail - Intercity
properties.gc_short_desc:
City Trail caches have been placed near to some historical or interesting spot in Salisbury. If you have young children keep an eye on them as this cache is quite close to the stream, but it might be an idea to bring some bread which might come in useful for our floating feathered friends, thanks to a cachers log for the suggestion!
The cache is in the Central Car Park, so plenty of parking available.
properties.gc_long_desc:
I called this cache Intercity because at this point there was once a branch railway line that ran over this bridge to the market square and the heart of the city. The line has long gone but I do have a map of Salisbury dated 1901 and its clearly marked on that. The line ended where the library now stands.

The cache is a 35mm film container hidden as close as I could get to the bridge. There is a log and a tiny pencil.

properties.name: Abbey Green
properties.gc_short_desc:
The site of many a hanging over the years, the tree in the centre of the green was used for public hangings of crooks, felons and criminals.

The cache is accessable to all but there are many streets in the area with cobbled stones under foot.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Located a short walk from The Bath Abbey and the Roman Baths, this is a nice quiet corner of the city with a good bit of shade on a sunny day provided by the huge tree in the middle of the green.  There are some quaint little shops around this quarter and a pleasant public house to refresh you after a hard day of caching or shopping!

The cache is a magnetic 35mm film canister and you'll have to be very discreet with lots of muggles around!

Due to the Abbey Green being a 'Scheduled Ancient Monument', the cache is placed just outside Abbey Green on one of the approaching roads, but I hope you still enjoy the Abbey Green area itself.  

Please bring a pen/pencil to complete the log.


FTF goes to Jenny&James - well done!

properties.name: Morphin' Around Too
properties.gc_long_desc:
We decided to archive the predecessor to this one (GCW9AX Morphin' Around) as access to it became problematic.
A footpath that lead straight across a recently ploughed field. Another that went through a field that had an electric fence put up all round it. 
Not to mention the muck spreading sprinkler. 
Seems the farmer didnt like people enjoying his little bit of the countryside.

So we've moved the cache, now named Morphin' Around Too, to somewhere altogether much nicer and much more accessible ...
a nice little spot up on the Ridgeway between Marlborough and Broad Hinton.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Suggested parking for the cache is the car park at N51 28.287 W001 48.926.
Its just a short walk along the Ridgeway to the cache - so you could cache & dash if you wanted. 
But do stay a little while and enjoy the views. 

Theres a few caches up along this stretch of the Ridgeway already. 
Why not bag a few on the nice walk over to Barbury Castle.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The cache, a medium sized plastic container, takes its name from its unusual contents.
Inside, along with a log book, is some plasticine, which when the (old) cache was first placed was 
moulded to the shape of Morph, who older Cachers will remember from the Take Hart series on TV. Theres a photo in the cache gallery.

The idea is, when you visit, you roll your sleeves up and re-shape the plasticine.
Add something to the existing shape or mould it into something completely different.
Something to reflect your caching name perhaps?
Its up to you.
Just take a photo of your handy work and upload it to the gallery when you log your visit here.
Photos seem to come out in best focus on our camera by using the macro setting - which is a little picture of a tulip.

If the plasticine is a little hard it just needs a couple of minutes in some warm hands. :-)

Theres not much room in the cache for many swaps, only really room for the plasticine and a log book and maybe a few small TBs.

Happy Morphin!
Oh, and dont forget your camera!

properties.name: Wild West(end)
properties.gc_short_desc:
A 35 mm canister hidden within sight of a central london bird
sanctuary.
properties.gc_long_desc: We found this place just by chance, walking through the park. A flash of color flew by. We stopped and looked closer. A flock of parrots, great spotted woodpeckers, colorful finches and starlings all flying about, chattering away. Here in the middle of London. "Bird records for Kensington Gardens go back more than a hundred years and 178 species have so far been identified. Green Woodpeckers nest in the Gardens - a rare occurrence in Central London." Click here for more. And Wild Life For All. So whether you are a birder or not, on a good day, this is quite a sight to behold. Even on a not so good day, there is wildlife abound. Note: Please replace camo as found. It's been muggled a couple of times so let's keep it well hid. Thanks

properties.name: Grovely's Witchcraft Ring No14
properties.gc_short_desc: This is number 14 of the Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring which is a series of 24 caches, placed in a figure of eight, of various sizes and difficult to complement the Grovely Series which is a little further to the West.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Full details of the Witchcraft stories are included on the Govely’s Witchcraft Ring Listing No1 (GC1XF72) and No 10 (GC1XFDM). 

Details of parking places, access and other information are also provided on those listings. This figure of eight ring is about 9 miles long and does keep to the Roman road, public paths, bridleways, etc. At times, for those that do the full ring, the going is very hard as there are some hills to climb and descend. Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging.

You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village.

Please note The Wobbly Club have advised: To drive past any of the Blue Entrance Signs into the woods saying "No Unauthorized Vehicle Beyond This Point". it is a requirement to have a permit readily issued by the Wilton Estate Office for those with a disability as well as a Disabled Persons' European Parking Permit. What the penalty is for not having a permit I do not know but better to be safe than sorry. For those of able body there would be no need anyway as you can enjoy the walks and park your car in permitted areas just before those blue signs.

properties.name: Littlecombe Ring #5
properties.gc_short_desc:
A pleasant 2 to 3 hour amble along the tops of Littlecombe and
Tytherington Hills to enjoy the open landscape of the West
Wiltshire Downs.
properties.gc_long_desc: This 5 mile circular trail has been set to start and finish in the Wylye Valley village of Sutton Veny. There are no clues or bonus to collect so you can enjoy the series of 21 caches in any order. Please note you will have a slight climb whichever way round you do the trail but don’t be put off, as once you are at the top the terrain is quite level and easy going. You will hopefully be successful in finding a variety of caches ranging from very small micro containers to the usual small clip lock style boxes containing a few small swaps. Although the clip lock boxes contained pencils, at time of placing, we do ask you to bring along a writing implement for signing the micro logs. Enjoy

properties.name: Fast Food
properties.gc_short_desc: An easy cache and dash.
properties.gc_long_desc: This micro can be found in a small retail park.  Accessible 24/7 with free parking.

properties.name: Grovely Witchcraft Ring No6
properties.gc_short_desc:

properties.name: Hotwells Junction (reincarnated)
properties.gc_short_desc: Quick and easy
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache is located in a location
      previously used by a now defunct cache. The location is
      however really quite good, too good to be left alone in fact.
      Check out the plaque for historical information and the
      tribute.

properties.name: The Star of Bath
properties.gc_short_desc: Cache marking the site of the Bath Paragon, simple bison cache, containing log book only.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The cache is sited outside one of bath's oldest hostelries, and the entrance was moved to it's current location as the Paragon was being built, to allow workers to collect their pay from inside.

The Star Inn nearby is one of Bath's oldest public houses, first licensed in 1760, and is a fantastic Bath drinking house, with wood paneling, open fires and good ales. Highly recommended quick cache 'n' pint for a cold winters day !.

Warning - the spoiler will completely give it away 

Thanks to the Snowfox for helping set this one, she's an inspiration!.

properties.name: Church Micro 437 - Sutton Veny
properties.gc_short_desc:
The Church of St John the Evangelist, Sutton Veny is a relatively
new church as churches go. The foundation stone was laid on 27 May
1866 after the decision to build a new church to replace the Church
of St Leonard that had fallen beyond repair. Financed by the
Everett family, the building was completed inside two years with
the consecration ceremony conducted on the 16 April 1868.
properties.gc_long_desc: The church is built of Frome stone with Box ground stone dressings. Interestingly it was not built on the usual east-west axis but slightly off set so that the east window aligns with the sunrise at the winter solstice. In fact this continues through the following 6 days which include Christmas Day and the 27 December, the festival of St John the Evangelist. A significant feature of the churchyard is the Commonwealth War Memorial which faces 170 war graves. Many of the graves are of Australian and New Zealand service personnel who were based in the Wylye Valley after the Great War and who had survived the conflicts on the western front only to be cut down by the devastating influenza epidemic that hit this country in 1918/1919. You are looking for a 35mm film canister hidden just outside the church grounds. If any body would like to expand to this series please do, I would just ask that you could let Sadexploration know first so he can keep track of the Church numbers and names to avoid duplication.

properties.name: LQ:Bristol - Clifton Down
properties.gc_long_desc:
There is an Iron Age hill fort at Clifton Camp on Observatory Hill
on the down, and there are remnants of an Iron Age or Roman field
system between Ladies Mile and Bristol Zoo. The Roman road from
Bath to Sea Mills crossed the Downs near Stoke Road, and a short
length is visible as a slightly raised grassy bank.
In the Middle Ages Clifton Down was the commons of pasture for the
manor of Clifton. In 1676 and 1686 the manor of Clifton was
purchased by the Society of Merchant Venturers. During the 18th
century Clifton became a fashionable summer spa, and Clifton Down
was increasingly used for recreation. There were also lead mines in
the 18th century, which account for the bumpy surface in the area
by Upper Belgrave Road known as the Dumps. A gibbet was erected
opposite the end of Gallows Acre Lane (now known as Pembroke
Road)
By the mid 19th century Clifton Down ceased to be used for grazing.
Clifton became a desirable place to live, and large houses were
built close to Clifton Down. Bristol Corporation became concerned
at the threat to this public amenity, and in 1861 promoted an Act
of Parliament, under which the Society of Merchant Venturers
undertook to secure Clifton Down for public enjoyment free of
charge.
Since 1861 Clifton Down has been managed, with Durdham Down, by the
Downs Committee, a joint committee of the Society of Merchant
Venturers and Bristol Corporation, which owns Durdham Down. The
committee appoints a Downs Ranger to oversee the Downs.

properties.gc_short_desc: A pleasant 2 to 3 hour amble along the tops of Littlecombe and Tytherington Hills to enjoy the open landscape of the West Wiltshire Downs.
properties.gc_long_desc:

Please note you will have a slight climb whichever way round you do the trail but don’t be put off, as once you are at the top the terrain is quite level and easy going.

Although the clip lock boxes contained pencils, at time of placing, we do ask you to bring along a writing implement for signing the micro logs.

Enjoy

properties.name: A Horse Named "Beware Chalk Pit"
properties.gc_short_desc:
A beautiful spot with tremendous views over the Winchester countryside.

Read all about the horse with the strange name at the monument.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is in an area well known to Hampshire cachers, but this cache is close to the highest point. 

This cache is in the same place as my original one here, and has been resurected at the specific request of Allthebridges.  It is now well secured and animal proof (please bring a pen). 

The reviewers state that they are unable to un-archive the original, so this has a slightly different name, a new GC number and may therefore be claimed again should those of you who have been before wish to return.

properties.name: Compton All Saints Cache
properties.gc_short_desc:
PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS CACHE CANNOT BE
      ACCESSED THROUGH THE SCHOOL GROUNDS.
The cache has been placed by the children of class 2 with the help
of Debbie from THE BRAMBLERS.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Class 2 took great delight in searching for a hiding place for
their latest cache. It is hidden quite close to the school, but can
only be accessed through the church grounds.
The cache is an ammo box and it has been filled with items brought
in by the children themselves. Some were a little reluctant to part
with their gifts and one item had to be retrieved shortly after the
cache had been placed! It is only a very short and level walk with easy access, so
shouldn't cause any problems.

properties.name: CORTON RING 01
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The caches are set in such a way that they can be completed in one 12 mile round walk or attempted in two separate 6 mile circular walks.  Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

There is a parking space near to CORTON RING 01 at N51°09.831 W002°05.737, but this is very limited.  Alternative parking can be found at N51°09.555 W002°03.359 (near to CORTON RING 34) or N51°09.664 W002 03.426 (near to CORTON RING 35).

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: Victorian Suspense
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a small traditional cache with enough room for small trade items and/or travelbugs.  Watch out for muggles when retrieving and replacing as they can arrive at the scene quickly and silently!
Enjoy....
properties.gc_long_desc:
A Victorian structure designed by James Dredge, a brewer from Bath.  Located only a short stroll from Royal Victoria Park and the Royal Crescent.

"In 1836, James Dredge of Bath patented his ‘taper principle,’ in which he proposed that both suspension chains of reducing thickness and inclined wedges be used in the construction of suspension bridges. The advantages of Dredge’s system were threefold. The decreasing thickness of the chains links reduced, in turn, the weight of the bridge, the amount of the wrought iron required to erect it and the time required for its construction. Dredge went on to build some 50 such bridges..." (Colin Rynne, Industrial Ireland 1750-1930: An Archaeology (Cork: The Collins Press, 2006), 335)

properties.name: Bored of shopping?
properties.gc_short_desc: Short cache offering great views of Pulteney Weir in the centre of Bath. Great one to do if you are bored of following the wife round shopping. Should only take about 10 mins and is suitable for pushchairs. Please try and access cache without being seen by others as it is hidden in a fairly busy and overlooked spot.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Bored of shopping? Tired of the wife nagging? Then this is the cache for you!! Make your excuses and head off to the posted coordinates where you will find a plaque on a wall. I will warn you you may well be a bit out as it was a nightmare to mark. On the plaque there is a date. Put the date in the following format  - a/b/cdef and solve the following to find the cache position:

N51 22. d a+b 0
W002 21. b-a 0 e

Again please try and access cache without being seen if possible.The best way is to sit on the wall and pretend to tie your shoelace. You are looking for a 35mm film canister.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: UC15 (Lewinsky's little foible)
properties.gc_short_desc: A small addition to the University Challenge series to enhance our understanding of the phrase 'The Yanks are coming'
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Yanks are coming???
Well for many years the Yanks have been coming and in fact came.
Through The Rhodes Scholarships, (created by Cecil John Rhodes), citizens of the USA have walked between these portals on a regular basis. The scholarships have been awarded to applicants annually since 1902 by the Rhodes Trust, on the basis of academic qualities as well as those of character. They provide the successful candidate with two years of study at the University of Oxford, possibly extended for a third year. When Rhodes died in 1902, his will stipulated that the greater part of his fortune was to go towards the establishment of a scholarship fund. The scholarships, originally worth £300, would reward those applicants who exhibited worthy qualities of intellect, character, and physical ability.
Approximately 90 Scholars are selected worldwide each year of which just over a third come from the USA.
Famous American scholars include:- Edwin Hubble, James William Fulbright, Robert Jemison Van de Graaff, Kris Kristofferson, and of course; 
William Jefferson Clinton

To find the final co-ords, how many (A) Ionic topped columns form the loggia to Rhodes House?  Put (A) into the formula below and a short walk will lead you there.
N51 45.3(A-1)3   W001 15.3((4!/(3!x2!))0

Should you not know what the ! stands for in the equation I am sure a bit of googling on mathematical notation may help. You never know when you might need it again!

properties.name: ACT #01 - Off we go!
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a series of 34 caches, plus a bonus cache and 4 other
existing caches that follows the 12.5 mile "Aldbourne Circular
National Trail" on the north Wiltshire Downs, just a short distance
from Swindon. There are some stunning views and it is suitable for
walkers, horse riders and cyclists and can be completed in a single
day.
properties.gc_long_desc: Although I have seen plenty of cyclists all the way along the route it does look very hard going, but if there are any geohorse riders this could be ideal for you! The route mainly follows broad tracks through rolling downland countryside rich in history from prehistoric to recent times. Livestock is present on parts of the trial - more info below. GO PREPAREDIt's a long walk so go prepared with the right gear, food and water, I'd recommend long trousers all year for the long grass. There a couple of steepish climbs, one at the start and one about half way around. Apart from that you will then be walking along the top of the hills with glorious views, but it can be windy and cold. I'd also advise gloves, hawthorn bushes are sharp! DOG OWNERS Being a dog owner I want to warn you about the livestock that is present on a few short sections, this is not to put you off in any way, just to make you aware in advance. At the time of setting the caches there were sheep leading to cache 1, and then again leading to cache 15. There were also cows leading to cache 21, with "Bull in Field" warning sign. There are no caches in this field and it can be avoided with a small detour. There were also cows in the field between cache 32 & 33, these can not be avoided although I have only seen them on one occasion. Otherwise it is mainly crop farmland and dogs will have a great time running around. You will also need to walk along the relatively busy B4192 before starting the 2nd part of the traill, the grass verge will enable safe walking but take care nevertheless. CACHES The caches are intended to be quick & easy finds but there are a few that may be tricky, there is a variety of containers to keep you guessing. The hints should help you find any difficult ones, so don't sneak a peek if you want to add to the challenge.Not all caches have a pencil - please take one with you This cache is a 1/2 Litre clip lock box in camouflage bag BONUS CACHE To find the bonus cache you will need to walk the whole route and collect a series of combination numbers - See Bonus - Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details PARKING - Cars can park at the start of the route near Cache 1, or in Aldbourne. REFRESHMENTS - Aldbourne has pubs, a restaurant and various shops. POINTS OF INTERESTThe walk has points of interest in abundance, including:- Sugar Hill - The track onto the hill (between cache 1 & 2) is an old Saxon way known as the Thieves’ Way. Prehistoric Sites - A look at any Ordnance Survey map will show that this area is thick with the remains of ancient man’s activities. The oldest remains are the Bronze Age barrows recorded on maps as tumulus or tumuli. The four barrows between caches 7 & 8 are the best and can be seen in the distance on the way to cache 16. Liddington Castle, an Iron Age hillfort some 2,000 or more years old that can be visited via a permissive footpath from cache 28. Aldbourne - a pretty village that has flourished for over 1,000 years.  A severe fire in 1760 reduced much of the village to ashes. Upper Upham (cache 19) - The history of this site dates from as early as Roman times and there are remains of a deserted medieval village behind the Elizabethan manor house. Snap - Between cache 20 & 21 you pass the deserted village of Snap is unusual since it was abandoned as late as the last century as a result of agricultural depression. . This route passes Snap but the site itself is private and may contain dangerous well-shafts. Wildlife - The wildlife on this route is typical of chalk downland with many flowers, butterflies and bird, hares deer, skylarks and meadow pipits. You are also likely to see buzzards and possibly red kites, both large birds of prey. OTHER CACHES Along the way you can also find:- GC1H09T - War and PeaceGCMWHF - A Symphony of NumbersGC1G06P - SugarhillGCR6XE - Deserted Snap (Wiltshire)

properties.name: The Knight's Journey - Clue B
properties.gc_short_desc: Easy access on Public Footpaths in the centre of Bristol.
properties.gc_long_desc: This was the centre of Knight's Templar activity in 13th Century Bristol. The current church was build on the remains of the orginal Knights Templar church, the foundations of which still exist (allegedly). The tower of the current church is of special interest as it is leaning dramatically. Don't worry however, it has always been like this as the church was originally built on marsh land. Indeed after the war when the church was bombed the cleanup squad nearly demolished the tower as they thought it damaged. The is more about this at this site . The main cache page is found below The Knight's Journey The clues can be found at the following locations: Clue A Clue C "Knights Journey" travel bug

properties.name: Victoria Park
properties.gc_short_desc:
A short multi-stage cache that will take you around Royal Victoria Park, Bath, leading to a small clip-lock plastic container cache, large enough for small travelbugs, geocoins and some small items of swag.
Please be extra wary of muggles when retrieving and replacing the cache as the park is infested with them and the final cache site does not offer much cover.
properties.gc_long_desc:
You start this cache hunt facing west, with the obelisk in front of you and the gate to the Royal Crescent behind you.  The obelisk was first dedicated to Princess Victoria, then latterly to Queen Victoria and Prince Consort Albert.  You are looking for a date in this format: [mmm dd yyyy]. Take the year and call this ABCD.
Turn to the north and walk across the road, past the large tree and up to the house.  This is the park warden's house.  What is the number on the door?  Call this E.
Now go to: 
N51 2(C-E).(A+E)B(E-A) 
W02 22.C(E+C)(B-A).

You need to find a small stone memorial.  The memorial has two dates on it.  Call the first date FGHJ.
Now go to: 
N51 2(J+F).(C-J)(H-E-J)G 
W02 22.H(H+C)D

You are looking for bench with a dedication plaque on it.  How many letters in each of the person's names? call this K,L.  
Take a seat, enjoy the view, the cache is somewhere out there waiting for you...
Now go to: 
N51 23.(K-F)(K+F)(G-K) 
W02 22.(L+A)(K+L)(L-J)

Looking north, you should see a structure in front of you.  There are some letters on the structure.  How many letters are there?
Do a checksum of the number (add all the digits until you get a single digit, so if the count was 12, the checksum would be 1+2=3)  Call this M.

Now go find the cache at: 
N51.2(H-J).(K-J)M(L+D) 
W02 2(K-E).(K+J)(M+C-L)(E+J+M-L)

Hope you enjoyed the tour of the park.  If you have time and the sun is shining, reward yourself with an ice-cream from the ice-cream van near the playground, then why not try Jenny&James' lovely multi at the Great Dell (GC1RVC2)

properties.name: Bath Blitz
properties.gc_short_desc: This nano cache is hidden in the Memorial Gardens just off the busy Moorland Road shopping area.  Easy access for all participants but beware of muggles.  Please note: daytime access only as gardens are locked overnight.
properties.gc_long_desc:
More than 300 people were killed during the Bath Blitz in April 1942 and more than 19,000 buildings were damaged.

In May 2008, Willi Schludecker, attracted international attention when he visited Bath sixty-six years after dropping bombs on Bath during the infamous Baedeker raids.  

He sought the city's forgiveness during a special memorial service in front of a 200-strong congregation at the Memorial Gardens in Oldfield Park.

properties.name: CCCC
properties.gc_short_desc:
Nice easy location near John Cabot's Tower in Bristol just off Park
Street.
properties.gc_long_desc: The tower possesses possibly the best view of Bristol. It is a fantastic place to visit situated near Park Street which has some of Bristol's most attractive shops and boutiques. The tower commemorates John Cabot discovering Newfoundland in 1497. The squirrels are the friendliest I have ever come across so if you can take some monkey nuts. I'm sure they will not let me down. Near the cache you can find an Ice Cream van during the weekends, and nearby there are plenty of pubs and resturants. The name of the cache? Well that is a bit of a mystery, but I'm sure some of you will be able to find the answer to that!

properties.name: Forest View - Environmental Cache
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache has been set up with an environmental theme.  It would be nice to try and keep it's contents as environmentally friendly as possible.  Please feel free to take even if you have no appropriate swaps.
properties.gc_long_desc: The chalk downland in this area has a rich diversity of flora and forna. You can visit the website for further details. (Farley Mount) (This) is a useful website particularly for people who have recently become involved in geocaching.Some of the cache contents have been donated by Hampshire County Council.You can take your pick from any of the car parks along the top of this country park although the closest one has the same name as this cache. Kite flying and picnics are very popular here.There are a number of good caches within walking distance that would be worth a visit.Although the walk to the cache is quite easy going, the walk back will take a bit more effort. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britainoffering support for Geocachers in the UK

properties.name: Dlrow Rorrim
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a simple little puzzle cache based on the rather
eccentric writing style of Leonardo di ser Piero da Vinci.
properties.gc_long_desc: The cache is not at the listed co-ordinates but is in fact close by. To prevent madness from setting in, I would suggest furnishing yourself with a very useful piece of specialist equipment as suggested in the tittle of the cache. Please note: The cache is located near to deep water, so please keep an eye on children and dogs. The cache is a small container capable of holding small swaps and geocoins. When first placed it contained: Log book & Pencil for the first person to find this cacher, there is an unregistered geocoin awaiting your pleasure. FTF was The Rowan in an impressively quick time!

properties.name: CUBA Phone Box Cache #29
properties.gc_short_desc:
The twenty-ninth of an expanding series of TARDIS-esque caches
celebrating the iconic Red Phone Box. These caches will be placed
in (or on) phone boxes around Bath and the eastern side of Bristol,
across the Counties that Used to be Avon (CUBA).There is no pen in the cache.
The box is overlooked by a busy pub/restaurant, so stealth is
required!
properties.gc_long_desc: For the 28th in the series, follow this link: CUBA #28

This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.

Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

properties.name: Victoria Square
properties.gc_short_desc: The cache is a small nano.
properties.gc_long_desc:
**This cache is
located within an area frequently patrolled by Police. Please avoid
acting suspiciously whilst searching for it, and if challenged,
explain about geocaching**
There are workmen watching from the scafolding nearby who are now
directing cachers to the cache. If they speak to you please ask
their names as I want to meet them, thank them for looking after
the cache and give them some geoswag for for their children as a
thank you.
PLEASE DO NOT LOSE THE
SMALL MAGNET IN THE NANO. IF YOU LOSE IT YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO
ATTACH THE CACHE TO THE IRON RAILINGS AND THE CACHE MAY BE LOST FOR
CACHERS WHO LOOK FOR THE CACHE AFTER YOU. SO PLEASE BE
CAREFULL!

    
Victoria Square is a real gem close to Victora Station. It is a
small residential square located to the west of Buckingham Palace,
between Lower Grosvenor Place, Beeston Place, Grosvenor Gardens,
and Buckingham Palace Road. It is on land forming part of the
Grosvenor Estate. Cachers who fantasy is that they are spies making
a dead letter drop will love this one. No 16 was the home of Ian
Flemming where he wrote the books about 007's exploits. Ian Fleming
lived there from 1953 untill his death in 1964 . If you look very
carefully you might see James Bond paying a visit to the square to
show his respects to his creator!
The square comprises about 25 residential houses, which are all
Grade 2* listed as being of special historic interest. These are
five-storey stucco-fronted properties designed by the architect
William Wyatt constructed in the late 1830s to celebrate the
beginning of Queen Victoria's reign. The central square was
recently renovated after residents contributed to a six figure sum
towards the project. A statue of the young Queen Victoria was
specially commissioned and has been placed there. Former other
residents include,former Conservative MP Michael Portillo.
The cache is inside Victoria Square but you can retrieve it with
out entering the square. The cache contains a just log book .
Before moving here Ian Fleming lived in Ebury Street and there
is a cache GC1ZMC2 007 You only live twice! by bevroutley which I
have adopted marking the Blue Plaque commemorating Ian Fleming at
that location.

properties.name: What's up? Things ain't what they used to be
properties.gc_name: What's up? Things ain't what they used to be
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a straightforward multicache that takes you around some of the shopping streets of central Bath. From start to finish, you will cover about 1 mile. If you don't get diverted into too many shops along the way, the stroll should take under 1 hour. There are some steps towards the end, although it is possible to avoid them if you go a longer way round. All the waypoints are virtual, and the final cache is a micro, containing only a logbook, so please bring your own pen.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Bath has some great shops. It is also lucky to have some interesting remnants of its retail past; however, most of the time we completely miss them. This multicache takes you on a trail back in time. The instructions are simple: at each waypoint, just look up! Waypoints are labelled A-H in a suggested walking order ('A' coincides with the main posted coordinates of this cache). I have also provided a numbered list below, which should make sense as you walk around, although the list order is random. At each waypoint, find the appropriate mapping between the letter (e.g. Waypoint A) and a digit in the list (e.g. Dill's=7); then substitute your values into the formula for the final coordinates (e.g. A=7). (Warning: the example given might not be correct!)

At the final GZ, there is another excuse to look up, but this time it has nothing to do retailing. Instead, this is a pleasant spot away from the hubbub of the shops, where you may even get to glimpse Bath's swiftest residents (Falco peregrinus), although I hear them more often than I see them. I've already given too much away for the locals, but this cache is as much for visitors to Bath! The main point is not to conquer a tricky puzzle, but to enjoy wandering around the shops while spotting the waypoints.

My GPSr really doesn't like the streets of Bath, so please just do your best with the waypoint coordinates! Most of these clues are best viewed from the other side of the street anyway, plus the clues are very large and very easy. Remember, just … look … up!

1 - Nestle's Milk / Milkmaid
2 - Hand's Dairy
3 - George Gregory Book Store
4 - Brush Manufactory
5 - W D Lane Abbey Dairy
6 - A Wills & Sons Building Contractors
7 - Dill's Famous Bath Polonies
8 - Circulating Library and Reading Room

The cache is a micro at:

N 51° 22.(D+G)CA
W 002° 21.(F-E-G)(H+C)B

To ensure a nice dry log, you will find that it is 'double-containered', as I suspect the outer container is not 100% damp-proof (but I liked it!). Please bring your own pen. When replacing, please align precisely so that it is flush front and back (nothing bright showing!).

properties.name: Church Micro 1121 - Bentworth - St Mary's
properties.gc_short_desc:
The cache is not here - these are the coordinates for the
parking and the front of the church
You are looking for a film cannister
Please bring a pen
properties.gc_long_desc: The church of ST. MARY, situated at the north-east of the village, stands in the centre of a churchyard which is inclosed by a wood paling and surrounded by tall trees. It consists of chancel 27 ft. by 17 ft. 4 in., with a small north vestry; nave, 48 ft. 7 in. by 17 ft., with north and south aisles and south porch; and west tower 9 ft. 6 in. square, these dimensions being internal. The nave arcades date from the last quarter of the 12th century, and the chancel arch is of the same period. The chancel was built round an older chancel about 1260, and the lower part of the tower is of the same date or a little earlier. The aisles of the nave seem to have been rebuilt in the 14th century, and in modern times the fabric has been thoroughly repaired. The church has been entirely refaced with dressed flints, the ashlar work renewed, and the whole church re-roofed. The present tower arch dates from 1890, and the wooden belfry placed upon the tower, and finished with a short octagonal spire covered with tiles, is of the same date. The cache can be found at N51 09.ABC W001 02.DEF where A=Number of letters in second name of the family that restored the lych gate B=Number of letters in first + second names of the family that restored the lych gate The lych gate was restored in G00H C=GxH D=Number of letters in the gallantry decorations after Neville Elliott Cooper's name E=H F=Number of clocks on the church tower

properties.name: Sights of Manchester - Manchester Town Hall
properties.gc_name: Sights of Manchester - Manchester Town Hall
properties.gc_short_desc: A magnetic micro located in Albert Square near Manchester Town Hall, part of the Sights of Manchester series. The Cache includes a pencil and a log sheet.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This Cache is part of the “Sights of Manchester” series intended to demonstrate some of Manchester’s interesting buildings and features.

This Cache is located in Albert Square which is worth a visit in its own right as there are various statues located here. The main purpose of the cache, however, is to demonstrate Manchester Town Hall. Designed by the architect Alfred Waterhouse, it was completed in 1877 at a cost of £1 million, and is a fine example of Victorian Gothic Revival. Take time to look at the intricate external carvings and sculptures. At certain times, guided tours of the interior can be attended, where the murals of Ford Madox Brown can be seen. If you want to attend a tour, be sure to check if they are actually running when you plan to visit. 

This cache is located very close to the Manchester Town Hall itself. It should be fairly easy to find. The difficulty rating of 3 is because extreme care will need to be taken not to arouse suspicion. Albert Square is generally busy, and is often used for events. Wishing you all the best with your hunting. DG + CS

properties.name: Fellowship of the Mega Ring
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache is dedicated to The Lord of the Cachers.
 
It is placed near the centre of the UK Mega Series of 126 caches. 

It was placed for the Hampshire Monthly Midweek Cache Event No 2 on 11 February 2009 but will be left in place after that event.

The cache itself is a black container.

properties.name: CORTON RING 33
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The caches are set in such a way that they can be completed in one 12 mile round walk or attempted in two separate 6 mile circular walks.  Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: Flonopoly Cache 15 - Northumberland Avenue
properties.gc_long_desc:
**This cache is located within an area frequently patrolled by
Police. Please avoid acting suspiciously whilst searching for it,
and if challenged, explain about geocaching**
 Welcome to FireLanterns-onopoly, or Flonopoly for short. A cache
series inspired by (but in no way associated with or endorsed by!)
the board game of a similar(ish) name. This series of caches will
take you to 28 locations around the streets of London, some well
known, some not so well known, but all of them made famous by that
great board name we all know and love. 
The caches are mostly all 35mm and magnetic, containing log book
only, so bring a pen. Within each cache you will also find a small
Flonopoly logo, with a number on the back. Take careful note of
this number (and make sure you get the logo the right way up - turn
it round, not upside down - don't mix up those 6's and 9's!) - as
you will need all of these if you want to go for Flonopoly - Jail
and ultimatley Flonopoly - GO. If you make it all the way round
these London Streets, there will be a small Flonopoly reward as a
mark of respect for covering a lot of miles. Also if this is your
first Flonopoly cache, please take note of the date and time of
your first find - and when/if you do them all, the date and time of
your last, so when you log Flonopoly GO you can tell us how long it
took you to do the series !
Flonopoly Cache 15 - Northumberland Avenue
The cache - NOT a magnetic 35mm this time, but a small silver key
ring, containing log book only. No number in this one either, but
you'll still need a number - SO - take a step back from the cache
(when you've found it!) - and turn to your right to look under the
bridge nearby. How many hanging lights are there on the same side
of the road as you ? - it'll be obvious what you're looking at -
they're all in a row, hanging from the roof of the bridge. Single
digit number.

properties.name: Rochdale Canal Manchester (Wii pot #2)
properties.gc_long_desc:
Situated in Manchester City Centre close by to the Bridgewater Basin, along the Rochdal Canal. 
The cache is on the left side if you are walking away from Deansgate locks towards Bridgewater Basin on the city centre. It is on the other side of the canal to the blue sign.

properties.name: Cardiff,s "bouncy" bridge
properties.gc_long_desc: This cache is located within a 15min walk from the city centre so it is a good cache for people visiting the Welsh capital or wanting a bit of a break from shopping. See if you can work out why I have called this cache Cardiff,s "bouncy" bridge. Stealth will most certainly be required on this one. Refreshments can be found at the new Summerhouse kiosk on the opposite side of the bridge to the cache if you require a break.

properties.name: 1066, Battle of Hastings (Battle, Hastings)
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is a 1L plastic box that is located at ground level within 500m (1500 ft) of the published co-ordinates. Sorry, it is not accessible to wheelchair cachers. Access with a baby buggy may be difficult on wet days.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The published co-ordinates are for the site of the Battle of Hastings. 
I believe they are the actual co-ordinates where King Harold was killed. 

Please feel free to add your own facts relating to the Battle of Hastings in your log. 

The easist town centre parking (fee payable) is here: 
N 50° 55.060 E 000° 29.100 

Alternatively, if you are paying to visit Battle Abbey then you can park in the Abbey's car park for free (NB: a token is required to active the exit barrier), here: 
N 50° 54.895 E 000° 29.090 

If you are a member of English Heritage then I believe that you may park at the Battle Abbey car park all day for one pound. 
Please check at the ticket office that this is still possible, paying for the exit token at the same time, before you enter the car park. 

You need to solve the following amended formulae to find the cache:

N [G - A] [A - C]  [H - C] [ B ] . [B + B] [A + E + G] [C + G]

E [A - C] [C - E] [E - A]  [A + C] [A + C + G] . [C + E + H] [A + B + C] [E + H]

Where: 
AB CD EFGH = the date (dd mm yyyy) of the Battle of Hastings.

properties.name: Homes of the rich and famous
properties.gc_name: Homes of the rich and famous
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a multi-legged cache visiting houses of the famous (and not-so famous) people who have lived and worked in the fashionable Clifton village area of Bristol. Details taken from the plaques will eventually lead to a hidden cache close at hand.
properties.gc_long_desc:
My suggested start point for the 7-legged virtual part of this cache is Christ Church in Clifton. It`s coordinates are shown above and there is usually adequate on-street parking close at hand. The church spire is 212ft high and it is therefore the highest point in Bristol and visible for many miles.
The suggested route below is the shortest distance between each cache but you can deviate if you wish. Details taken from each plaque will eventually lead to a nearby hidden cache. This cache is hidden at:-
N51 2A.BCD W2 3E.FGH. Letters A- H are represented by the numbers as shown below :-

Virtual cache 1 : N51 27.465 W2 37.244 (A poet)
                  Lived here 1836-183A

Virtual cache 2 : N51 27.356 W2 37.200 (Sir -------- ---- Scientist)
                  Lived in this house 1C98

Virtual cache 3 : N51 27.317 W2 37.043 (A sportsman)
                  Lived here 189B-6

Virtual cache 4 : N51 27.241 W2 37.033 (A novellist)
                  Lived here 190E-18

Virtual cache 5 : N51 27.217 W2 37.443 (An architect)
                  Lived here 19H9-1990

Virtual cache 6 : N51 27.254 W2 37.416 (An historian / statesman)
                  Lived here 18F2

Virtual cache 7 : N51 27.305 W2 37.240 (An architect)
                  177G-1837

Finally     D=C-2

The route should take 1-2 hours and is designed such that the final cache is reasonably close to your start point.It consists of a half pint lunch box suitable for small items. 
There are adequate stopping-off places en route to do some shopping or have a quiet drink or a meal.
