properties.name: Southsea Secrets #2 (Hants)
properties.gc_short_desc: Urban micro cache in Southsea, Hants.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This area of Southsea is full of historical monuments and information including the Garrison Church. It is a short walk to Old Portsmouth along the Millenium Promenade where there are many pubs and tea shops. There is seating nearby so that you can relax and enjoy the excellent views across to the Isle of Wight.

The cache is a 35mm film canister containing a log book only.

The terrain is wheelchair and buggy friendly to within a few metres of the cache, but a step up is needed to reach it, and a possible jump down again depending on your preference. Hence the difficulty rating. You will not need to move any objects or material to locate the cache, just think about it and feel with your fingers. 

Please remember to bring your own pen or pencil in case there isn't one in the cache at the time of your visit. One of the fundamental understandings of geocaching is that visitors sign the log so if you can't do that you can't count it as a find......

properties.name: Hackpen White Horse (Wilts)
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is an offset cache starting at the Hackpen White Horse hill,
which has excellent views. There is an adjacent car park. The cache
is about a mile from here (well away from the sensitive areas SSSI
and World Heritage Area).
properties.gc_long_desc: The views from this location are excellent and the Ridgeway path passes through here. After visiting the top of the hill then you will move down to a location where you can see the white horse. More information about the White Horse can be found at Bill D's excellent web site. The above co-ordinates will take you to an information plate. Take the LAST phone number on the information board as ABCDE FGHJKL (make sure it really is the last phone number) then the cache is at N51°2G.FGD', W01°DA.C(B-D)H'. This cache is located a mile from the first location, some distance from the sensitive area. When replacing the cache please ensure it is hidden from view in every direction. You can park safely adjacent to the offset clue and the final cache. However, please beware traffic by listening for approaching cars when rejoining the road. An Ordnance Survey map for the overall location is available at this web site. Please check out the Geocaching Association of Great Britain offering support for Geocachers in GB.

properties.name: Up In The Woods!
properties.gc_short_desc:
The cache is located in Grovely Woods, which is only a few miles
from the A36/A303 junction, and the drive up to it has the most
wonderful views over the area.
properties.gc_long_desc: Grovely Wood is a large area of woodland that now belongs to the Forestry Commission. By ancient right, the villagers of Great Wishford (4 miles east of cache location) can gather their firewood there. Oak Apple Day celebrates this custom and is held annually on 29th May. In more recent times, it was used during World War 2, look hard enough and you can still find some old air raid shelters. There are numerous places to park to access this cache depending on the length of the walk. I recommend you turn off the main road at N51 06.748 W001 59.527 and either park soon after, or continue down this track for about 0.6km to a small parking area near a pile of black gravel. The cache itself is a short walk from the second parking area and is a 2-litre container. It contains all the usual type of things (photo frames, wind up toys, books etc). After finding the cache, should you wish to extend your walk, turn left along the track (rather than heading back to the car), go straight over at the next junction and take the next left along a major track. Follow this path, which narrows considerably, and you’ll end up back at the parking area after about 30 minutes. There are lots of other walking options up here – go and enjoy! NOTE: It appears people may be a little concerned with the spent cartridges found near the parking spot. This is an area well used by walkers and I have been walking up here for over 10 years without the slightest problem. Yes, the area is used for pheasant shooting occasionally but it has never presented a problem to myself or other local walkers. That said, exercise caution if you're mad enough to go at night! Please don't let this put you off visiting a beautiful area!

properties.name: Way Down West 81
properties.gc_short_desc: The series starts in West Down,North Devon.
properties.gc_long_desc:

properties.name: Bradford on Avon
properties.gc_short_desc: Easy multi staged cache taking in the delights of Bradford on Avon Town Centre and then a river walk to the cache. Could get muddy, pushchairs should be OK and should take around an hour to complte in full.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The above coordinates take you to something wooden. Find a persons name and let the number of letters in the first name be 'a' and the number in the second name 'b'. Now solve the first equation to get you to the next point.

N 5 1   2 0 . ax2  a-2  1
W 0 0 2  1 5 . a-2  3  b

You are now at a historical part of Bradford on Avon. Find Rex and the 2 dates at this point and number them a b c d & e f g h.
Now solve the next equation to progress. When done, cross back over and follow the tow path under the railway bridge.

N 5 1   2 0 . a+d 0 c
W 0 0 2   1 5 . c g 0

You are now at a green circular plaque. Find the date with the 's' after it and label the numbers a b c d.
Now solve the last equation to lead you to the cache.

N 5 1  2 0 . a+b 0 a+b+c+d 
W 0 0 2   1 5 . b 8 a

Easy really. Happy hunting.

properties.name: Portland View
properties.gc_short_desc:
The search begins in the seaside town of Weymouth. We suggest
parking in any of the town centre car parks. Allow about 1.5 hours
to find the cache. The walk, allowing for the return to your start
point is about 2.5 miles. There is a steepish climb on the last leg
to the cache. The above coordinates are for the start of your
search.
properties.gc_long_desc: Evolving over the years by the combination of the two smaller ports of Melcombe Regis and Weymouth, the town of Weymouth became famous by the patronage of King George III in the 18th century. Now one of the country's leading seaside resorts, nearby Portland is soon to be the home of the sailing events at the 2012 Olympics. Substitute numbers for letters were appropriate: 1. What year is shown on the plaque on this structure? a.b.b.c The next location is at N 50 deg 36.5aa W 002 deg 2c.02b 2. There are two signs attached to railings here, make a note of the numbers, as follows: d-e and f-dge The next location is at N 50 deg 3e.g(g-d)(f+d) W 002 deg 2f.(dx2)fe 3. Standing at the given coordinates, take a look at the sign in an approximately SW direction on the opposite side of the water. What number do you have to call? hjkhp mnmpmn The next location is at N 50 deg 3n.kpp W 002 deg 2m.j(k+p)(m-k) 4. What was built here c1600? _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 1 2 6 9 4 3 9 2 7 0 Your next location is at N 50 deg 36.uoe W 002 deg 27.er(r+r) 5. Lookout for the sign attached to the lamppost. What is it directing you to? _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 7 8 0 9 4 5 0 4 1 The cache, a 2.1 litre bowl shaped plastic container, is located at N 50 deg 36.a o s W 002 deg 27.h a a Watch out for muggles near the cache site. Some may have a canine friend! Please ensure cache remains well hidden. Enjoy the walk and the views!

properties.name: The Gas
properties.gc_short_desc:
Start at St Werburgh’s city farm. As well as being an
interesting place to visit, the farm also has a café, play ground
and a pub near by called The Farm.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Follow the clues and replace the letters with numbers.
1) Starting at an information sign. The year of the first church
service ABCD.
N5A.2B.3A3 W002.34.CC3 will take you to a sign.
2) The Registered Charity No. EFGHIJK.
NJE.2B.3JD WFI2.34.4K2 will take you to a spot where the name of
this cache becomes clear. The view includes the local Gas works and
Eastville Stadium (Now Ikea). This is the spiritual home of Bristol
Rovers football team who were nicknamed The Gas because of the
dominant Gas works that towered over the stadium. The Gas works are
now all but gone and Bristol Rovers now play at the memorial
stadium in Horfield.
3) The Year in which the Narrow ways walk way opened PQRS.
There is an interesting bench on top of the hill here where you and
sit and watch he trains go by.
NJE.PB.4KP WSR2.34.J3D will take you to the location of the
cache.
After you have found the cache, carry on along the path and past
the self build houses to get back to the Farm.
Original contents: Robot, Glasses, Puzzle, Baby Classics CD, Tape
Measure, Toy Watch.

properties.name: The Best (or Worst) View of Bath
properties.gc_name: The Best (or Worst) View of Bath
properties.gc_short_desc: Short multi-cache overlooking the World Heritage City of Bath.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Our first cache, and in a location close to home. This replaces Fruitdrop’s “A view that kills”; similar views, different approach, and not so killing. Approx 1km walk over surfaced paths throughout. Suitable for buggies, and if you have small people with you there’s a small-but-perfectly-formed playground on top of the hill. Parking is available on street at N 51 deg 22.489 W002 deg 21.817 and on the road to the south; please do not park closer to the first waypoint, the road is narrow and careless parking can obstruct access. You’re looking for a 35mm film canister, so no room for swaps I’m afraid.

Waypoint #1 is at the posted coordinates. You should get an idea of the views to come, and you also need to solve a clue… although you might need to do a little research before getting there. According to the information available at the waypoint, what is the height of GCP3XF ? Call it ABC. Waypoint#2 is at:

 N 051 deg C C . (A-3) (B*5) (C*2)  W 002 deg C B . (B*4) (A+1) (C*4)

Off you go, and along the way you’ll come across either the best, or the worst, view of Bath. Why the best ? Well, this is the closest high vantage point to the city centre, and sights such as Royal Crescent, Bath Abbey, etc are easily visible within the panorama. And why the worst ? Because the foreground is dominated by the grotesque 70’s shopping centre known as Southgate. It’s due to be redeveloped soon, so if you’re lucky you’ll see a building site instead. If you feel so inclined, take a picture and perhaps we’ll end up with a sequence showing the demolition & rebuilding. Exactly where you come across the view depends upon which bits of tree growth B&NES Council have trimmed back, and whether you’re doing this in summer or winter.

At Waypoint#2 – which just might be the best viewpoint – look for John Street. What’s the first number on the plaque ? Call it DEFG. Now you can head off to the cache at:

N 051 deg F F . G D (E-1)    W 002 deg F D . (F+G) E 0

NB Cache is accessible from the path - you do not have to climb over, nor lean dangerously far. When you replace the cache, please ensure it is within easy reach for the next cacher.

If you’ve walked up from town, retrace your steps a few metres, take the obvious northward path and keep heading downhill (not suitable for buggies).

properties.name: Can I See Uranus ?
properties.gc_short_desc: This is an offset multi cache starting at the former home of William Herschel, discoverer of the planet Uranus.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The house is now home to a museum dedicated to the life and work of this man. 

This cache requires you to go to the above co-ordinates and gather some information. You will also need to do a bit of homework using the Internet to gather some of the required answers.

Date on the plaque when William Herschel lived here 		ABCD
Number of keyholes in the front door					E
Number of letters in the day of the week when the museum is closed		F
Date the planet was discovered							GH/J/KLMN
Number of the house								PQ
White number on lamppost opposite museum				R 

The cache can be found at:

N51	(A+G)(H-K).F(E+P)(B-A-D)

W002	(J-N)(Q-L).(P+D)ER 

Parking – Don’t even try to park at the posted co-ordinates. Parking in the area is for permit holders only, and there are plenty of Pay and Display car parks in Bath for you to use. Or you could use the parking facilities of a nearby supermarket – but I haven’t told you this !

You are looking for a 35mm camera film canister, containing logbook only. So please remember to bring your own pencil.

You do not need to leave the footpath to retrieve this cache.

properties.name: Bristol Curios #10
properties.gc_short_desc: "Get Back VK"
properties.gc_long_desc: So you think you know Bristol? This series will find out how much you know/can find out/are lucky enough to bump into. All the series are small or micro caches with a code letter and number inside. Please make a note of these for the final cache. All the caches can be found within wandering distance of the City Centre. Some are well known and easy, some can be googled and simply found, some are obscure and some are plain difficult with no WWW reference at all. the cache difficulty will let you know which category is which. The series will be released bit by bit to give everyone a chance to find the cache first. The instructions are simple and apply to each cache: Find the object pictured and then follow the instuctions to find the cache location. Here is a hard number ten.. Find this object and how many letters are on the closest street name sign = I? The cache is at: (Checksum all digits = 53)        When attempting this cache series you assume all risks involved and agree with the geocaching.comTerms and Conditions

properties.name: Roamin' Bath #1
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a multi-cache that will take you around some of the
interesting places in historic Bath. It should take less than 1
hour. Except for the actual cache location, it is all on the level
and does not involve steps or unmade paths. Park at the Sports
Centre at the above co-ordinate, or use any public car park, or the
Park and Ride. Street parking rarely available.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is the first cache that we have created. We hope you like it. 
The co-ordinates have been corrected 31/8/08 in response to
comments and the descriptions in the waypoints have been
clarified.

properties.name: Roamin' Bath #2
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is the second in our series of Roamin' Bath. You can park at
the posted co-ordinates free for up to 2 hours – the cache itself
will take less than 1 hour to complete. There are some steps to
negotiate, although an alternative route can be used which would
miss them.
properties.gc_long_desc:
You are looking for a small Lock'n'Lock container in a cammo bag. 
Initial contents are: Log Book, Pen, First to Find Certificate,
Lyn Hatch Amateur Gardeners Butterfly Travel Bug, Shower Cap,
Artificial flower, Dog clip, mini clothes peg.
First to Find goes to jenandberry. Well done!
Co-ordinates corrected 27/8/08 in response to comments.

properties.name: Monarch Way #1
properties.gc_short_desc:
A stroll of less than 1 mile along Monarch Way in Wick village. 
There are stiles to negotiate, so not stroller friendly. The
route can be wet and muddy – watch out for cow pats too!

The posted co-ordinates are to the Golden Valley car park adjacent
to Wick Village hall.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Wick village is very old. The Manor of Wyke, belonged to the Abbey
of Glastonbury before the reign of Richard I. In 1192 the manor
became the property of the Bishopric of Bath and Wells, thus it
continued until Henry VIII acquired it in 1546. He granted it to
John Wintour. 
Monarch Way is the 610 mile route used by Charles II after the
Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the
Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled
north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then
travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South
Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham
from where he made his escape to France.
The original contents of this cache are: 
Log Book
Pen
First to Find Certificate
Butterfly Brooch Gift for First To Find
Disney Rubber
Little doll
Small monkey toy
CONGRATULATIONS: FTF CIDERMAN

properties.name: Don't Be Deceived!
properties.gc_short_desc: My second cache in the Ashton Court Estate, almost in view of the first (R.I.P Ashton Number One), but much better hidden. The cache can be approached from several ways. Terrain is quite steep in places, and can be muddy.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Ashton Court is a mansion and estate to the west of the City of Bristol. It is owned by Bristol City Council, although much of it is in North Somerset. The estate covers 850 Acres (3.4 km²)of woods and open grassland, and contains two golf courses, a miniature railway, an orienteering course, and a mountain bike trail. There is also an extensive deer park, dating from the fourteenth century.

There are two main parking places inside the estate. You can park at the bottom, off the Portway, or at the top off Bridge Road. You should be able to reach the cache location without too much difficulty, access is on paved road/hard ground until the last fifty meters or so.

properties.name: Way Down West 33
properties.gc_short_desc: The caches start at West Down in North Devon.

      and in Marwood see Way Down West 70(GC24Y6C)

properties.name: Monarch Way #3
properties.gc_short_desc:
A walk to the cache and back to the car of 1.5 miles. Involves
stiles so is not buggy friendly. The co-ordinates are to a free
parking area.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Wick is a modest yet pretty village that is situated on the A420
between Bristol and Bath. Many travellers will have passed through
the ribbon-like development without realising the beauty that it
hides. 
Monarch Way is the 610 mile route used by Charles II after the
Battle of Worcester in 1651 when he was pursued by the
Parliamentary forces under Oliver Cromwell. Charles first travelled
north, where he hid in the famous oak tree at Boscobel. He then
travelled south through the Cotswolds and the Mendips to the South
Coast at Charmouth, and finally along the South Downs to Shoreham
from where he made his escape to France.

properties.name: #12 Westwood Wander
properties.gc_long_desc:
Part of a series of caches placed in and around the villages of Westwood, Farleigh Hungerford & Iford. There are no clues to collect or puzzles to solve, so just enjoy your walk and take in the breathtaking countryside views.
This circular route covers approx 3.5 miles, and should take about 2.5 hours. 

The difficulty and terrain scores refer to the series as a whole.

properties.name: The Frome Kryptos
properties.gc_short_desc: A cryptographic cache that starts in the centre of Frome and ends up just outside it.  The cache is located nowhere near the above coordinates.
properties.gc_long_desc:
In front of the CIA Cafeteria at Langley stands a sculpture entited 'Kryptos' by artist James Sanborn.  The sculpture, in the form of an S, consists of two convex surfaces: once covered with a 869 character long chunk of ciphertext and the other showing a 869 Vignere-like table based on the keyword Kryptos.  

Edward M. Scheidt, former chairman of the CIA's Cryptographic Center, chose the types of ciphers used for the encryption.  The sculptor then encrypted the plaintext using Scheidt's methods – but subtly changing them.  Since it's dedication in October 1990, the full plaintext has been known only to the Sculptor, the Cryptographer and a closed-mouthed handful of others.  At the time of writing (October 2009), all but the last 97 characters have been decrypted.  It is true to say that the Kryptos is considered to the Everest of cryptographic challenges.  

This cache is a homage to James Sanborn's sculpture, but it is designed to be cracked.  

This is the orginal version of the cipher text:  

ORAQW KUEQF ZFNMM NGJYB VBVRM TAPGG KJJHY VWTTI OGRQT
TFECH QGGGR QJBRG NSAJL ZEPBQ YRWOI MKLHR ICLEL AXPJS
IAMWK JRTTW GXTZB QYVWE AJVJY SJFVF BTUPD LHRTH FINSQ

SUBAR ZWSRS YVHVP YRSSU QBWBW RBOEP ORSQT RZAOD EYAPS 
RSSER ESKCV WZSRB CPTVU BSIC

This is the new version of the cipher text:

TOJFR RFLEE TZRPC SYJBX YSSGT SRGWN WPYVQ WAGFB JYANT 
QWKGS AFUSI OGWRE QREWD PISJG UAEFR YNKTR TZRPC CNSSU 
PSRRE HYRAR FMWET DAFUG ABCEQ TZRPC SYJBX PSRRE QREWD 
OPKVQ UOCTS RFLEE KCBRV BBXSU FDIAH LVEMS PBFVQ KLNDY 
RFLEE YSIHK CNSSU FDAPL OJGWR FMWET ?LOSL OSYEO FQIPO 
FSWEL KBNEO FYGKN FSYDF IBNHD VSYEL OSYTD VSYEL OSYRN 
MPMEO DAERO FEOEL OSYEO FYGRO FLYFS YLOSN MSYEO FSWEO 
AACSA UWSTE OKGDK OIERF CSPQE OZOBP OWSTV RSPNS RWSRA 
UEVBS RWSRA UEVSO NILYC SZSZE OWCSA UWSTE OZOCE OKRTE 
VACSO NWSTE OIETP S?SQR IPFMG IECMW IEQJB LTISR ILFMG 
IEQKS PRHSP IERAI BPFMG IEMDR ILISR ILFMG IEQKS PRHSP 
IEFUK NYFMG IECMW IEQKS PRQJB LTHSP IERAI BPNBL IEJSQ 
RQHSP IEQJS HGHSP IEISR ILHSP IECMW IEAIS VIHSP IEFUK 
NYHSP IEHSP IEQJB LTRAI BPNBL IECJS HGBLS LIBLS LI

Here are a few clues to get you started:

Three encryption methods are used which will render a piece of poetry in which the location of the cache is hidden.  The '?' (question mark) donates a change in cipher scheme as per the real Kryptos.  

All of the cipher schemes use a keyword or keywords.  These words are included somewhere on this page.  


To recover the location from within the poem embedded within version #1 of the cipher text you will need to divine the link between: the number nine, a military rank, a famous English Detective (not that one!), the building at the above co-ordinates and a manufacturer of bespoke clothing.  

To recover the location from version #2, you will need to work out who it wasn't who wrote all of the famous Bard's plays.  

The Cache when first placed included:
Log book & pencil
Yo-yo
Toy car
A badge or two

and the first to find prize.

***Congratulations to The Evil Poles on their FTF***

properties.name: Xmas Curios #12
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. Now to the cache:"On the twelth day of Christmas my true love sent to me, twelve strange lines" Find the curio. Add the number of steps behind the curio to the number of bollards? = "Y" Cache is at N51.2?((X*Y)+(Y*39)+S)) W002.3?((Y*5)+K))

properties.name: Xmas Curios #11
properties.gc_long_desc: So the first series took you to the streets of Bristol. This Xmas group will be no different, except they are a little easier to find. They are not at the posted co-ordinates. As befitting a Christmas series there will be a bonus Xmas Day cache for those who complete the series. As before, find the curio, follow the instructions to find the co-ordinates and then the cache. There will be a series of letters to record for later in the series. Now to the cache:"On the eleventh day of Christmas my true love sent to me, eleven bored stiff wives" Find the curio. Look opposite for 6 white words on black. How many letters in total? = "W" Cache is at N51.2?((W*5)+R) W002.3?((W*13)+G)

properties.name: #17 Temple Bottom
properties.gc_short_desc:
One of a series of 36 caches around Temple Bottom starting and ending at Hackpen Hill on the Ridgeway.

I've upped the difficulty due to tree cover
properties.gc_long_desc:
Whilst you will be using public footpaths you will be crossing  farmland and gallops, so please keep dogs on their leads and be aware of any livestock and horses that you may come across.

Please be aware that there may be shooting at certain times of the year and all warning signs should be adhered to.

Parking for several cars at N51 28.279   W001 48.918, 
Please take care when crossing the road as vehicles travel quite fast along this stretch.

Please take a pen or pencil to sign logs

I've spotted Red Kites, Kestrels, Buzzards, Deer and plenty of Pheasants whilst setting up the series so keep your eyes open.

properties.name: Avoncliff Aqueduct Ring 1 : Between waters
properties.gc_short_desc: Circular walk of approx 4.5 miles and 13 caches taking cacher to Westwood, Avoncliff and Winsley. Set predominantly for Event at Tithe Barn in Bradford on Avon on Sunday 12th July.  Some parts of circular could be muddy and unfortunately the route is not suitable for wheelchairs or pushchairs. A few of you may recognise the route as it appears on a few of our previous caches. Good luck....

Parking for several cars at N51 28.279   W001 48.918, 
Please take care when crossing the road as vehicles travel quite fast along this stretch.

Please take a pen or pencil to sign logs

I've spotted Red Kites, Kestrels, Buzzards, Deer and plenty of Pheasants whilst setting up the series so keep your eyes open.

properties.name: Time At The Bar - The Hero
properties.gc_name: Time At The Bar - The Hero
properties.gc_short_desc:
Located Just outside Winchester city centre on an uphill gradent on the way from the city center.

Parking is for permit holders only from  08:00 to 18:00 Monday to Saturday.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Time At The Bar series will take you around the centre of Winchester to visit some of the gone and forgotten public houses that ceased trading long ago.

The caches can all be done on a pleasant walk in one day in good weather or on their own.

If you would like to learn a little more about Winchesters forgotten history, have a go at GC1279A which is a mystry cache created by Juggles.


On the site here stood The Hero which stoped trading in 1906 having been in existance since before 1860 and became a privet house, untill nos. 22 to 34 were knocked down and replace with  the current incumbent in 1974.

At the bottom of the hill, just over the railway bridge is perninsular barracks. This was home to The King’s Royal Rifle Corps and The Rifle Brigade, although now coveted into some rather nice apartments it is still the headquaters of Regimental Headquarters of The Royal Green Jackets and houses the militry museams.

Please rehide carefully.

properties.name: Micro cache series #1
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is located in the blaise castle estate, the terrain is simple and the cache maybe difficult to find for some.
properties.gc_long_desc: This is cache number 1 of 5 in this micro cache series all located in the blaise castle estate, the cache is a tiny plastic screwtop container! The series takes you from one end of the estate to the other, all the micros are 0.2 - 0.5 miles from each other and are not too difficult to find and retrieve, happy hunting.

properties.name: Wander Wound Westbury
properties.gc_short_desc: A short wander winding awound Westbury-on-Trym.  All the clues are accessible 24 hours (although the information may be difficult to read in the dark).  The walking part is about 1km, all on well-made paths.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The posted co-ordinates are for the main car park in Westbury-on-Trym.

To find the cache, visit the waypoints below and answer the questions.  They don't have to be done in order (but it helps...)

The final cache is at N51 2F.(E-C)(G+H)A W002 3(J-K).L(D/B)(A-C).  It is a small lock'n'lock box, containing a selection of the usual oddments.

properties.name: Cache Across Somerset #5 Bath
properties.gc_short_desc: See the bonus cache for this series is GC1R3EP "Taunton" for further information and a table to enter the bonus letters and number combination.
properties.gc_long_desc: Cache Across Somerset - City of Bath Dont forget to note the bonus letter and number, please leave the card in the cache.Good luck.The cache is a film can hidden in Green Park in the center of Bath, it shouldn't be too difficult to do the deed without attracting attention if you are careful. *** FTF congratulations go to Gnonedodds ***

properties.name: Grovely's Witchcraft Ring No24
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is number 24 of the Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring which is a
series of 24 caches, placed in a figure of eight, of various sizes
and difficult to complement the Grovely Series which is a little
further to the West.
properties.gc_long_desc: Full details of the Witchcraft stories are included on the Govely’s Witchcraft Ring Listing No1 (GC1XF72) and No 10 (GC1XFDM). Details of parking places, access and other information are also provided on those listings. This figure of eight ring is about 9 miles long and does keep to the Roman road, public paths, bridleways, etc. At times, for those that do the full ring, the going is very hard as there are some hills to climb and descend. Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging. You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village.

properties.name: Brislington Brook Walk 4 - Sidetracked in St Annes
properties.gc_name: Brislington Brook Walk 4 - Sidetracked in St Annes
properties.gc_short_desc:
A series of caches that lead from the River Avon up Brislington
Brook. The terrain is varied; paths and tracks wind their way along
the side of the brook and as you head further along, it can get a
bit muddy at times.
properties.gc_long_desc: The best path to get to the this cache from Brislington Brook Walk 3 is to head back down stream on the right hand side of the valley and head up to the path junction at N51 26.937 W002 32.651 (there are some steps here!) and then out onto St Annes Park Road at N51 26.910 W002 32.669. Head right following St Annes Park Road straight on past the roundabout up to Wick Road and turn left heading over the bridge - take care here with kids as this can be a busy road! Take the first left turn down St Annes Terrace and follow it to the end to get to Nightingale Woods. St. Annes Station 1900 On your left there used to be St Annes railway station - where once a large boulder stood in memorial of a brave soul. On Friday March 31st 1876, just after 2 p.m., a local train passed on the up line towards Bath. It is considered possible that this train shook and so dislodged a big boulder. A few minutes later, on the opposite line, the West of England express from Paddington known as the 'Flying Dutchman' (then the fastest train in the world) was travelling towards Bristol at 50 m.p.h. There are two tunnels on this part of the line, and as the express came out of the Bristol end of one of them its fireman saw a huge stone lying right across the rails. In the same fleeting moment he saw a man trying to move it. By a superhuman effort the man managed to clear the line in spite of the enormous weight of the stone and so saved the whole train from almost certain disaster, for there is little doubt that it would have de-railed and rolled down the bank into the River Avon. However before he could get clear himself the engine struck and threw him a distance of eight or nine yards. On being picked up he breathed just once and then quietly died. The train had been saved by the courage of a man called Jack Chiddy, who at 47 lived in Hanham with his wife and seven children. A curious Brunel relic, the Apple Stone is the name of the huge bolder that was taken from the St Anne's Tunnel in Brislington and preserved by Brunel in memory of Jack Chiddy. It is now clearly visible from Woodland Road. .. but its plaque bears no mention of John Chiddy. Bristol University had hoped to credit the Victorian hero, but British Rail has no record to support his tale of heroism. Whilst steam trains rarely come this way, it is still exciting to stand here and watch/listen to the trains come past. The cache itself is hopefully an item Brunel would have appreciated, had he been a geocacher! Not much room in here! The cache is next to Brislington Boat Screen, built in 1978 to divert floodwaters from the brook under the hill to the East and into the River Avon. To protect the tunnel from blockages a large 3-tier screen was constructed in the shape of a boat, hence the locally used name “Brislington Boat Screen”.

properties.name: Metamorphosis
properties.gc_short_desc: This cache is named after the location and its contents are themed. It is situated in the quiet Hampshire chalk downlands, with sheep in nearby fields, on the outskirts of Winchester.
properties.gc_long_desc: The best time of year to visit is between March and September. The prize is situated just outside a small 5-acre conservation area. There is no need to climb fences there are plenty of footpaths and gates. This area will be of special interest to those in touch with nature. The cache is accessible via a number footpaths from various directions with a children’s play park fairly close by, with limited parking at in residential area at N 51° 02.522 / W 001° 21.038 The cache is a small ammo box, please take a photo with the camera and note any interesting sightings in the logbook. To see photos of previous visitors Click Here The cache is a small ammo box, please take a photo with the camera and note any interesting sightings in the logbook.

properties.name: The Great Dell
properties.gc_short_desc: This is a short multi-cache situated in 'The Great Dell' within Royal Victoria Park. It should be completed within 30 minutes, and you are looking for a 3" plastic tub that contains a log sheet and pencil, and is big enough for coins and small trackable items. Sorry that this cache is not wheelchair accessible due to steps. Strollers a possibility! Please note that the park gates are locked at 8pm!
properties.gc_long_desc:
The posted co-ordinates should take you to an obvious memorial, that celebrates the birthday of a famous person.

How many letters are in this persons name? Call this AB
How many letters are in the month inscribed? Call this C

Now go to: N51 23.(C-A-B)(A+B)(A+B+C)  W002 22.C(C+A)(C+B)

Here is a much smaller memorial dedicated to the Coldstream Guards Association. It has 2 dates listed.
Call these DEFG and HIJK

Now go and find the cache at: N51 23.FA(F+C)   W002 22.(C+H)CC

Please make sure that the cache is tucked back carefully so that is is not easily visible, and be mindful of watching Muggles. Thank you!

properties.name: CORTON RING 25
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The caches are set in such a way that they can be completed in one 12 mile round walk or attempted in two separate 6 mile circular walks.  Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

Have fun!

properties.name: Leigh Side
properties.gc_short_desc: A lovely walk through ancient woodland with occasional views across the Avon Gorge.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This micro-cache is situated in Leigh Woods close to Clifton Suspension Bridge and is best approached via the A369 Portishead to Bristol road. There is ample free parking at N51 27.794  W2 38.725 which is the start of several colour coded trails through the woods. The cache is located half way around the purple trail.
Leigh Woods cover 440 acres and is a site of Special Scientific Interest. You may be lucky enough to see Peregrine Falcons and Green Woodpeckers and there are also some deer in the forest. 
The trail is hard surfaced , suitable for push-chairs and unlikely to become too muddy even during heavy rain. There are some seating areas on the walk suitable for picnics.
There is the occasional view across the River Avon to the Sea Mills area of Bristol.
Whilst the heavy tree cover will give problems with your GPS there are enough open areas to help you navigate to the cache area.
The cache itself is a 35mm film cannister which is only large enough to hold a small log-book and pencil.

Have fun!

properties.name: Hansel and Gretel
properties.gc_short_desc: A lovely woodland walk on tarmac paths in a forest gorge.
properties.gc_long_desc:
I suggest leaving your car at the large public car-park at N51 30.305 W2 38.212. This is a free car-park and the cache is hidden along a paved path / road about 1 mile away and the return journey should be completed within 1 hour.
The path passes alongside a very large and well-laid out children`s play area. It then leads you very close to Blaise Castle Museum which is open Saturday - Wednesday from 10am to 5pm. It is well worth a short visit. Keep to the path down into the valley. Here you will pass the disused Stratford Mill. It was moved here in the 1960`s to preserve it from demolition. Follow the Rhododendron Path which winds it`s way up the other side of the gorge. You will eventually arrive at the most amazing wooden cottage ,hence the name of this cache. I have not been able to find any details of it`s age etc. so if anyone can help perhaps they could let me know. The roof is obviously recent but I have seen much older photos when it had a thatched roof.
The cache is fairly well hidden and with heavy tree cover in the summer months you may well need the clue and spoiler photo. (I had no problem with GPS signal in January.) It contains a log-book and some small items.

properties.name: Frome - by the Numbers
properties.gc_short_desc: An interesting walk thru the old streets of Frome along part of the “Frome Town Trail” with its Numbered Plaques.  This 4 stop multi cache is a mile including the walk to the final cache and return to the INFO centre.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The Frome tourist information centre is in the Round Tower just off the town centre car park at N51 13.953 W2 19.210.  It’s open Monday-Saturday 10am - 5pm.

Frome has a market here on Wednesdays and Saturdays so parking can be a bit busy then.

The info centre has maps of the Frome Town Trail for sale that will lead you on a guided walk of historic Frome and provide some interesting history.  The spots on the Map are marked by large round plaques.  You might want to pick up a copy of the map for the history, but it’s not needed to complete the cache as the answers are mostly posted on plaques.  Don’t forget to enjoy Frome while you walk through and find the numbers! :-)

(1)  The posted coordinates take you to the Market Cross [plaque 2].  What year was the cross originally erected?  The answer is in the form ABCD

(2)  From the market cross walk up medieval Cheap street, where an ancient leat still channels the spring water down the centre of the pavement.  When you reach the top you will find the source of the water at coordinates N51 13.817 W 002 19.236.  There is a sign at the fountain with 6 words on it.  Record the number of letters in the 5th and 6th words.  These will be E and F.

(3)  From the fountain walk up the church steps that lead to the entrance of St. Johns Church.  Count the number of steps.  Let the number of steps be GH.

(4)  Now turn right at the top of the steps and navigate to N51 13.860 W2 19.416   You will need to cross the street in front of the church and go up Catherine Hill street and find plaque #11 at Shepherd’s Barton.   According to the plaque, St. Katherine’s Chapel was founded before what year?  The answer gives you JKLM.

You can walk back down Catherine Hill turning left at the bottom to the market cross to have a seat and work out the final cache location.  Now we find out if you got all the right numbers!  The final cache is about a quarter of a mile from the cross and is found by putting all the numbers into this form.  N 51 AE.HBD  W 002 GF.(K+M)KJ  

You can get there either by walking along the road [this is the best route if you've got push chairs and need to avoid steps] or better yet take the public foot path along the river.  Cache is in a camo coloured tupperware type box. Some Frome Goodies there.

properties.name: CORTON RING 17
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.

Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: ACT #03 - Forest Clump
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is part of a series of 34 caches, plus a bonus cache and 4
other existing caches that follows the 12.5 mile "Aldbourne
Circular National Trail" on the north Wiltshire Downs, just a short
distance from Swindon. There are some stunning views and it is
suitable for walkers, horse riders and cyclists and the whole
series can be completed in a single day.
properties.gc_long_desc: This Cache - Camouflaged 140ML clip lockbox. Remember to check for the Bonus Cache combination! See 01 Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the series. See Bonus - Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the Bonus Cache.

properties.name: ACT #04 - Plantation
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is part of a series of 34 caches, plus a bonus cache and 4
other existing caches that follows the 12.5 mile "Aldbourne
Circular National Trail" on the north Wiltshire Downs, just a short
distance from Swindon. There are some stunning views and it is
suitable for walkers, horse riders and cyclists and the whole
series can be completed in a single day.
properties.gc_long_desc: This Cache - 35mm Film Pot Remember to check for the Bonus Cache combination! See 01 Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the series. See Bonus - Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the Bonus Cache.

properties.name: Knights Challenge..2...Swineford Picnic Area.
properties.gc_short_desc:
This cache is one of a series of 4, which carry clues to find the Knights Challenge Bonus cache. In each of the series you will find a coded reference to part of the coordinates for the final cache. To decode these you need to refer to the further instructions contained in the Bonus Cache page.
This is almost a cache and dash.The paths are gravelled and flat.Only the final 2m to the cache require you to leave the path.
properties.gc_long_desc:
In decent weather the area near the parking spot might be suitable for a picnic, or the nearby public house The Swan, alledgedly does good food.

Follow the path, which could be muddy in wet weather, through the wooded area alongside the stream, to the cache site. Tree cover may make Gps readings vary so you may need to revert to the clue.

properties.name: Farleigh Castle
properties.gc_short_desc: 40 min round trip country walk offering views of Farleigh Castle. Can get muddy and not suitable for pushchairs.
properties.gc_long_desc: Thanks to G&C who have recently archived their cache in this area and who agreed we could place here. The area deserves a cache of its own and I believe the walk is well worth the visit back to those who have already found the archived cache.

properties.name: ACT #05 - Tumulus
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is part of a series of 34 caches, plus a bonus cache and 4
other existing caches that follows the 12.5 mile "Aldbourne
Circular National Trail" on the north Wiltshire Downs, just a short
distance from Swindon. There are some stunning views and it is
suitable for walkers, horse riders and cyclists and the whole
series can be completed in a single day.
properties.gc_long_desc: This Cache - Camouflaged 1/2 litre Clip lock box Remember to check for the Bonus Cache combination! See 01 Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the series. See Bonus - Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the Bonus Cache.

properties.name: Ghost Train........
properties.gc_short_desc:
*****SCARY CACHE*****SCARY CACHE*****SCARY CACHE*****SCARY CACHE*****

Round trip walk of about 40 mins. Could get muddy and not 
suitable for wheel/pushchairs.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache, originally hidden by 'Fruitdrop' was one of our favourite ever and after being archived we felt we had to rehide to encourage people back. 

It can be hard to find the path in so parking coordinates are N51 22.151 W002 21.886.

This cache is spooky so be warned!!!! I certainly wouldn't try it at night. Can you spot the ghostly train?? Many local residents have reported seeing the ghostly vision running between the hours of 9pm and 11pm...so avoid these hours if you can....

properties.name: Walks & Views Galore-ious Revisited No2
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is a relatively simple off-set multi-cache, one of a series
that replaces the original Walks & Views Galore-ious
Multi-cache that was near Warminster. It will take you to some
beautiful Wiltshire downland countryside with fantastic views and a
lot of history; there are also some very old woodlands close by.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache is located off a back road between Stockton and
Sherrington Down on a public footpath on route to Boyton Down.
Despite being a multi-cache, it is actually a cache and dash taking
less than 30 minutes if you are in a hurry. However, the public
footpath and bridleways crossing this point can take you to some of
Wiltshire’s incredibly beautiful chalk downland countryside and
interesting woodlands including Stockton and Great Ridge where
several other caches are to be found.
The co-ordinates given are for the parking place at the side of
the road. To find the cache you need to be observant where you park
as there are some large storage tanks close by; count them and the
answer =A. The cache, which has plenty of contents and room inside,
can be found at:
N51º 08.1(9-A)4 W002º 03.8(6+A)(3+A)
Please make sure the cache is well hidden when you replace
it.

properties.name: Bat Caves
properties.gc_short_desc: Short woodland walk in Murhill near Winsley. Can get very muddy and not suitable for push/wheelchairs. Look out for the caves during the cache which are home to loads of bats.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This cache replaces the Murhill Monster which had unfortunately been lost down a deep chasm. (ask Ailec Nor!!). The marking of this cache proved to be VERY difficult due to tree cover so a good clue is provided.
The caves are part of a small mine complex (the Murhill / Winsley Rift Mine) and are now home to several species of protected bats (see the following web-link:  www.english-nature.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005675.pdf).   The mine itself consisted of two small underground workings from which stone was hauled via an inclined tramway to the nearby Kennet and Avon canal.

properties.name: Something Sinister... (Staffordshire)
properties.gc_short_desc:
>>Incoming Transmission... 
#User: MarcB
properties.gc_long_desc:
#Background: 
It should have been a simple task. Geocache 'GCGHRC' aka
Alternative Alton persisted to stay hidden. Why? I did not know. As
if possessed, it kept shedding it's cover - it had laid at the base
of the Churnet Valley for over a year and a half and had been the
black sheep in the arsenal of my caches. Everyone had found it so
easy to find... 
# 
It needed to be removed. 
#Main:
I felt the need to rehide it in the local area. If only I had known
the trouble that it would cause...
#
I recommend you park at Ramblers' Retreat:
#Co-Ord
N52°59.150
 W001°54.531
-It is the only feasible way to approach the location.
#
It is situated in the vicinity of the 'Hex' tree - the oak tree
tied up in chains which forms the centrepiece of Alton Towers' ride
of the same name.
#
For those that don't know, a curse was (supposedly) put on this
tree by a witch. As punishment to the Earl of Alton Towers for
treating her badly, everytime a branch fell off the tree, a member
of his family would die. In fear, the Earl had the Oak chained up
so no branches would ever fall...
#
On 01/04/05, something didn't want me to hide the cache there. My
GPS failed as I was placing the ammo box. It is now broken and
needs replacing.
#Final:
I recommend this only to the bravest cachers - the terrain is
uneven and can be very muddy. The location is very eerie; faint
screams were heard at the time of my visit.
#
Always be discreet, rehide the cache well and remember...
...Something or Someone doesn't want you there...
#End Transmission

properties.name: ACT #06 - Coney-warren
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is part of a series of 34 caches, plus a bonus cache and 4
other existing caches that follows the 12.5 mile "Aldbourne
Circular National Trail" on the north Wiltshire Downs, just a short
distance from Swindon. There are some stunning views and it is
suitable for walkers, horse riders and cyclists and the whole
series can be completed in a single day.
properties.gc_long_desc: This Cache - Camouflaged 1/2 litre Clip lock box Remember to check for the Bonus Cache combination! See 01 Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the series. See Bonus - Aldbourne Circular Trail for full details about the Bonus Cache.

properties.name: BeachComber 02
properties.gc_short_desc: A small clip and lock container with some goodies and log
properties.gc_long_desc:
Located on the beach at Bigbury On Sea

This cache is easily accessed but some climbing is needed, not recommended for smaller children.

Please take care when getting to this cache and ensure you are confident to be able to get to it without any risk to yourself or others as the rocks can be a little slippery, especially if the tide hasnt been out for long.

Please note, the tide can affect access to this cache. Keep in mind getting back as well as getting there so you aren't waiting for the tide to go back out

properties.name: CORTON RING 16
properties.gc_short_desc: Following the success of our nearby Littlecombe Ring Series we couldn’t resist setting another trail.  This series of 44 caches of differing sizes, shapes and hides will lead you through more of the Wiltshire countryside leading up to the Great Ridge and Longdean Bottom and then down into the Wylye Valley through the villages of Sherrington, Upton Lovell and Corton.
properties.gc_long_desc:
The caches are set in such a way that they can be completed in one 12 mile round walk or attempted in two separate 6 mile circular walks.  Either way we hope you enjoy the walk and countryside as much as we did when setting the Ring.  Look out for some splendid scenery and an abundance of wildlife.

Other caches in the immediate area include Camouflage 2 (GCXGP0), Q=10 (GCWB49), Walks and Views Galore-ious Revisited 2 (GC18PR0), Herne2’s Little Thing 3 & 4 (GCQPC6) & (GCQPCH), Church Micro 475 Sherrington (GC1MRV6).  Walks & Views, Little Thing 4 and the Church Micro are directly en route.

Have fun!

properties.name: K6 x 4
properties.gc_short_desc: The cache is not at the above location but can be found within a mile of here.
properties.gc_long_desc:
To find the final location of this cache you will need to
go to the co-ordinates above. There you will find all the
information required to decode the following two lines.
N SW8,NE9,SW10,SE3,NE4,NW8,SW9.W
NW10,NE9,SW3,SW8,(NE6+SW5),NW5.
The cache is available 24/7 and as GPS reception in the
area is poor, we have given a large clue.

properties.name: 1066 Trail 3
properties.gc_short_desc:
In Battle town there is limited free parking or a couple of pay and display car parks. There is also limited free parking in Marley Lane.
Please be careful at cache location as there is a steep slope near to where cache is hidden.
properties.gc_long_desc:
This is one of 5 caches by us around the historic town of Battle in East Sussex. All of which can be done individually or as a longer circular walk through both town & countryside, taking in all the sights of this historic town along the way.

If approaching from Marley Lane, you will need to take the Public Footpath down through Lake Field. The National Trust was able to acquire Lake Field in 1938 & so preserve the view to the North.

When standing at the top of Lake Field you will be able to see the sails & top of a windmill if you look carefully.

Alternatively you can take the footpath down through the church car park or the footpath which leads down from Mount Street. Depending which direction you approach the cache, the walk can be quite hilly.

This is a 450m clip-n-lock plastic container inside a camo drawstring bag, with certificates for the first 3 to find.
Contents when placed -
log book & pencil
Mini Torch, 
shopping trolley token, 
yo-yo, 
dice,
2 x bouncy balls, 
ladybird eraser, 
cat highlighter pen.

Please ensure that cache is fastened securely, replaced carefully & is covered well...

This is a popular area & stealth may be required.

If continuing the series, you will approach through fields from the bottom.You can then take the public footpath up through Lake Field and down towards Battle Railway Station.

* Drawstring bag is missing, now just a cache container *

properties.name: Grovely's Witchcraft Ring No2
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is number 2 of the Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring which is a series
of 24 caches placed in a figure of eight of various sizes and
difficult to complement the Grovely Series which is a little
further to the West.
properties.gc_long_desc: Full details of these Witchcraft stories are included on the Govely’s Witchcraft Ring Listing No1 (GC1XF72) and No 10 (GC1XFDM). Details of parking places, access and other information are also provided on those listings. This figure of eight ring is about 9 miles long and does keep to the Roman road, public paths, bridleways, etc. At times, for those that do the full ring, the going is very hard as there are some hills to climb and descend. Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging. You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village..

properties.name: The Grovely Ring Golden Cache
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Golden Cache is what it says, a securely hidden large golden chest, well ammo box, packed with goodies and of course a log book, also camera to record your visit if you wish. You can only retrieve this cache by completing some of the Grovely Ring series of caches,
properties.gc_long_desc:
The co-ordinates given above relate to one of the parking places near the start of the Grovely Ring Series, not the location of the Golden Cache itself. Don’t feel constrained to start here, as access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock; plus loads of other place if you want a really long walk. 

When walking the Ring series  each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A to E. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start. Failing that, depending on your chosen route, if its not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds; good luck.

In order to find this Golden cache you must collect the values of A, B. C, D & E. from the lids or log sheets within the series caches. If you want to do this Golden cache with the minimum number of finds on the ring that is possible by studying cache listings. Each listing contains a single clue to which letter is contained within a given cache; however, that process may take you a considerable time, possibly longer than walking the ring itself which is about 4 hours on a good day.  Be warned boots are advisable. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All Ring caches are place on or within a few feet of a public footpath, bridleways, etc. You should not need to climb fences or stiles, although you will need to open and close the occasional field gate; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

The Golden cache is located at: 

N51º  0(A+E). (C+D)(E-D-B)E    W001º  5(B+C+D).DE(B+C)

When you have found the cache please hide the container well, in theory as you should find it.

properties.name: Grovely Ring No4
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Ring  is a series of  24 caches of various sizes and difficulty. This is the 4th in the series we placed. The 7 mile walk, which could last well over 4 hours, will take you around the Western end of Grovely woods enjoying a variety of scenery from dense woodland to open high elevation downland with spectacular views over the Wiltshire countryside. Success with the Ring will give you the opportunity to visit the Grovely Golden Cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking place co-ordinated are provided within the listings for Grovely Ring No1 & No2, these allow the easiest walk and are convenient for the Grovely Golden Cache. However, don’t feel constrained to start here, access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock. If you want an even longer walk, there are tracks up to Grovely from Wilton at Water Ditchampton and from Wishford with a bit of a climb. 

When walking this series each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A, B, C, D and E., which should help locate the Grovely Golden Cache. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although very unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start your walk: see Golden Cache listing for details of the short cut. Failing that depending on your chosen route, if it’s not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds to gather the values; good luck.

Be warned comfortable footwear and walking boots are advisable when attempting the Ring. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All caches are placed on or within a few feet of public footpaths, bridleways, etc. You should not need to climb fences or even stiles, although you will be required to open and close a couple of field gates; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions, so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

Please hide cahe containers well, hopefully as you find them and remember to note the value of that letter A, B, C, D & E.

properties.name: Grovely Ring No22
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Ring is a series of  24 caches of various sizes and difficulty. This was the 22nd cache in the series that we placed. The 7 mile walk, which could last well over 4 hours, will take you around the Western end of Grovely woods enjoying a variety of scenery from dense woodland to open high elevation downland with spectacular views over the Wiltshire countryside. Success with the Ring will give you the opportunity to visit the Grovely Golden Cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking place co-ordinated are provided within the listings for Grovely Ring No1 & No2, these allow the easiest walk and are convenient for the Grovely Golden Cache. However, don’t feel constrained to start here, access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock. If you want an even longer walk, there are tracks up to Grovely from Wilton at Water Ditchampton and from Wishford with a bit of a climb. 

When walking this series each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A, B, C, D and E., which should help locate the Grovely Golden Cache. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although very unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start your walk: see Golden Cache listing for details of the short cut. Failing that depending on your chosen route, if it’s not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds to gather the values; good luck.

Be warned comfortable footwear and walking boots are advisable when attempting the Ring. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All caches are placed on or within a few feet of public footpaths, bridleways, etc. You should not need to climb fences or even stiles, although you will be required to open and close a couple of field gates; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. Please ensure all gates are fully closed after passing through, even if they were open when you arrived. There have been cases, due to inconsiderate walkers, of cattle escaping into the woods, much to the annoyance of their owners. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions, so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

Please hide cach containers well, hopefully as you find them and remember to note the value of that letter A, B, C, D & E.

properties.name: Secret Hi-de Away
properties.gc_short_desc:
Unless you live in the area, you may not be aware that this is
here. It boasts fantastic views of Norwich's landmarks, and has a
rich and varied history. The cache is placed with the permission of
the Green Spaces Officer for Norwich City Council, Paul Holley.
Please note that the stipulation is it can be here as long as the
historic ruins are not disturbed or damaged in any way. The cache
is not, and can not be, placed in the ruins.
properties.gc_long_desc: This place offers a unique chance to escape from the hustle and bustle of this part of Norwich. Fantastic pictorial views of Norwich, and also a good place for CITO if you have a little time. If you stand in just the right place, the cathedral can be seen, framed by two trees either side, natures own picture frame! There is only one unmarked entrance now, shown on the info boards in situ. There is very limited 2 hour parking at N52 38 0319 E 001 18 8118, parking can also be found on residential areas behind this. Watch out for permit parking areas in the vacinity. Entrance is through the double black metal gates. Unless you fancy bumping up a pram, it's best to take children on foot, as it's very steep. The cache contains a log book, pencil (please leave), swag and has space for flattish TBs and GCs. It is very well hidden, due to this being a popular dog walking area. Please leave it how it is, and let me know if you need help or it has moved from the co-ords please. Only use the clue if you really must. ****** Congratulations to Globetrotter UK and Galaxy Travellers for joint FTF ************ This Cache was set by a member of the East Anglian Cachers Forum

properties.name: Witchcraft Ring Bonus-The Very Isolated Sister
properties.gc_name: Witchcraft Ring Bonus-The Very Isolated Sister
properties.gc_short_desc:
An added cache to take you close to what we believe to be the beech tree which may have been associated with the most mischievous sister who was buried well away from the others.

The co-ordinates given are not that of the cache just a point in the woods.
properties.gc_long_desc:
During your walk around Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring many of the caches or listings display a value of  V, X, Y and Z, some have all 4 values close to the Bonus. If you note these as you go, the bonus cache is to be found at

N51º  0(Y-V).0((V+Z)-(X+Y))0

W001º  5X.(Y-V)(V+X)Z

properties.name: Grovely's Witchcraft Ring No19
properties.gc_short_desc: This is number 19 of the Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring which is a series of 24 caches, placed in a figure of eight, of various sizes and difficult to complement the Grovely Series which is a little further to the West.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Full details of the Witchcraft stories are included on the Govely’s Witchcraft Ring Listing No1 (GC1XF72) and No 10 (GC1XFDM). 

Details of parking places, access and other information are also provided on those listings. This figure of eight ring is about 9 miles long and does keep to the Roman road, public paths, bridleways, etc. At times, for those that do the full ring, the going is very hard as there are some hills to climb and descend. Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging.

You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village.

Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging.

You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village.

properties.name: Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring No22
properties.gc_short_desc:
This is number 22 of the Grovely’s Witchcraft Ring which is a
series of 24 caches, placed in a figure of eight, of various sizes
and difficult to complement the Grovely Series which is a little
further to the West.
properties.gc_long_desc: Full details of the Witchcraft stories are included on the Govely’s Witchcraft Ring Listing No1 (GC1XF72) and No 10 (GC1XFDM). Details of parking places, access and other information are also provided on those listings. This figure of eight ring is about 9 miles long and does keep to the Roman road, public paths, bridleways, etc. At times, for those that do the full ring, the going is very hard as there are some hills to climb and descend. Please note some of the paths are muddy in the winter or after heavy rain so boots are advisable; certain paths are also very rutted for very short distances due to the movement of heavy machines used when logging. You can start this ring from several places; the Wilton/Water Ditchampton end of Grovely, Wishford and Barford St Martin but if you want to get the steepest hill climbing over early start from Wishford, there is plenty of on road parking places in the village.

properties.name: Grovely Ring No12
properties.gc_short_desc: The Grovely Ring  is a series of  24 caches of various sizes and difficulty. This was the 12th cache we placed in the series. The 7 mile walk, which could last well over 4 hours, will take you around the Western end of Grovely woods enjoying a variety of scenery from dense woodland to open high elevation downland with spectacular views over the Wiltshire countryside. Success with the Ring will give you the opportunity to visit the Grovely Golden Cache.
properties.gc_long_desc:
Parking place co-ordinated are provided within the listings for Grovely Ring No1 & No2, these allow the easiest walk and are convenient for the Grovely Golden Cache. However, don’t feel constrained to start here, access is possible from Hanging Langford via the Hollows footpath and from Baverstock. If you want an even longer walk, there are tracks up to Grovely from Wilton at Water Ditchampton and from Wishford with a bit of a climb. 

When walking this series each cache contains a vital bit of information, a value of A, B, C, D and E., which should help locate the Grovely Golden Cache. As these values are repeated several times over the series, in theory you could have the required information with only 5 finds, although very unlikely unless you are prepared to do much homework before you start your walk: see Golden Cache listing for details of the short cut. Failing that depending on your chosen route, if it’s not your lucky day, it could take as many as 17 finds to gather the values; good luck.

Be warned comfortable footwear and walking boots are advisable when attempting the Ring. Some paths and tracks are steep in places for short distances and can be very muddy and rutted, particularly in the winter or after heavy rain. 

All caches are placed on or within a few feet of public footpaths, bridleways, etc. You should not need to climb fences or even stiles, although you will be required to open and close a couple of field gates; this is all legal as it’s a public right of way but be careful if cattle or sheep are grazing. You will also cross relatively quiet public roads on a couple of occasions, so please be very careful if you have children and dogs along.

The difficulty rating is associated with tree cover and poor GPS reception.

Please hide cache continers well, hopefully as you find them and remember to note the value of that letter A, B, C, D & E.

properties.name: Longwell Green Mega Series #17
properties.gc_long_desc: This is number 17 of a 24 caches set up in a 7.43 mile circular walk most of the caches are set up in a distance ranging from 0.2 - 0.35 miles. The walk takes you up through Hanham Hills down into Hanham woods, then past the chocolate factory and through willsbridge mill, then through Longwell Green back to your car. Please try to do these caches as a day walk (instead of doing a few at a time), for me setting it up. It took 3 1/2 hours and ther are a couple of pubs and resturants on the way. (a perfect place for a break) parking is available feet from the first cache.

properties.name: Longwell Green Mega Series #20
properties.gc_long_desc: This is number 20 of a 24 caches set up in a 7.43 mile circular walk most of the caches are set up in a distance ranging from 0.2 - 0.35 miles.
